REPLIES TO REQUESTS FOR DETAILED INFORMATION
Joint House Department
On 28 April 1981, Mr Les Johnson asked Mr Speaker:
(1) Further to his answer to my request for information relating to the disposal of waste paper from Parliament House (Hansard, 26 March 1981, page 1046) why were tenders not called for this service.
(2) When was the present private treaty arrangement entered into.
(3) Was consideration given to allowing charities to clear the waste paper by private treaty under the same terms and conditions as presently apply; if so, what were the reasons for not proceeding.
(4) Has an estimate been made of the value of the private treaty; if so, what is that estimate.
Mr Speaker-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) There is no file record of why tenders were not called.
(2) The date the private treaty was entered into is not known, a memorandum on file dated 2 August 1971 states that the arrangement had operated for many years.

(3) There is no record of any charities having applied for or having been considered for this concession.
(4) No.
The private treaty with Mr A. T. Cooper was terminated at his request on 10 April 1981. Arrangements have since been made for the removal of waste paper from Parliament House to be effected by the general contractor to the Department of Administrative Services--a Canberra paper and cardboard recycling company, to make a regular clearance free of charge, for a period of 1 year. At the expiration of that period new arrangements will be considered.
Joint House Department On 3 June 1981, Mr Holding asked Mr Speaker:
(1) When was Mr James Murray Jorgensen appointed to the Position of Permanent Head of the Joint House Department.
(2) Was the appointment announced in either House; if so, when; if not, why not.
(3) Prior to the appointment ofMr Jorgensen to his current position, was he Federal Executive Director of the Master Builders' Federation of Australia; if so, for what period.
(4) Has he been a Director of Palmdale Insurance; if so, for what period.
Mr Speaker-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) 17 July 1980.
(2) No. The Appointment was made during the Parliamentary recess and was notified in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette No. 31 of31 July 1980.
(3) Yes. From March 1968 to July 1980.
(4) Yes. From May 1976 to January 1980.

3462 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981 ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

Answers to Questions

The following answers to questions were circulated:

Employment Figures: Civilian Employees Series
(Question No. 457)
Mr Willis asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:
Does the Australian Bureau of Statistics intend to republish employment figures in the Civilian Employees series which was suspended in April 1980; ifso, when.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
I refer the honourable member to my answer to Part (2) of Question 1938 (Hansard, 26 May 1981, page 2623).
Functions of Government Returned to the States
(Question No. 594)
Mr McLean asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister in Federal Affairs, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:
What functions of government have been returned to the States since 11 November 1975.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
See the answer of 21 August 1979 given by Senator Carrick in reply to a similar question by Senator Wriedt (Senate Hansard, pages 49-52). The following additional information is provided:
Minister for Aboriginal AffairsLocal government/municipal type services provided by the
Department of Aboriginal Affairs to Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory, with the exception of those on pastoral properties, were transferred to the Northern Territory Government from 1 Feburary 1980.
Funding provided under the Department of Aboriginal Affairs culture, recreation and sport program to the YMCA in the Northern Territory was transferred to the Northern Territory Government as from 1 February 1980.

Commonwealth legislation to extend State powers to the territorial sea, including the seabed, has been enacted and is to come into force on a day to be proclaimed.
Minister for EducationApprovals of certain categories ofnew courses at colleges of
advanced education, which previously had been given by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, are now the responsibility of State authorities.
The provision of education services and responsibility for education matters in the Northern Territory, with the exception of those of a national nature for which the Commonwealth has a continuing responsibility. were transferred to the Northern Territory Government on 1 July 1979.
Under the Transition from School to Work Program, responsibility for approval of program proposals for 1981 has been substantially devolved to the State level.
Minister for Housing and ConstructionResponsibility for Northern Territory education buildings,
design. construction and maintenance was transferred to the Northern Territory Government on I July 1979.
Minister for National Development and EnergyThe Bureau of Mineral Resources is in the process of trans-
ferring responsibility to the States and the Northern Territory Government for the revision of the 1:250,000 scale geological map series.
Powers and functions under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 in respect of the areas adjacent to the Northern Territory and to the Ashmore and Cartier Islands were transferred to the Northern Territory Government on 12 June 1979.
With respect to offshore mining to the outer limit of the 3 mile territorial sea and subterranean mining extending from the land mass, Commonwealth legislation to transfer responsibility has been passed but it has not yet been proclaimed. The legislation is part of the overall offshore constitutional package which awaits completion by the enactment of complementary State legislation.

Attorney-GeneralTaxation, industrial and intellectual property jurisdiction
was conferred on State and Territory Supreme Courts with effect from 15 May 1979, when the relevant provisions of the Jurisdiction of Courts (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1979 came into force. That Act also invested State and Territory Supreme Courts with jurisdiction in certain matters arising under the Financial Agreements (Commonwealth Liability) Act 1932 and the Overseas Telecommunications Act 1946, in which jurisdiction had previously been exercisable only by the High Court.
Responsibility for the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory was transferred to the Northern Territory Government on I October 1979 upon the proclamation of the Northern Territory Supreme Court (Repeal) Act 1979, which enabled the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory to be established under an Act of the Northern Territory.
The Supreme Courts of the States have been invested with federal jurisdiction to deal with chambers applications in matters pending in the Federal Court of Australia.
The functions of the Australian Legal Aid Office have been absorbed by the State Legal Aid Commission in Queensland.

TransportAll Commonwealth funding for the MITERS (Minor Im-
provements to Traffic Engineering and Road Safety) program under the Roads Grants Act 1980 ceased by 30 June 1980.
Transfer of 'State-type' aviation powers to the Northern Territory Government was effected on 1 June 1980.
The Navigation Amendment Act 1980 gives effect to the Commonwealth/State Agreement on Shipping and Navigation responsibilities that formed part of the Constitutional Offshore Settlement. The Act ensures that the Sates have responsibility for trading vessels on intra-State voyages, fishing vessels other than those on overseas voyages, pleasure craft, inland waterways vessels and offshore industry vessels whose operations are confined to the one State. The relevant provisions of the Act have been proclaimed and came into eff~t on 1 February 1981. Previously, the Commonw.ealth regulatedsome aspects of the navigation of these vessels.' <
Minister for Veterans' AffairsNegotiations are nearing completion with the Northern
Territory Department of Health concerning the transfer ofresponsibility for the cost of orthoses to non-repatriation

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3463

beneficiaries resident in the Northern Territory to the Northern Territory Government.
In addition, the Prime Minister announced the early transfer of a number of functions to the States in his MiniSterial Statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions on 30 April 1981.
Wanniassa High School Buildings, Australian Capital Territory ."
(Question No. (38)
Mrs Kelly asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:
(1) Does his Department propose to extend the arrangements for-the provision of accommodation for Trinity College and Cowman College, in the Wanniassa High School buildings, Australian Capital Territory, beyond 1981; if so, for how long.
(2) Does the arrangement represent a change in attitude by the Government on the utilisation of Govermnent school buildings; if so, what change has been made.
(3) What costs are borne by the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority under this arrangement in terms of (a) heating, (b) lighting, (c) maintenance, (d) staff and (e) equipment.
(4) Was action taken to evaluate the effect of these arrangements on the curricula and educational opportunities offered to Wanniassa High School students; if so, what action and will he make available any studies or reports on this matter.
(5) What provision has been made for accommodation for community groups which would normally utilise school buildings. whilst non-govermnent schools occupy parts of WanniassaHigh School.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Government school buildings are provided primarily for education purposes. Use of portion of the Wanniassa High School building by Trinity College and Cowman College meets that criterion without effect on normal community access. In agreeing to this arrangement, which expires at the end of the 1981 school year, the ACT Schools Authority took into account the effect on curricula and education opportunities offered to Wanniassa High students. The two nongovermnent schools meet all costs associated with their tenancy with the exception of structural maintenance which is a normal landlord cost;
It is unlikely that Trinity Christian School and Cowman College will be accommodated in Wanniassa High School in
1982 as development of that school will require additional ac-
commodation. In the context of the Review of Government Functions, the Government has announced that it will actively promote the more economical and efficient use of government and non-government school.}mildings. In the light of this decision, I have asked the ACT Schools Authority to examine the question of locating Trinity Christian School, Cowman College and O'Connor Christian School in surplus accommodation in government schools that will be available in 1982 for alternative uses.
Agricultural Land: Purchases by Foreign Interests
(Question No. (46)
Mr Wallis asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:

(1) Has his attention been drawn to the concern expressed by rural organisations at the extent of the purchase of agriculturalland by foreign interests.
(2) Are records kept which indicate the extent of these purchases.
(3) Are there any restrictions in force to control the pur-
chase of agricultural land by foreign interests; if so, how do
these restrictions compare with the restrictions that apply in countries such as New Zealand, Canada and the United States of America.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes, I am aware that some rural organisations have expressed concern about foreign ownership of rural land. The Government respects such views and through its policy on foreign investment looks very closely at proposed acquisitions of rural land by foreign interests. Before any approval is given, other than in c.ases where the purchasers are Australian citizens resident abroad or genuinely intending immigrants, the parties must demonstrate that Australians have been given adequate prior opportunity to purchase the land if they wished to do so and that there will be benefits through development of the property or otherwise to Australia from the investment.
(2) The Foreign Investment Review Board keeps records of the proposals submitted for approval under the Govermnent's foreign investment policy. These records do not, however, indicate whether the purchases take place. Similarly the Board's statistics do not record sales by foreign interests to Australians as these proposals do not require notification. I am forwarding to the honourable member a paper on foreign investment in rural land which outlines in some detail the Government's policy and provides detailed statistics.
(3) Acqnisitions of rural properties by foreign interests generally involve acquisitions of assets of Australian businesses and, as such, these transactions fall within the scope of the Foreign Takeovers Act. Proposals notified in accordance with the Act are examined by the Foreign Investment Review Board to determine whether they would lead to benefits through, for example, development, marketing and employ-- ment opportunities, and to ensure that Australians have been given an opportunity to purchase the land.
The Government considers each proposal carefuliy on the advice of the Board and grants approval only where it is satisfied that the acquisition of land by the foreign person would not be contrary to the national interest.
I am informed that the approaches adopted by the other countries mentioned by the honourable member are:
New Zealand
Under the Land Settlement Promotion and Land Acquisition Act 1952, as amended, foreign interests are restricted from acquiring rural land, offshore islands and any land required for public use. The legislation aims to restrict absentee foreign ownership of certain types of land in New Zealand.
Restriction of foreign ownership applies to any land of two hectares (five acres) or over in area which is zoned for rural purposes, or is so zoned that farming of any kind is a predominant or conditional use in that zone.
However, acquisition of land by a foreign interest may be permitted if:
the acquisition is for experimental and research purposes which would benefit New Zealand; or
intended uses of the land, other than for agriculture, clearly show significant benefits to New Zealand and thus are in the national interest; or

3464 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

an individual alien permanently resident in New Zealand farms the land exclusively for his own use and benefit and has the ability and means to achieve these purposes.
If land is part of the assets of a business, and where the consideration involved exceeds $NZ100,000, a non-resident has to notify full details to the Overseas Investment Commission of any proposal that would lead to the non-resident interests controlling 25 per cent or more of the voting rights of the business. Each proposal is considered by the Commission on its merits.
Canada
The Provinces have primary jurisdiction with respect to real estate and regulations vary according to the host Province. Some of them have fairly restrictive statutes. The regulation of foreign ownership of real estate may also fall within Federal Government responsibilities which are administered by the Foreign Investment Review Agency. Foreign acquisitions of real estate are subject to review to the extent that they represent the acquisition or control of a Canadian business.
The United States
Under the Agricultural Foreign Investment Disclosure Act 1978, all foreign interests who own or acquire United States agricultural land are required to report their holdings with the United States Department of Agriculture. This legislation is not intended to restrict or regulate land purchases or sales by foreign interests. It is aimed primarily at strengthening the efforts to monitor foreign investment in United States agriculturalland.
The American States generally have no restrictions on ownership of land by resident aliens. However, nine States have laws that generally prohibit or restrict in a major way, nonresident aliens from owning real estate. Some of these States also have restrictions on ownership of land by resident aliens. An additional four States have laws that limit the total acreage that aliens can acquire or hold and the limits range from 5 acres to 500,000 acres. Six States, five of which are included in the nine States mentioned above, have laws that permit aliens to hold land for a limited duration or require aliens to dispose of all or part of their holdings within specified time periods if they do not become United States citizens or residents of the State.
The policies of these countries are related to their particular circumstances just as the Australian policy is aimed at meeting Australia's needs. This Government's policy and the way in which it is administered provide a reasonable basis for exercising supervision and, where necessary, restraint of excessive foreign investment in Australian land.
Transportation of Deaf School Children
(Question No. 770)
Mrs Kelly asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:
(1) Were changes made in the method of transportation of deaf children attending the Page and Mawson Primary Schools in the Australian Capital Territory; if so, what were the reasons for the changes.
(2) Were consultations held with the parents and teachers involved in this matter.
(3) Is it a fact that under the new transport arrangements the children are unable to use seat belts and are not adequately supervised because the driver cannot communicate with them; if so, can the safety of the children be guaranteed.
(4) Will he take action to overcome the excessive length of time spent in travel for the children and the necessity for them to change buses.

Mr FifeThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(J) Yes. These deaf children form part of a group of handicapped children in the Australian Capital Territory who on an individual needs basis require school transport but who are not eligible for bus transport provided by the Capital Territory Health Commission. Because of difficulties associated with the then existing transport service which was provided by a local taxi co-operative, the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority invited public tenders for the provision of school transport for this group of handicapped children. A mini bus service was introduced at the beginning of the 1981 school year.
(2) Extended discussion and consultations took place prior to the decision to invite public tenders, between officers of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, and parents and teachers on questions of reliability, punctuality and safety. Various alternative modes of transport were examined. A questionnaire was sent to parents during the latter part of 1980 asking if they would be interested in transporting, with payment from the Authority, their own child and possibly other children. The responses clearly showed that generally parents were not in a position to transport their children on a regular basis, preferring the Authority to provide transport.
(3) Officers of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority have recently completed a survey of the bus service and have reported to me that although the buses being used are not fitted with seat belts, their investigations revealed that satisfactory safety standards were being maintained. It was found that the behaviour of the children was generally good and that they were well controlled by the drivers, who despite some initial problems of communication, were able to exercise reasonable care and supervision.
(4) Yes. Additional vehicles have been provided to overcome the excessive length of time spent in travel and to eliminate the need to change buses. With the exception of students travelling from Tuggeranong Valley to Lyneham, no student should now spelld more than 30 minutes on a journey to or from school.
Social Security Appeals Tribunal
(Question No. 779)
Mr Scott asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:
(I) Did the Minister's predecessor state in September 1980 that where Social Security Appeals Tribunals were to hear appeals against a medical decision, a doctor would be included on the Tribunal.
(2) Did the Minister state on 5 March 1981, almost 6 months later. that the delays in setting up the Tribunals with the inclusion of a doctor were regretted.
(3) How many invalid pensioners have gone before Tribunals, without a doctor included, since September 1980.
(4) Will these invalid pensioners have another opportunity to go before a Tribunal which includes a doctor; if not, why not.
(5) How many appellants have been refused an invalid pension having gone before a Tribunal which did not include a doctor.
(6) How many invalid pensioners have had their appeals delayed because of the failure to appoint doctors to the Tribunals.

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3465

Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3), (4) and (5) No appealinvolving a medical assessment has been heard by a Social Security Appeals Tribunal without a suitably qualified medical practitioner being a member of that Tribunal.
(6) While there have been delays in appointing medical practitioners as members of the Social Security Appeals Tribunals, it is not possible to say how many appeals have been affected by those delays.
Social Security: Payment of United Kingdom Pensions in Australia
(Question No. 842)
Mr Jull asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 March 1981:
(I) What arrangements are made for the payment of United Kingdom pensions in Australia.
(2) Does the Australian Government supplement the UK rate to bring it to the level of Australian pensions.
(3) If so, what exchange rate is used in determining the rate of payment.
(4) If the UK pensions are adjusted, is any consideration given to exchange rate fluctuations; if so, is any adjustment made by the Australian Government so that UK pensioners receive an equivalent rate.
(5) Are bank charges made for the exchange and conversion of UK pensions; if so, is the UK pensioner disadvantaged by any charge.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) The United Kingdom Department of Health and Social Security pays pensions direct to eligible persons in Australia.
(2) Yes, for people subject to the reciprocal agreement on social security between Australia and the United Kingdom.
(3) It is impracticable to ensure that Australian pensions, when affected by United Kingdom pensions, are assessed on exchange rates applied by banks in day-to-day operations. For the purpose of calculating Australian pensions a notional exchange rate is set, based on the Commonwealth Trading Bank on-demand air mail buying rate, and monitored daily. The notional exchange rate is altered when the exchange rate between the Australian and United Kingdom currencies varies by 5 cents or more Australian per one pound sterling, and appears to be relatively stable. This method of assessment is currently being reviewed.
(4) For people in Australia, United Kingdom pensions are not adjusted, but paid at the rates in force when the recipient left the United Kingdom or at the time of grant, if later. As outlined in (2) and (3) above, the Australian Government supplements the constant rate (in pounds sterling) of the UK pension to bring it up to the current level of Australian pension by using the notional exchange rate.
(5) It is understood that some banks impose a charge for the conversion of English currency drafts. To the extent that anyone may be disadvantaged, this results from the method of payment of the United Kingdom pensions.

Sheltered Workshops
(Question No. 846)
Mr Humphreys asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 March 1981:
(I) Is he able to say whether Australia is the only English speaking country which has not legislated for conditions in sheltered workshops.
(2) In this International Year of Disabled Persons, does he propose to recommend amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to ensure that persons employed in sheltered workshops gain the benefit of national wage case increases.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) The Commonwealth Government has no legislation governing conditions in sheltered workshops. I am, however, aware that some States have legislation which could be used to license, and thereby regulate, sheltered workshops. To the best of my knowledge the situation varies among other English-speaking countries.
(2) The Handicapped Persons Assistance Act, the legislation under which the Government subsidies sheltered employment services, does not prescribe working conditions for these facilities. Some control is exercised through requirements that sheltered workshops sign a written agreement when they are approved under the Act. The agreement specifies that approval is conditional upon, inter alia, payment of disabled workers according to the work they perform, and organisations' compliance with relevant State and Local Government requirements on building standards, health and sanitation, safety measures and conditions of employment.
In addition to a wage, the majority of disabled people in sheltered workshops receive Sheltered Employment Allowance. This allowance is paid at similar rates to the invalid pension and includes an income test free Incentive Allowance of $5 per week. Sheltered Employment Allowance is subject to the same terms and conditions as the Invalid Pension and undergoes regular adjustment in accordance with CPI movements. This is provided for by section 28A of the Social Services Act, the legislation under which pensions are paid. It is noteworthy that Australia's provisions in relation to Sheltered Employment Allowance were commented upon favourably at last year's World Rehabilitation Congress in Winnipeg, as a possible model for other countries.
Sheltered workshops also employ a number of able bodied people. The Government, under the provisions of the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act, subsidises the salary of any person employed in a workshop who is directly concerned with supervising or training handicapped people.
The indexing of wages for both handicapped and able bodied employees is a matter for decision by the management of each sheltered workshop.

Attachments for Television Sets for the Profoundly Deaf
(Question No. 960)
Mr Adermann asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:
(1) Does he recall my representations to him concerning Seven Tel attachments for television sets which enable the profoundly deaf to call up printed information such as news, weather, cyclone warnings, police messages and other public information bulletins.
(2) Can he say whether profoundly deaf people can get little or no benefit from public information screenings when they can see the image but hear no sound and whether the benefits of television can be considerably increased for these persons where printouts are available.
(3) Is it a fact that these attachments are expensive and attract a sales tax component.
(4) If so, wiII he consider the exemption of these attachments or television sets from sales tax where the purchaser produces a medical certification of profound deafness.
(5) Would this be an important and humane action in 1981, the International Year of Disabled Persons.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2) I would imagine that deaf persons would obtain greater benefit from television where printouts are available.
(3) The recommended retail price of $475 for an attachment includes a sales tax component of 27t per cent of the wholesale price of the attachment.
(4) and (5) In 1979 the Government widened the then existing sales tax exemption item 123 covering certain goods for use by blind persons so as to make exempt from tax goods designed and manufactured expressly for use by handicapped persons generally, unless those goods are of a kind ordinarily used by persons who are not handicapped. More recently, in the 1980-81 Budget, the Government announced its intention to support financially the observance of the International Year of Disabled Persons and its decision to implement a number of initiatives to assist disabled persons. Further initiatives in relation to the disabled wiII be considered during the preparation of the 1981-82 Budget. The matter of exempting these television attachments when for use by deaf persons will be considered in that context.

Taxation: Concessional Allowances
(Question No. 1651)
Mr Bungey asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 Apri11981:
What action has been taken on the recommendation of the Commissioner for Community Relations contained in his 5th Annual Report for the year 1979-80 (page 63), that the Australian Taxation Office consider the whole question of concessional allowances paid in respect of dependants resident overseas.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
This matter was thoroughly examined in the Report of the Review of Post-Arrival Programs and Services for Migrants (the Galbally Report) dated May 1978.
The Review group, while recognising that many migrants feel a strong obligation to give financial help to family members in their home country, noted that provisions enabling migrants to send money out of Australia were generally adequate to meet any family obligations a migrant in Australia may feel. In recording its belief that it was an unreasonable burden on the Australian taxpayer to allow tax rebates for some of these overseas payments, the Review group noted that it was extremely difficult to check claims as to the existence of the people abroad in respect of whom rebates were claimed, and, more importantly, to take into account their income for the purpose of calculating the rebate.

overseas who continue to be residents of Australia for taxation purposes, or for wives and children awaiting migration to Australia.
No new aspects have been raised which would warrant reconsideration of the matter by the Government and the Australian Taxation Office must, of course, apply the law as it is enacted.
British Pensioners in Australia
(Question No. 1675)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the fact that it is virtually impossible to secure a reply to representations on behalf of British pensioners forwarded to the British Department of Health and Social Security.
(2) Will the Minister examine the position and, if necessary, have discussions with British officials to enable British pensioners in Australia to have their complaints speedily examined.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

After careful consideration of the Report and of all other relevant issues, including especially the substantial cost to revenue caused by the mounting abuse of the rebate attributable mainly to the difficulty in checking claims noted by the Review group, the Government decided to withdraw the rebate in respect of dependants resident overseas from I November 1978. This did not affect rebates for dependants temporarily

(1) and (2) Any difficulties in obtaining replies to representations to the British Department of Health and Social Security on behalf of British pensioners had not previously been drawn to my attention. I have however asked officers of the Department of Social Security to bring the honourable member's question to the attention of officers of the British Department.

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3471

Aboriginal Housing
(Question No. 1854)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(1) What action has been taken by his Department on the recommendation contained in the 5th Annual Report, for 1979-80, of the Commissioner for Community Relations (page 58) that public housing appropriate to the needs, values and lifestyles of Aboriginal people in all States and the Northern Territory should be provided.
(2) In what way would acceptance of this recommendation require changes in the policy or practices of his Department.
Mr MeVeigh-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The 5th Annual Report of the Commissioner for Community Relations acknowledges that Aboriginals are eligible for housing assistance under general welfare housing programs. In this respect, general eligibility criteria apply to Aboriginal people along with any other groups of persons.
Aboriginals also receive special assistance by way of earmarked grants under Part III of the Housing Assistance Act 1978, and the Commonwealth-Northern Territory Housing Agreement in recognition of their special needs. Amounts of $21.06m and $22. 10m were allocated among the States and the Northern Territory for this purpose in 1979-80 and 1980-81 respectively.
Administration of all welfare housing programs funded through the Department of Housing and Construction is the responsibility of the State Governments. The earmarked funds mentioned above are directed to special programs administered by State authorities in liaison with authorities having special interests in Aboriginal housing including the regional offices of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The need to earmark funds to meet the special housing needs of Aboriginals will continue to be recognised in the proposed 1981 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement.
In addition, the Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs has for many years funded a special program of grants to State Housing Authorities for housing for Aboriginals. In recent years this program has been controlled by the 1978 Aboriginal Housing Agreement. Participation of Aboriginals in policy formulation and management matters is encouraged under this Agreement. Under this program grants totalling $12.9m and $10.7m have been allocated for 1979-80 and 1980-81 respectively.
Further, the Aboriginal Housing Association program funded by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs allows Aboriginal communities to establish, plan and administer housing schemes. Funding totalled $20.5m in 1979-80 and is estimated to be $22.lm in 1980-81.
Aboriginal Hostels Limited, a company wholly owned by the Commonwealth Government, provides a home environment enabling Aboriginals to avail themselves of education, training and employment opportunities.
The Aboriginal Development Commission makes available concessional home purchase loans to eligible Aboriginals who cannot obtain home finance on the open market.
(2) Commonwealth grants for Aboriginal housing are directed to special programs for Aboriginals which are either administered by or in liaison with the Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs and with State Government authorities having well defined responsibilities. These practices are considered to be in accordance with the recommendation of the Commissioner for Community Relations.

AIcohoUsm
(Question No. 1925)
Dr Everingham asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 28 Apri11981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to an article entitled The Prevention of Alcoholism: Epidemiological Studies of the Effects of Government Control Measures published in the British Journal of Addiction, 1975 Vol. 70, pages 125-144.
(2) If so, does the article produce a wealth of evidence that restricting sale times and outlets for alcohol is less effective in reducing community intake than cost maintenance through taxation policy.
(3) Does it also confirm that total intake, regardless of source, determines prevalence of alcohol-related illness.
(4) Will the Government undertake public education of these facts and pursue appropriate excise policies, unimpaired by budget-balancing or industry support considerations, as suggested in that article and in my request for submissions from his Department in support of such a policy when I was Minister for Health.
Mr MaeKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) No. It does show that regulation of the accessibility of alcohol is not a major determinant of alcohol consumption. Evidence is produced suggesting that alcohol consumption and the relative price of alcohol (the price of 10 litres of absolute alcohol divided by personal disposable income) vary inversely but this does not prove that price is a major determinant of consumption. The degree of affluence, as reflected in the disposable income, is probably more important.
(3) No. The article contains statistical evidence linking variations in the level of average consumption with variations in the level of occurrence of some chronic alcohol-related problems. These are only associations the meaning of which is uncertain, and no evidence is produced about the associations of variations in the level of average consumption and other alcohol-related problems.
(4) No. The Government's policy on alcohol-related health problems was detailed in the response to the Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare: 'Drug Problems in Australia: an Intoxicated Society?', tabled in the Senate on 19 March 1980 which stated that the Government favoured an overall reduction in alcohol consumption and that the Government would take health considerations into account in a budgetary context when setting tax rates on alcohol.

Warmun Community at Turkey Creek, Western Australia: Water Supply
(Question No. 1988)
Mr Campbell asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 29 Apri11981:
(1) Has his Department received funds from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs for the Warmun Community at Turkey Creek, Western Australia, for the upgrading of the water supply in that community.
(2) If so, what funds were received in each year and for what specific purpose were they received.
(3) Did his Department (a) receive funds to install 2 water bores and (b) arrange for 2 water bores to be drilled and equipped.
(4) Were these water bores drilled and equipped to the satisfaction of his Department.
(5) Are these bores providing an adequate supply of water to the community; if not, why not.
Mr lVIcVeigh-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2) $111,500 in 1979 to drill and equip bores, provide water storage, extend and upgrade water reticulation and construct four ablution/laundry blocks.
(3) (a) Yes. (b) Two bores existed at the site, one of which was equipped with a windmill. Four new holes were drilled, two of which were productive. One new bore has been fitted with a diesel powered pump, a second bore provided with a new windmill and pump, and a diesel engine installed to supplement the previously existing windmill.
(4) Yes.
(5) Yes, provided the bores and pumping equipment are adequately maintained. The Community is responsible for operational maintenance.
Pneumoconiosis Compensation: Taxation
(Question No. 2018)
Mr Campbell asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 30 April 1981:
(1) Does the Government propose to tax money paid in compensation to victims of pneumoconiosis; if so, what estimated sum will it raise.

(2) Has section 23 of the Income Tax Assessment Act been effective since 1973; if so, why has the Government waited until now to enforce it.
(3) Is a massive social injustice being perpetrated by this occurence; if so, will he advise the Commissioner of Taxation not to proceed against this particularly disadvantaged group.
(4) How many persons are subject to paying tax on this compensation and what is their average age.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The Income Tax Assessment Act requires a taxpayer to include in assessable income the gross income derived from all sources in or out of Australia. Because amounts paid by way of compensation to victims of pneumoconiosis are of an income nature they form part of a recipient taxpayer's assessable income. No details are available of the estimated amount oftax involved.
(2) Section 23 of the Income Tax Assessment Act provides for the exemption from income tax of specified classes of income. The section does not operate to exempt from tax amounts paid by way of compensation to victims of pneumoconiosis. The Commissioner of Taxation has, however, advised that in some cases in Western Australia the view was in the past mistakenly taken that these amounts did not constitute assessable income.
(3) Decisions of the courts have confirmed that compensation payments of the type referred to are assessable income. It would be necessary to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to provide that the amounts be exempt from income tax.
(4) Statistics of this kind are not maintained.
Tertiary Education Fees
(Question No. 2030)
Mr Humphreys asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:
(I) Is he able to confirm or deny recent Press rumours that the Government will be reintroducing tertiary education fees, as reported in the Brisbane Courier Mail of25 April 198I.
(2) If fees are to be reintroduced will he give an assurance that tertiary students who have already embarked on an approved post-secondary course and who are receiving Government assistance, will be permitted to complete their course on that basis.
Mr Fife--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The Government, following an examination of this matter by the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions, has confirmed that it has no intention of introducing fees for students undertaking courses leading to a first qualification or for those taking recognised double degree and diploma combinations. From the beginning of the 1982 academic year, tuition fees will be introduced for students enrolling for the first time for second or higher qualifications at universities and colleges of advanced education. Fees will not be charged for students holding Commonwealth Postgraduate Awards or scholarships from universities and colleges of advanced education.
(2) Fees will not apply to students for courses commenced before 1982.

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3473

Reduction of Staff and Functions: Department of Industrial Relations
(Question No. 2129)
Mrs Kelly asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
Will he provide a detailed list of the (a) numbers of staff and (b) functions to be eliminated in all areas of his Department that are located in the Australian Capital Territory, when the recommendations of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions are implemented.
Mr Viner-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The recommendations of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions did not include the elimination of any functions in this Department which are located in the Australian Capital Territory.
Interest Rates
(Question No. 2145)
Mr Hurford asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 May 1981:
(I) Has his attention been drawn to the studies undertaken by Professor J. W. Nevile of the Centre for Applied Economic Research at the University of New South Wales show that a rise of one percentage point in the nominal rate of interest is enough to reduce investment in fixed capital by about $250m, in terms of April 1981 prices.
(2) Is there any substance to Professor Nevile's calculations.
(3) If not, what are the reasons.
(4) Is this apparent lowering of levels of investment due to high interest rates contrary to the medium and long term viability and efficiency of Australian industry.
(5) If so, what steps will he take to ensure not only that high interest rates do not produce further increases in the level of unemployment but also that they do not lead to industry being saddled with outdated and uncompetitive plant and capital.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) to (5) I understand that a paper by Professor Nevile entitled 'Inflation and the Incentive to Invest' refers to the impact that an increase in the nominal interest rate might have on business investment. I also understand, however, that the main point of the paper is to demonstrate the adverse impact that a rise in inflation has on investment, both through its effect on interest rates and through corporate profitability.
It is worth noting that simple regression results, such as those cited by Professor Nevile, do not in fact 'show' anything. They can at best provide only a broad guide to underlying economic relationships and cannot capture all the influences bearing on (in this case) private investment.
It may also be worth noting that if there is one thing that is abundantly clear about the Australian economy today it is that Australia is not suffering from any shortage of new investment at this time. On the contrary, business investment is likely to grow by around 20 per cent in real terms in 1980-81 and recent expectations data from the ABS point to further very strong growth in 1981-82.

Closure of Engineering Courses in Victoria
(Question No. 2150)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 7 May 1981:
(1) Was he and his Department asked to express an opinion on the closure of engineering courses at the Deakin University, Victoria, and at the Bendigo Institute of Technology, Victoria (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1843); if so, what advice was given.
(2) Has he had consultation with the Victorian Minister for Education about these courses.
(3) If so, did the Victorian Minister support the proposals to close these courses and if support was given, what reasons were advanced for this action.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Advice given to me by the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) in its Report for 1983-84 Triennium included concern for the fragmentation of engineering programs in Victoria and the opinion that some rationalisation was required on the grounds of quality. When preparing its advice, the TEC had regard to the recommendations of the Victorian PostSecondary Education Commission's Working Party on Engineering Education, released towards the end of 1980. In this Report doubts were raised 011 the continuation of certain engineering schools including those at Deakin University and Bendigo College of Advanced Education. This advice was made available to the Government before the decisions under question were made.
(2) and (3) I will be meeting next week with all the Education Ministers to discuss the range of Commonwealth decisions on education arising from the Review of Commonwealth Functions and the Guidelines for the Tertiary Education Commission and the Schools Commission.
The Victorian Government authorities will be among the State and Territory bodies consulted by the TEC on the implementation of the Commonwealth's decisions.
Tax Exemptions: Overseas Airlines
(Question No. 2161)
Mr Campbell asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
(I) Is South African Airways the only international airline that currently enjoys general exemption from Commonwealth sales tax, under item 72A in the First Schedule of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act.
(2) If not, what are the wholly-owned national airlines that enjoy exemption under this item.
(3) Could the wholly owned national airline of a Communist State enjoy exemption from Commonwealth sales tax under item 72A.
(4) Do any of Australia's principal trading partners grant immunity from any or all of their taxation laws to foreign government trading concerns.
(5) Does this provision give unfair advantage to certain international airlines; if so, what is the justification for certain airlines which are run as profit-making ventures, to be exempted from sales tax because they are owned by a foreign government.
(6) Will the Government give consideration to tightening up the regulations or the Act to ensure that foreign governments only enjoy exemption from taxation in matters directly affecting their diplomatic representation in this country and excluding their trading ventures.

3474 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) I am advised by the Commissioner of Taxation that the answer is no.
(2) This is not at this stage public knowledge and, in view of the secrecy provisions of the taxation laws, the Commissioner of Taxation is not prepared to supply the information.
(3) Yes, if on the facts of a particular case the doctrine of sovereign immunity applies.
(4) Recognition of the doctrine of sovereign immunity is not confined to Australia, but no information is available regarding its application by other countries.
(5) The extent of any sales tax advantage would depend on the kind and quantity of purchases of goods made in Australia and may, in practice, be of a relatively minor nature. The justification for any tax exemption is, of course, Australia's acceptance of the doctrine that one government should not seek to tax another. It is to be noted that the doctrine applies only to an arm of government; it does not apply in respect of corporations or other organisations owned by a government.
(6) It is the Government's practice to keep under review aspects of the tax laws on which it receives representations.
Participation in Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting: Department of Education
(Question No. 2175)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 7 May 1981:
(1) How many (a) 2nd Division, (b) 3rd Division and (c) 4th Division officers in his Department are engaged (i) full time or (ii) part-time in administrative, policy or other preparations for the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne.
(2) How many officers of his Department are expected to attend the meeting:
(3) What is the expected cost of their attendance at the meeting, including salaries, overtime, accommodation, travel and other expenses.
(4) What other expenses does he expect his Department to incur as a result of Australia's participation in, and conduct of, the meeting.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) One Third Division officer has been seconded on a full time basis to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, at the request of that Department to assist with administrative arrangements. A further request has been received to provide delegation liaison officers, which is being considered.
(2) At this stage it is not known whether any officers of my Department will be required to attend the Meeting.
(3) See answer to (2).
(4) Nil.
Rules of Broadcasting
(Question No. 2252)
Dr Klugman asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to the comment 'better luck next time' allegedly made by a radio 3CR announcer when referring to the attempted assassination of President Reagan on the day of the incident.

(2) If so, does this comment contravene any rules laid down by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.
Mr Sinclair-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes. (2) The Tribunal has advised me that following its examination of an audio recording of the program item in question, the Tribunal advised the management of station 3CR that it considered the matter to be in breach of the Broadcasting Program Standards and that it would be further considered at the forthcoming public inquiry into the renewal of the licence of the station commencing on 10 June 1981.

Invalid Pension Appeals
(Question No. 2306)
Dr Jenkins asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:
(1) How many appeals were pending concerning the refusal of invalid pension benefits under the guidelines for eligibility existing before 4 May 1981.
(2) What period of time will be taken in reviewing these appeals under the new guidelines for eligibility announced on 4 May 1981.
Mr Hunt--The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) Statistics are not maintained for appeals pending concerning refusal of invalid pension. Statistics are, however, collected for the number of medical appeals undetermined. This category includes decisions affecting not only invalid pensions but also other decisions involving medical assessment-for example, decisions relating to sickness benefit and handicapped child's allowance. Further, the category covers decisions involving not only a refusal to grant a pension, benefit or allowance, but also a decision to cancel or suspend the payment of such after grant. The latest available figures show that there were 2492 medical appeals undetermined at 31 March 1981.
(2) It is not possible to indicate the time which will be taken to review appeals against refusal of invalid pension pending at 4 May 1981. All such appeals will however, be handled as expeditiously as possible.
Commonwealth Games Foundation: Income Tax Deductions for Donations
(Question No. 2335)
Mr Humphreys asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 May 1981:
(1) Is it a fact that the Income Tax Assessment Act presently makes no allowance for authorisation of income tax deduction for gifts to the Commonwealth Games Foundation.
(2) Will he take steps to have section 78 of the Income Tax Assessmcnt Act amended in order to add the Commonwealth Games Foundation to the list of organisations in regard to which gifts of $2 and upward may be treated as tax deductible; if not, what is the reason.
Mr HowardThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2) The matter of allowing tax deductions for gifts to the Foundation was examined some time ago and subsequently reviewed. Against the background that gifts to assist the financing of international sporting or athletic events have never been allowed, the Government decided that gifts to the Foundation should not be tax deductible. I do note, however,

that the Commonwealth is making a substantial contribution towards the Games in a number of ways, including a grant of $IOm towards the cost of capital facilities; up to $11.5m to enable the ABC to act as host broadcaster; $2m in administrative and other support; and the issue of commemorative coinage, which is expected to yield the Foundation up to $1.5m.
Micro-electronics Industry
(Question No. 419)
Mr Humphreys asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:
(I) Did he say in a speech delivered at the first International Conference on Technology for Development on 24 November 1980 that the CSIRO will provide a major impetus to Australia's micro-electronic industry.
(2) Is it a fact that the 1980-81 budget allocation to the CSIRO for the purpose of design of very large scale integration of the next generation of computer chip technology was $1.5 million.
(3) Is he able to state whether comparable expenditure in the micro-electronic industry in (a) Great Britain is $400m, (b) France is $270m, (e) Italy is $130m and (d) West Germany is $IOOm.
(4) Has his attention been drawn to the statement of Dr MacDonald of the Univcrsity of Queensland in Search, Vol. 11, No. II, November 1980, to the effect that the allocation to the CSIRO is a waste of effort given comparable expenditure in other countries and given also the isolation of this research effort from mainline computer research being carried out overseas.
(5) If so, and the position is as stated in parts (2) and (3), will he explain the relevance of his remarks referred to in part (I).
Mr Thomson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes. In formally opening the 1st International Conference on Technology for Development I referred to my announcement that CSIRO would set up a research group to design very large scale integrated circuits (VLSI). Staff are now being recruited. I reiterate my view that this initiative will provide a major impetus to microelectronic technology in Australia. It will develop an indigenous design capability in Australia, and raise awareness of the enormous potential of custom chips in the late 1980s.
(2) No, it is not a fact. The CSIRO Executive has allocated $500,000 from the Organisation's 1980-81 Appropriation. The project will be financed at the level of $500,000 per annum for the next two years in the first instance. The amount envisaged is $1.5m in to to over 3 financial years.
(3) The comparison drawn between the expenditure of Great Britain, France, Italy and West Germany, and Australia is not valid. The European expenditure supports experimental and theoretical work concerning all aspects of the production of microelectronic circuits, including manufacture at the pilot plant scale. The CSIRO initiative will focus exclusively on the problems of chip design. CSIRO believes that an effort on this scale will be fruitful. In this matter they are not alone.
(4) Yes. I do not accept, however, the conclusions reached in this article. It is based on assumptions specific to the American situation.
(5) The facts as stated in 2, 3 and 4 above vindicate my confidence in the project. It is of considerable importance. CITA

3476 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

has identified microelectronics as a key area of modern manufacturing technology. The CSIRO initiative will give Australian industry access to an important sector of microelectronic technology.
Radio and Television Time Allotted to Political Parties
(Question No. 1042)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 2 April 1981:
(1) How much time was allocated to the (a) Liberal and National Parties and (b) Australian Labor Party during the period 20 October 1980 to 26 November 1980 inclusive, on the following Australian Broadcasting Commission programs (i) AM, (ii) PM, (iii) the 7 p.m. news in Queensland and (iv) Nationwide in Queensland.
Mr Sinclair-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(a) (i) 26 minutes 14 seconds; (ii) 53 minutes 11 seconds; (iii) 60 minutes 10 seconds; (iv) Il4minutes 11 seconds.
(b) (i) 7 minutes 13 seconds; (ii)22 minutes 21 seconds; (iii) 39 minutes 38 seconds; (iv) l!O minutes 3 seconds.
AM and PM are national public affairs programs and in the period immediately following a Federal Election devoted more time to Government activities, such as the appointment of Federal Ministers, than those of the Opposition. Similarly, items of national interest were included in the main television news bulletins.
Communications in North-western Australia
(QnestionNo.1155)
Mr Campbell asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:
(1) By what date will the microwave link in the Kimberley region, Western Australia, be operational.
(2) Is this microwave link dependent upon a single land line connection with Perth.
(3) Is it a fact that even with the installation of the microwave link, the communication system to and within the Kimberleys will remain fragile, vulnerable and antiquated.
(4) Will he encourage Telecom Australia to consider immediately the installation of a micowave link to Katherine from Kununurra, WA., in order to provide north-west Australia with an alternative communication link to that provided by the north-south microwave link.
Mr Sinclair-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) A microwave link between Port Hedland-BroomeDerby is under construction and is planned to be completed by the end of 1982. An extension of this link connecting Derby-Halls Creek-Kununurra is planned to be completed by the end of 1983.
(2) The microwave links between Port Hedland-Derby and Derby-Kununurra will connect at Port Hedland to the main co-axial cable system between that town and Perth.
(3) The microwave links will be modern and highly dependable. They will employ the latest radio relay equipment duplicated throughout for reliability and powered by solar cells giving independence from ground transported fuel supplies. The antennae and masts will be designed to withstand the cyclonic conditions that occur in the area. The reliability of communications in the Kimberley region will be further enhanced by a microwave link between Perth and Dampier planned for completion in July 1984.

(4) The overall advantage in providing a microwave link between Kununurra and Katherine is well recognised. However, the provision of such a project by Telecom depends on competing priorities for telecommunications services generally in Australia.

Telegrams
(Question No. 1633)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 9 April 1981 :
Is it the practice of the Australian Telecommunications Commission to ascertain the telephone numbers of addressees of telegrams and to telephone telegrams through, even though a delivery fee has been paid; if so, what is the purpose of charging the delivery fee.
Mr Sinclail'-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The telegram service offers a personalised message passing service and the fixed component of the telegram charge varies according to the sender's choice of method to be used in passing the message.
It is the practice in cases where the sender simply addresses a telegram to a residential or business address and pays the full charge rate for Telecom to deliver the message by the fastest means available. Quite often this is by telephone or telex. In these cases, the fee charged is not, therefore, for the physical delivery of the telegram but for transmission of the message by the fastest means possible. Should the addressee require a copy of the message which has been telephoned, it can be provided at no additional charge.
Where messenger service would provide the fastest means of delivery or if Telecom judges the messenger delivery would be more appropriate, say for telegrams concerning death, illness, or the like, then this means of delivery is used.
The sender, at the time oflodging a telegram, has the option of specifying messenger delivery by including the paid service indicator 'Messenger' before the address, and in such cases physical delivery of the message will be undertaken. However, in these circumstances it may not be practicable to pass the message to the addressee as quickly as when alternative methods such as telephone and telex are used.
Sale of Postage Stamps
(Question No. 1637)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
Does the Australian Postal Commission receive commission or some other payment for selling stamps of Fiji, Christmas Island, Norfolk Island, et cetera; if so, what sum was received from each country or territory in 1979-80.

Mr Sinclair-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Australia Post acts as sales agent, in Australia only, for the stamps, postal stationery and philatelic products of the following overseas postal administrations:
Christmas Island, Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Fiji, Nauru,NorfolkIsland, Papua New Guinea, Pitcairn Islands and Western Samoa.
The commission received from this. agency work by Australia Post totalled $1,034,075 in 1979-80. Australia Post does not record the commission on stamps, postal stationery and philatelic items separately.
Details concerning the amount received from each administration arc regarded as 'Commercial,in-Confidence'.
Telephone Calls by Staff: Department of Communications
(Question No. 1870)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 9 April 1981 :
(1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the West Australian of 18 July 1979, page 37, that London metropolitan police reduced its telephone bill by $985,000 or about 20 per cent by use of a monitoring device which recorded length, time and destination oftelephone calls and the extension from which the call was made.
(2) Are personal telephone calls, particularly trunk and STD calls,made by staff of his Department controlled; if so, in what way.
(3) Has any consideration been given to the introduction of monitoring devices for telephone calls in his Department; if so, what was the outcome of the consideration.
Mr Sinclair-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) My attention has been drawn to the article.
(2) Supervisors in my Department are responsible for the control of personal calls originated by staff in their area. In line with Directive 591 of 1976, STD barring has been introduced selectively in those Departmental offices where the switchboard equipment makes it possible. In addition, individual metering is in use in one location. Further STD barring will be considered whenever changes to switchboard equipment makes it practicable.
(3) My Department is currently housed in some 30 different locations throughout Australia, and to maintain effective communication, a high volume of official calls is unavoidable. The use of monitoring devices has been considered but given the high volume of authorised calls, the work involved in checking the machines' output for unauthorised calls would be so high as to make it uneconomical.
Participation in Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting: Department of Communications
(Question No. 2165)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 7 May 1981 :
(1) How many (a) 2nd Division (b) 3rd Division and (c) 4th Division officers in his Department are engaged (i) full time or (ii) part-time in administrative, policy or other preparations for the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne.

(2) How many officers of his Department are expected to attend the meeting.
(3) What is the expected cost of their attendance at the meeting, including salaries, overtime, accommodation, travel and other expenses.

Transmitter Power of Radio Station 2KA

(Question No. 2256)

Mr Uren asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:

(1) What ter location

is the current (a) transmitter power (b) and (c) coverage area of radio stations

tr0a)ns2mKiAt-

(ii) 2WS and (iii) 2UE.

(2) Have any proposals which would alter the coverage area of 2KA been put before his Department or been the subject of discussions between his Department and Broadcast Investments Pty Ltd.

(3) If so, what action does he propose to take concerning the proposals.

(4) Have recommendations been made by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal concerning the coverage areas of 2KA and 2WS; if so, what were they.

Mr Sinclair-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(l) 2KA Katoomba (main station) is located at Wentworth Falls, operates with a power of 2000 watts and serves the area approximately within a 12km radius of the transmitting antenna. 2KA Penrith (translator station) is located at Emu Plains, operates with a power of 500 watts and serves the area approximately within a 10km radius of the transmitting antenna.

2WS Blacktown is located at Prospect, operates with a power of 5000 watts and serves the area approximately within a 30km radius of the transmitting antenna.

2UE Sydney is located at Homebush Bay, operates with a power of 5000 watts and serves the area approximately within a 40km radius of the transmitting antenna.

(2) and (3) Discussions regarding 2KA's coverage area between representatives of the licensee company and my Department have taken place.

On 27 April 1981, having considered representations from the Company, I signed a direction to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, under section 84 (4) of the Broadcasting and Television Act, to amend the operating conditions of the 2KA translator from 250 watts to 500 watts.

The amended operating conditions will restore the service to an acceptable level. The service had been degraded by an

increase in night-time and man-made interference levels in the area.
(4) The Tribunal has not made any recommendations to the Department of Communications regarding the coverage areas of commercial broadcasting stations 2KA and 2WS.
Anabolic Agents
(Question No. 336)
Mr Kerin asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:
(I) Is the National Health and Medical Research Council examining the use of anabolic agents as growth promotants at the initiative of the Standing Committee on Agriculture.-
(2) Can he say whether representatives of the drug industry are pressing for the introduction of these agents.
(3) Is he able to say whether the use of such agents is virtually out of control in (a) North America and (b) the European Economic Community.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) It is presumed that the honourable member is referring in his question to the anabolic effects of oestrogenic substances. The Australian Agricultural Council has requested the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH & MRC) to reconsider its long standing recommendation against the use of oestrogens as growth promotants in meal production. The matter is being considered by the Public Health Advisory Committee of the NH & MRe.
(2) Representatives of the industry concerned with drug applications in animal husbandry are interested in the introduction of these agents but it is not correct to say that they are 'pressing' for introduction. Any submissions received from industry concerning such products will be subject to the usual rigorous scrutiny by the appropriate bodies.
(3) I am aware of recent press reports in relation to the use of oestrogens as growth promotants in the EEC but I am not aware of any substantial scientific reports indicating that anabolic agents in general are 'out of control' in either North America or the EEe.

Avalon Airfield, Victoria: Lease Renewals
(Question No. 797)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:
Was the value of buildings constructed by the private lessee of grazing rights at Avalon Airfield, Victoria, taken into account when determining the allocation of lease renewals.
Mr Newman-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Yes. A house only was involved.

Trade Practices Act: Merger Provisions
(Question No. 857)
Mr Jacobi asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 24 March 1981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to recent criticisms of the merger provisions of the Trade Practices Act emanating both from the Victorian inquiry into the newspaper industry and from a number of academic writers in the field of antimonopoly law;
(2) Is there any basis to the thrust of these criticisms that section 50 of the Trade Practices Act as it is structured is almost totally ineffective;

3480 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

(3) Will he lake steps to ensure that the current dominance and control test is replaced by a provision, or a number of provisions, that effectively prevent mergers in substantial markets which have the effect of substantially lessening competition;
(4) Will he confirm the thrust of statements attributed to him upon his appointment that he favoured the curbing of monopoly power both through the Trade Practices Act and more direct forms of anti-monopoly regulation,
Mr Moore-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) I am aware of some criticism made by Mr Ranald Macdonald of The Age newspaper;
(2) I understand that in making his criticism, Mr Macdonald was referring to the proposed takeover in 1979 of the Herald and Weekly Times Limited Group by the News Limited Group. In that case the Trade Practices Commission stated its intention to take proceedings for a contravention of section 50 of the Trade Practices Act to prohibit the takeover, but News Limited withdrew its offer before that action was taken;
(3) The present section 50 of the Trade Practices Act is the result of a considered decision taken by the Government when it implemented a substantial revision of the Trade Practices Act 1977. The Government has not since then changed its policy in relation to section 50. The Government is, of course, continuing to monitor all provisions of the Trade Practices Act;
(4) I believe, and it is the Government's policy, that the Government has a clear role to play in promoting and maintaining free and fair competition throughout the Australian economy and in preventing the abuse of monopoly power.
Family Health Plan
(Question No. 924)
Dr Blewett asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:
(I) Is it a fact that financial members of the Family Health Plan are regarded as uninsured because this service is not a registered health insurance organisation.
(2) If so, does this enable doctors providing medical services for the plan to classify patients as disadvantaged and bulk bill for their medical services, despite plan membership costing $450 per annum.
(3) If the position is as stated, does this enable the plan to sell medical cover which appears to be paid for by the plan but which is in fact paid for by the Commonwealth.
(4) Is he able to say whether any of the doctors providing medical services under the plan have any financial interest in the service.
Mr MacKellar--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2) Yes, however the Family Health Plan has advised that persons classified as disadvantaged do not contribute financially to the Plan.
(3) See (2) above. Under the new arrangements to operate from 1 September 1981, the Commonwealth is to determine eligibility for disadvantaged status. Those who qualify will he made aware of their entitlements and adequate publicity will be given to the fact that they do not have to contribute to any organisation to obtain them.

(4) No. However it is known that Dr Geoffrey Edelsten is a Director of the Geoffrey Edelsten Foundation Limited, which operates the-Family Health Plan.

I refer the honourable member to the answer given by the Treasurer to Question No. 1101 on 13 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2374).
Air Travel: Department of National Development and Energy
(Question No. 1130)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:
(l) How many travel warrants have been issued for Department of National Development and Energy officers' air travel to and from Canberra during (a) 1976-77, (b) 1977-78, (c) 1978-79, (d) 1979-80 and (e) 1980 to 31 March 1981.
(2) What was the total cost of this travel.
Mr Anthony---The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) (a) Not applicable. DepartmeI\t of National Development created on 20 December 1977; (b) For the period 20 December 1977 to 30 June 1978: 641; (c) 1560; (d) 1770; (e) 1235.
(2) The cost of all travel in Australia over these periods was $967,816. The component relating to air travel to and from Canberra is not readily available from Departmental records and I am not prepared to authorise the use of resources to identify the particular information requested.
Depo-Provera
(Question No. 1202)
Dr Everingham asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:
(1) Can h,e state whether the substance Depo-Provera is recommended by any (a) professional, (b) academic or (c) government authority in Australia for contraceptive use.
(2) If so, (a) what qualifications are placed on its use, (b) are any contra-indicatiollS or recommended precautions especially applicable for patients who have difficulty in making an informed judgment for or against this use of the drug and (c) do any of these authorities recommend its use particularly for women who have difficulty in comprehending proper methods ofuse ofalternative contraception.

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3481

(3) Will the Government take steps to ensure that (a) due precautions are not relaxed and (b) proper alternative contraception is available and adequately explained in particular to (i) the mentally retarded and (ii) Aborigines with limited understanding of contraceptives and of the English language and 'a high incidence of diabetes; if so, what steps will be taken.
(4) Will he seek the advice of the National Health and Medical Research Council on recommendations to the States for notification or other recording of contraceptive uses of Depo-Provera for statistical analysis of (a) safety, (b) sideeffects and (c) reliability.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) No. However I understand Depo-Provera is used by Family Planning Associations, health authorities and private doctors in individual cases where a specific need exists for which no other contraceptive method is considered suitable.
(2) Those organisations which have approached my Department on the use of Depo-Provera as a contraceptive have been advised that the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC) has considered progressively available information on Depo-Provera for contraceptive use on a number of occasions. The Committee is of the opinion that the use of the drug as a contraceptive must be regarded as investigational since there are unresolved questions related to its safety. This statement appears in the product information distributed by the company for this drug.
These organisations have also been advised that the ADEC supports the concept of properly controlled clinical trials provided they are designed to help resolve some of the questions raised and provided adequate measures are incorporated in the trial protocol satisfactorily to protect the participants. To date no applications have been made to my Department in this regard.
(3) (a) The Government is not in a position where it can take steps to ensure that due precautions are not relaxed in the situation where a drug is already available and relatively safe and effective for other accepted indications. It is a recognised fact that a doctor may occasionally decide that special circumstances warrant the use of a drug for conditions other than those for which it has been approved. In such circumstances the responsibility for adequately informing the patient or the guardian and for any adverse consequences of the therapy must rest with the practitioner concerned.
(b) Alternative forms of contraception are readily available and the product information relating to these is adequate to enable the medical practitioner to explain the position to his patient. It is a matter for the practitioner to determine what he considers to be the most appropriate method of contraception to suit the particular circumstances of his patients.
(4) Yes. However, it is for the reasons suggested by the honourable member that my Department has encouraged organisations to design properly controlled trials using DepoProvera as a contraceptive.
