Tea Services: Department ofAdministrative
Services
(Question No. 1615)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(1) How many (a) full-time and (b) part-time stall are employed on tea-making and distribution in (i) the Head Office and (ii) other offices of his Department.
(2) What was the cost of (a) salaries and (b)-other charges in the provision oftea services in his Department'in 1979-80.
Mr Newman-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
.(1) (a) (i) 4, (ii) nil, (b) (i) 2, (ii) 3.
(2) (a) $53,281.62; (b) $37,380.00 paid to Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services Ltd.
I am advised that the answers to parts 1 and 2 (a) of the question deal with the provision of beverage services in buildings occupied by my Department and where the services are the direct respOnsibility of my Department. The answer to 2 (b) of the question deals with the-provision of beverage services in buildings occupied by my Department where the services are provided by Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services Ltd.
I am also advised that there is a third category: in some buildings (such as the Commonwealth Centre in Perth) occupied by several departments where the beverage services are provided by Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services Ltd, for reasons of administrative convenience the costs of the services are met by my Department. In 1979-80 they amounted to $593,840.
The answers to other questions asked by the honourable member on this matter need to be read in the light of this information.

Quarantine Procedures and Requirements
(Question No. 1713)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Health. upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(1) Can he say whether Philip the Chimpanzee performed at the Happy Holidays show at the Perth Entertainment Centre eady in January 1981.
(2) If so, did Philip arrive by air from San Francisco, USA., immediately before the show.
(3) What quarantine procedures and requirements operated in respect of Philip to ensure that there was no risk to Australian human and animal health.

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3483

(4) Were normal quarantine procedures or requirements cornpromised or abbreviated in any way in this case; if so, in what ways.
.Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(l) Philip the Chimpanzee performed at Perth Entertainment Centre from 5 January to 17 January 1981.
(2) This animal and two other chimpanzees arrived in Perth from San Francisco on 3 January 1981 and left Australia on 21 January 1981.
(3) The Perth Entertainment Centre was registered as a 'B' Class circus under quarantine legislation for the duration of the animals' stay. The animals were subject to the usual preimport conditions with regard to yellow fever and rabies, namely, certification that they had not been in a yellow fever country for the three months preceding export to Australia and had been on rabies-free premises for 12 months. The animals were examined by a United States Government veterinarian with regard to their general health status and tuberculosis. The chimpanzees were accompanied to and from the Perth Airport by a veterinary officer. A veterinary officer previously inspected and approved accommodation at the Entertainment Centre for suitability and security for the purposes of registration as a 'B' Class circus. The chimpanzees remained in their quarters throughout the visit except for stage appearances. Only the trainer had access to these quarters.
(4) No.
Telephone Calls by Staff: Department of Education
(Question No. 1883)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the West Australian of 18 July 1979, page 37 that l,ondon metropolitan police reduced its telephone bill by $985,000, or about 20 per cent by use of a monitoring device which recorded length, time and destination of telephone calls and the extension from which the call was made.
(2) Are personal telephone calls, particularly trunk and STD calls, made by staff of his Department controlled; if so, in what way.
(3) Has any consideration been given to the introduction of monitoring devices for telephone calls in his Department; if so, what was the outcome of the consideration.
Mr Fife---The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) Personal telephone calls are not controlled, however STD barring has been introduced wherever possible, except in Central Office where Telecom advice was that STD barring was not technically practicable at present.
(3) Staff are informed by Departmental Circular of their responsibility in the efficient use of telephones, particularly the use of facilities for non-official purposes.
Teaching of Languages Other Than English
(Question No. 2013)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 30 April 1981 :

(1) In how many (a) private, (b) State and (c) Commonwealth schools and/or other educational institutions are languages other than English taught,
(2) What is the number of students in each of these courses in each State or Territory.
(3) What is the number of teachers in each of these courses in each State and Territory teaching (a) part-time and (b) full-time courses.
(4) What special qualifications do these teachers have.
(5) What is the (a) basic material provided or (b) source of the teaching materials used in each of these courses.
(6) What sum was allocated in each State by the (a) State and (b) Commonwealth Departments of Education for these courses in each year since 1976.
(7) How many teachers are employed by the (a) private schools and by the (b) State and (c) Commonwealth Departments of Education.
(8) Are the classes held during or after normal school hours.
(9) Is there any choice for after-school classes in (a) State and (b) Commonwealth schools.
Mr Fife -The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) to (3) and (7) Courses in languages other than English are offered at primary and secondary levels in Government, Catholic and independent schools, by part-time and full-time ethnic schools, and by tertiary institutions including the TAFE sector, In addition. some courses arc oiTered by professional associations and by organisations in the private sector. Neither total numbers of students and teachers nor the number of schools and institutions oifering courses are known. My Department is at present coHating information currently available.
(4) It is generally the case that secondary schoolteachers of languages other than English have tertiary qualifications and some professional training in language teaching techniques. This, however, is less likely to be so in primary schools, where classes may be taught by teachers who speak a language other than English but without specialist qualifications. Some programs involve participation of members of ethnic communities. In a few cases teachers and/or other assistance are being provided by foreign governments.
(5) The provision of teaching materials for languages other than English is the responsibility of the authority concerned. However the Schools Commission through its Multicultural Education Program has provided funds for the development and production of language teaching materials. Languages for which materials are currently being produced include Italian, Greek and Dutch. Curriculum and material projects have been undertaken by schools and in some States by community groups. The Curriculum Development Centre has also supported the development of materials for community language teaching, and is involved in the Schools Commission Greek and Italian Curriculum Projects.
(6) Since 1978 the Government in accordance with recommendation 45 of the Galbally review has made additional funds available to the States for multicultural education including the teaching of community languages. The total allocation of $5m has been disbursed over a period of three years by the Schools Commission on the advice of State coordinating committees. In 1979 the total allocation for that year of $0.5m was directed to supporting the teaching of community languages. In 1980 and 1981 $1.5m and $3m respectively were made available for the further development of community languages for other aspects of multicultural education. General purpose recurrent grants from Commonwealth to State or non-Government schools can be used for

3484 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

foreign language teaching at the discretion of the authorities concerned.
The allocation of State funds to particular areas of education is a matter for the education authorities in each State.
The overall State allocations for the Multicultural Education Program for 1979 and 1980 were as follows:

(4) Will the Attorney-General take steps to ensure that these excessive costs for litigants are removed; if so, what steps.
Mr Viner-The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

(8) and (9) Courses provided by the education authorities are in general held during school hours as part of the normal school curriculum. Ethnic school classes are mostly conducted outside normal school hours, although some are 'inserted' into normal school programs. At the present time it is estimated that there are between 1,200 and 1,300 ethnic schools in Australia. This figure does not include an estimated 600 'insertion' classes involving about 6,000 children.
The Government supports the teaching oflanguages in ethnic schools, and is providing $30 per capita grants to part-time non-profit-making ethnic schools with an open admissions policy. A survey is to be conducted to determine appropriate support for ethnic schools after an initial two-year funding period.

Costs of Litigation
(Question No. 2041)
Mr Leo McLeay asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:
(1) Can the Attorney-General say whether it is a fact that the Registry of the Supreme Court of New South Wales will only accept Appeal documents typed on foolscap size paper.
(2) Can the Attorney-General say whether it is also a fact that the Registry of the High Court of Australia will only accept Appeal documents typed on A4 size paper.
(3) Is the Attorney-General able to say what is the average cost for re-typing an appeal book relating to an Appeal from the Supreme Court of New South Wales to the High Court of Australia.

(I) I understand that documents prepared for use in the Supreme Court of New South Wales are, as a general rule, required to be on foolscap size paper.
(2) Documents prepared for use in the High Court of Australia are, as a general rule, required to be on A4 size paper. However, I am advised that it is the practice in appeals to the High Court from the Court of Appeal of the Supreme Court of New South Wales to allow the reproduction of the Court of Appeal appeal book if special representations are made by the parties on the grounds of cost. In other cases parties have photo-reduced the Court of Appeal appeal book, but I am advised that photo-reduction is unsatisfactory in most cases and that the High Court does not encourage it.
(3) No. The cost would vary according to the size of the appeal book.
(4) The size of documents used in proceedings in the High Court of Australia and the Supreme Court of New South Wales is a matter of pactice and procedure within the responsibilities of those Courts. I am advised that there have been discussions between the two Courts on this matter, but that the problems have not yet been resolved. I hope that it will be possible for these problems to be overcome by agreement between the Courts so that the costs of litigation can be kept as low as possihle.

Northern Territory Disabled Persons: Health Projects
(Question No. 2053)
Mr Tambling asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
(1) What financial appropriations have been allocated by his Department for use in the Northern Territory for projects to assist the disabled during 1980-81.
(2) For what specific projects has this sum been allocated.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) and (2) For 1980-81, $700,000 has been appropriated for a proposed new program to provide certain categories of aids to disabled people throughout Australia, including the Northern Territory. It is hoped that the program will commence in the Northern Territory in the near future.
In addition the Government extended the medical benefits scheme from 1 January 1981 to cover orthodontic and related treatment for cleft lip and palate patients aged less than 22 years. This initiative is expected to cost the Government $1 m in 1980-81 for the whole of Australia. A specific figure for the Northern Territory is not available as this assistance is made available to patients by way of medical benefits.
Commonwealth Parliament Offices: Payment of Staff
(Question No. 2261)
Mr Humphreys asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:
Does the proposed elimination of the cash mode of salary payment as recommended in the Review of Commonwealth Functions (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1844) apply to staff in Commonwealth Parliament Offices.
Mr Howard-The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
The Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Bill 1981 contains an amendment to the Audit Act 1901 to provide that any payments of remuneration or allowances to Commonwealth employees shall not be made in cash, unless the Minister for Finance otherwise determines.
The staff in Commonwealth Parliament Offices come within the definition of 'Commonwealth employee' for the purposes of the Bill.
It is expected that a few exemptions will be granted mainly in respect of industrial type payrolls. Many other forms of salary payment are now available including cheque, pay to cheque account, savings bank, approved credit unions and approved building societies. The proposed elimination of cash pays should thus not present great difficulties; it will, however,

remove an element of risk to life and property which is present in the cash distribution system.

Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation

(Question No. 2429)

Dr Klugman asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:

(I) What was the cost of (a) producing and (b) distributing the 7th Annual Report of the Albury-Wodonga Development
Corporation for 1979-80.

Mr Anthony-The Minister for National Development and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

(I) (a) The cost of producing the 7th Annual Report of the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation for 1979-80 was $6,783, including $5,490 pre-printing costs, some 90 per cent of which was expended to produce common base material
used for the production of Annual Reports of the Albury Wodonga (New South Wales) Corporation and the Albury Wodonga (Victoria) Corporation as well as the Albury-
Wodonga Development Corporation.

(b) Distribution is not complete. However total costs will

be less than $100.

.

(2) The cost of maintaining the public affairs unit of the Corporation in each of the last five years is as follows:

1975-76-$99,447, 1976-77-$135,946, 1977-78$100,914, 1978-79-$108,569, 1979-80-$1I 5,580.

(3) Yes.

(4) The statement on page 7 refers to the annual popu-
lation growth over the period 1971-79 in the Albury-Wodonga
urban area. The figures on page 6 refer to the growth in the Albury-Wodonga Statistical District which includes the Albury-Wodonga urban area as well as the outlying areas.

Migrant and Refugee Education
(Question No. 395)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:
(1) How many adult migrant and refugee education teachers are employed in each State on an (a) permanent, (b) temporary, (c) casual and (d) hourly basis.

3486 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

, (2) How many persons in each State are estimated to be in need of English classes,
(3) How many English classes arc (a) conducted or (b) financed in each State under the Adult Migrant and Refugee Education program.
(4) How many students are taking part in the Adult Migrant and Refugee Education program in each State.
(5) How many of the students referred to in part (4) were admitted to Australia as (a) immigrants and (b) refugees.
(6) What provisions (a) are or (b) were there toincrease staff and funding in this area with more than 100,000 immigrants coming to this country.
(7) What is the standard material used by the students and teachers in the courses for Adult Migran ts and Refugees.
(8) Can he say what new curriculum and/or materials are (a) used, (b) being prepared or (c) in the process of being prepared by his Department and/or the Department of Education.
(9) How many persons are employed on curriculum development referred to in part (8).
(10) How many of the persons employed on curriculum development (a) speak fluently a language other than English, (b) have formal qualifications in linguistics or (c) have special expertise or traioing in the preparation of curriculum materials.
(11) How many of the teachers employed on the Adult Migrant and Refugee Education Program (a) speak fluently a language other than English, (b) have formal qualifications in this specific area, or (c) have special expertise or training in teaching Adult Migrants and Refugees.
(12) Are there any plans to broaden or change the Adult Migrant and Refugee Education Program.
(13) What mechanisms of consultation with the State Ministers and/or Departments of Education regarding the Adult Migrant and Refugee Education Program are there.
(14) Is ultimate responsibility for the program and the employment of teachers vested in the (a) State Department of Education, (b) Federal Department of Education, (c) Schools Commission or (d) his Department.
(15) How many officers are employed on the administrative side of (a) the Adult Migrant and Refugee Education Program, (b) curriculum development, (c) State administration and (d) any other area.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Some 2000 teachers are employed in the Adult Migrant Education Program throughout Australia. The bulk of these are employed on an hourly paid basis. The position regarding permanent teachers varies according to the appropriate mix of full-time and part-time staff needed to facilitate a positive and substantial benefit to stablility, quality and effectiveness of program services. Victoria, Western Australia and Tasmania have no permanent teachers employed in the program. New South Wales has some 123 permanent teacher positions, Queensland 6, South Australia 9 and the Northern Territory 6. Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia employ some full-time temporary teachers and in New South Wales a number of hourly paid staff work on a full-time basis. As staffing arrangements are the responsibility of the States, my Department does not keep detailed statistics of the number of teachers in the categories listed.
(2) There is no direct information available on the number of persons in each State in need of English classes. The Galbally Report estimated from a broad appraisal of 1976 Census data that in May 1978 there were some 400,000 adults in Australia whose fluency in English was 'low'. Currently, there

are research projects underway to implement Galbally Recommendation 10 aimed at obtaining information on the English language and related needs of migrants in Australia. Further data will become available from the 1981 Census.
(3) and (4) The Commonwealth provides the funds for the Adult Migrant Education Program in each State (some minor rental charges for the use of schools and halls are not met by the Commonwealth). There is a range of courses provided under the Adult Migrant Education Program which includes initial settlement courses and, as part of the on-going program; day and evening classes, full-time and part-time courses, correspondence tuition, courses at the workplace, specific purpose English courses to meet employment needs and English by television. In addition a voluntary Home Tutor Scheme helps men and women who are unable to take advantage ofother learning opportunities.
It is estimated that in 1980-81 some 750 on-arrival courses will be held encompassing some 15,000 students. It is expected that within the on-going program there will be about 105,000 enrolments in 1980-81.
(5) Migrants and refugees are not separately identified in Adult Migrant Education Program statistics.
(6) Funding for the Adult Migrant Education Program nationally has increased substantially in recent years as shown by the following figures:
1976-77-$8.8m; 1977-78-$I2.4m; 1978-79-$17.9m; 1979-80-$23.3m; 1980-81-$28.9m (appropriation).
Ninety-five per cent of the budget for the Adult Migrant Education Program (excluding living allowances) is for salary and salary-related costs of persons employed by States and non-Government bodies conducting services within the program.
(7) and (8) A detailed syllabus has been developed for the on-arrival program and supplied to teachers working in that program. This work has been well received in Australia and commended by international experts.
Pilot materials based on that syllabus have been prepared including slides, cassettes, charts and language skill practice materials, with a view to national production of the materials. The idea has met with limited success and some further development is necessary before national production is possible. The development of further national course material for student and teacher use is at present under consideration.
The State Adult Migrant Education Centres develop and use a range of materials with the benefit of audio visual equipment provided for the program. Particular attention is being given to the development of individualised materials for use by students according to what they see as their own needs.
A course syllabus and accompanying materials have been prepared for use in the courses-in-industry program. A course syllabus and accompanying materials have been developed for the programs run for particular occupational groups, e.g. nurses and motor mechanics and for professionally qualified people.
The trialling of the ASLPR (a uniquely Australian language proficiency rating scale) has been concluded and techniques have been developed for establishing proficiency levels according to the scale (through the observace of actual language behaviour within given situations and settings). The ASLPR is being increasingly used at all levels of the program. It assists classroom teachers to determine the capabilities-- and therefore the course requirements for individual students-as well as providing an instrument for broader needs assessment and course planning and development at the State and national levels.

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3487

(9) Curriculum development is undertaken by working parties, the membership of which includes staff of the State Adult Migrant Education Services and outside consultants, or by contracted specialists. A joint Commonwealth/States Committee on professional aspects of the Adult Migrant Education Program has been established to oversee curriculum and materials development. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs services the working parties, is responsible for liaison, undertakes some editing of the material produced and arranges the production of material. The number of staff involved is two.
(10) No Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs staff are directly employed on curriculum development.
The staff referred to in part (9) above speak a language other than English, have undertaken studies in the teaching of English as a second language andin linguistics.
(11) My Department does not keep statistics on the qualifications of the teachers who are employed by the States. The States have in-service training arrangements for teachers in the program. Under GalbaUy Recommendation 7, funds have been provided for in-service training and teacher development, especially for the On-arrival program. Two national in-service conferences have been held for Officers-in-Charge and Teachers-in-Charge with funds provided under this Recommendation. Funding has also been provided for local inservice arrangements, initially as a follow up to those conferences, and subsequently to assist the continuing development of teacher skills in planning and conducting courses, developing materials and evaluating outcomes.
(12) The Adult Migrant Education Program underwent change and reshaping following the Government's acceptance of the Galbally Report. Reshaping and development are continuing in accordance with the objectives of the Adult Migrant Education Program, viz:
1. To provide English language learning opportunities for migrants and refugees from non-English speaking backgrounds including specific need groups to meet personal, social and employment needs and to equip them to understand and make use of social institutions including those institutions through which they may wish to pursue educational advancements.
2. To provide information about living in Australia.
(13) There are various mechanisms of consultation regarding the Adult Migrant Education Program:
(i) Consultative committees in each State comprising senior officers of the State Adult Migrant Education Services and DIEA Regional Offices.
(ii) Commonwealth/State meetings of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs officers.
(iii) Commonwealth/State meetings of Ministers for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
(iv) Joint Commonwealth/States Committee ori professional aspects of the Adult Migrant Education Program.
(v) State level Migrant Settlement Councils.
(vi) Consultations between senior officers from the States and DIEA Central and Regional Offices on budget and program matters.
(vii) Joint Commonwealth/State Co-ordinating Committee on the Home Tutor Scheme.
(viii) Joint Steering committees in States to oversee the implementation of studies and surveys.
(ix) Day to day liaison between DIEA Regional Office and the State Adult Migrant Education Services officers.
(14) My Department as my delegate is responsible for arranging the provision of courses in accordance with the Immigration (Education) Act. This co-ordinating and arranging role has recently been confirmed in the Prime Minister's statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions. The States

or other agencies with whom the arrangements are made for the provision of courses are responsible for the employment of
teachers and for their terms and conditions of service.

(15) The number of Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs personnel employed on the Adult Migrant Education Program in the Department's Central and Regional
Offices, as at 30 April was:

Central Office

15

Regional Offices

31

46

Chemical and Biological Defence
(Question No. 491)
Mr Holding asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:
Further to his predecessor's answer to parts (9), (10) and (II) of Question No. 5359 (Hansard, 22 May 1980, page 3198), what is the definition of the term 'chemical and biological defence' in the two agreements referred to.
Mr Street-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The two arrangements referred to are the Technical Cooperation Program, which is administered in Australia by the Defence Science and Technology Organisation, and the Basic Standardisation Agreement, which is administered by the Army. Neither contains a definition of chemical and biological defence. The terms are interpreted by the participating countries in accordance with common usage. The definition of chemical and biological defence which is applicable to Australia's involvement in both arrangements is that stated in the Australian Joint Services Staff Manual Glossary: 'The methods, plans, procedures and training required to establish defence measures against the effects of attack by chemical and biological agents.'

Unemployment in New South Wales
(Question No. 538)
Mr Mountford asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:
(1) How many persons were registered as being unemployed in the Commonwealth Employment Office areas of (a) Hurstville, (b) Bankstown and (c) Campsie, New South Wales, in (i) 1978, (ii) 1979 and (iii) 1980.

Service by Australian Army Officers in United Nations Truce Supervisory Organisation in Palestine
(Question No. 592)
Mr Milton asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:
Will the Minister consider the declaration of Service by a small contingent of Australian Army officers in the United Nations Truce Supervisory Organisation in Palestine during the 1960's and early 1970's as eligibility for repatriation and Defence Service Homes benefits.
Mr Thomson-The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
The question of providing Repatriation and Defence Service Homes benefits to members of the United Nations Peacekeeping, Monitoring and Observing Forces and to members of similar forces has been considered on many occasions.

Although it was recognised that they would be placed in a position where injury or death could occur in the course of their duties, they were not required to engage enemy forces in military operations and were not considered to be on 'special duty' in a 'special area' as defined in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962.
Consideration of this matter involves more than service in Palestine. It would also have to include the extension of benefits to al1 serving Defence members and others involved in peacekeeping forces e.g. those in Cyprus.
However, members of peacekeeping, monitoring and observing Forces are eligible to claim compensation under the Commonwealth Employees' Compensation Act 1930-1970 which has since been replaced by the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act 1971. Special United Nations compensation provisions also applied to their service.
Social Security Appeal Procedures
(Question No. 760)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:
(1) What procedures are followed in appeals lodged by Federal Members of Parliament on behalf of aggrieved social security recipients or unsuccessful social security applicants against a decision of (a) a Social Security branch office, where the appeal is lodged with the State Director of Social Security and (b) a State Director of Social Security, where the appeal is lodged with the Minister for Social Security.
(2) What is the average time taken to process these appeals.
(3) What was the average time taken in 1980 to process appeals made to the Social Security Tribunal on decisions concerning (a) invalid pensions, (b) age pensions, (c) Unemployment benefits, (d) supporting parents benefits, (e) family al1owances, (f) widows' pensions and (g) special benefits in (i) Brisbane, (ii) Sydney, (iii) Melbourne, (iv) Adelaide, (v) Perth, (vi) Darwin, (vii) Hobart and (viii) Canberra.
(4) Are Social Security Tribunals in each State required to have as a member of the Tribunal a representative of the medical profession.
(5) Is it a fact that the Social Security Tribunal in Brisbane has been without a representative of the medical profession as a member of the Tribunal for several months; if so, why.
(6) If the Brisbane Tribunal has been without a representative of the medical profession has this resulted in delays of up to 4 to 5 months in processing appeal applications.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) Where an appeal is lodged against a decision made by an officer in a Social Security branch office or by a State Director, and that appeal has not previously been considered by a Social Security Appeals Tribunal, the appeal is referred to the Tribunal for registration and is then handled in accordance with the normal procedures governing social security appeals. These procedures require, among other things, that the decision appealed against be reconsidered by the Department of Social Security and then, if the appeaJis not to be conceded at this stage, dealt with by the Tribunal.
Where an appeal has previously been considered by a Tribunal which has recommended dismissal of the appeal, since 9 September 1980 the unsuccessful appellant may appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The State Director of Social Security in the case of representations made to him

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3489

from a Federal Member of Parliament, and the Director General of the Department in the case of representations to the Minister for Social Security, could still review the decision appealed against where, for example, additional evidence was supplied, notwithstanding this further right of appeal. The Federal Member is, of course, advised of the outcome of the appeal. Representations from Federal Members not involving an appeal are dealt with in accordance with usual departmental procedures.
(2) Statistics on the average time taken to process these appeals are not collected separately from statistics for all finalised appeals dealt with by the Social Security Appeals Tribunals.
(3) Statistics on the average time taken in 1980 to process appeals made to the Social Security Appeals Tribunals are not available by pension, benefit or allowance. The average processing time shown in the table below is for finalised appeals dealt with by the Social Security Appeals Tribunals by State and Territory. The average processing time measures the number of working days between the date of registration of the appeal by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the date of the Tribunal's recommendation. Where the Tribunal recommends dismissal of the appeal, the date of the recommendation is the same as the date of finalisation. However, where the Tribunal recommended the appeal be upheld, processing time does not include the period between the date the Tribunal made a recommendation and the date the Department finalised the appeal, for which statistics are not available.

(4) No. A Social Security Appeals Tribunal has a doctor as one of its members only when dealing with medical appeals under the Social Services Act 1947. There is no requirement to have a doctor when a Tribunal is dealing with a nonmedical appea\.
(S) A medical practitioner was appointed to the Social Security Appeals Tribunals in Queensland on 27 May 1981 and I expect to make additional appointments soon. A major obstacle in the making of such appointments prior to this was the reluctance of suitable doctors to accept appointment at the then prevailing rates of remuneration. However, after I raised this matter with the Minister for Administrative Services, a new determination was made by the Remuneration Tribunal on 4 May 1981 increasing the sitting fees payable to all members of the Social Security Appeals Tribunals.
(6) The delay in appointing doctors to the Queensland Social Security Appeals Tribunals has unfortunately meant that some medical appeals have not been handled as expeditiously as might otherwise have been the case, but it is not possible to say how many appeals have been so aft-ected. It is important to note however that the right of appeal operates in addition to, rather than in substitution for, the review process which previously operated, and that delays in the appointment of doclors to the Tribunals have in no way delayed this process, which involves the Department of Health and, as appropriate, external medical specialists.

Has the Government announced that it wishes to give assistance and encouragement to parents attempting to provide education in a normal school for their disabled children as opposed to special schools and sheltered employment; if so, in this International Year of Disabled Persons will this assistance include telephone concessions to families caring for disabled children at home.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question.

the integration of a further 300 handicapped children into regular schools, to operate from 1981. In addition, priority will be given to funding projects that will result in the movement of as many children as possible from special to regular schools. Government and non-government school systems, and schools. will be eligible to apply for grants for projects. The funds may also be used to:
(a) provide support to enable isolated handicapped children to attend neighbourhood regular schools;
(b) fund projects designed to test new ways of fully or partialIy assisting handicapped children already integrated into regular schools; and
(c) facilitate the enrolment of handicapped children who are beginning their formal schooling into regular primary schools.

The Government announced on 20 August 1980 that an additional $101 will be provided under the Schools Commission's Special Education Program for extra Staff resources to assist

The provisions of this program do not include telephone concessions for families caring for disabled children.

Answers to Questions

Underspending of Estimates: Department of Employment and Youth Affairs
(Question No. 1102)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:
(l) On what basis were the original 1980-81 appropriations made for division (a) 286-Administrative and (b) 288Commonwealth Employment Service.
(2) Has there been an underspending in these divisions by the estimate contained in the Department of Finance Information Paper, 'Statement on savings expected in annual appropriations made by Acts Nos. 141 and 142Appropriations Acts (Nos 1 and 2) 1980-81; if so, what are the reasons.
Mr N. A. Brown-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The original 1980-81 Appropriations made for my Department for Division 286-Administrative and Division 288-Commonwealth Employment Service were those presented to the Parliament in Appropriation Bill (No.1) 1980-81. The Government considered my Department's estimates in the light of its policies in respect of particular areas of expenditure and of general financial and economic objectives.
The general principles applied to the preparation of estimates by my Department are set out in the Directions issued by the Secretary of the Department of Finance under the Authority of the Audit Act 1901. These Directions are long standing and have been endorsed by successive Governments. The relevant general principles are set out in Finance Direction 6.3 and provide in essence that:
(i) Estimates shall represent a realistic assessment of the sums expected to be spent and shall be based on current or known costs. Items of a recurring nature may be estimated on the basis of experience.
(ii) Estimates shall not include amounts in respect of proposals which are so far from firm that it is not possible to form any real estimate of what payment, if any, will be made.
(2) The Department of Finance Information Paper, 'Statement of Savings Expected in Annual Appropriations Made By Acts Nos. 141 and 142-Appropriation Acts (Nos. 1 and 2) 1980-81', sets out amounts by which my Department estimated, at the time of preparation of the Appropriation Bills (Nos. 3 and 4) 1980-81, expenditure under the Appropriation Items concerned would at 30 June fall short of the Appropriation originally made. What actual underspending will occur in respect of those or other Items cannot be stated with certainty at this stage. The estimated savings would rellect for the most part the following circumstances:
(i) Current expectation that events would not occur by 30 June 1981, in cases where financial provision had been made in the Appropriation Acts (Nos. 1 and 2) 1980-81 in the then expectation that they would occur by that date.
(ii) Compliance with Government policy that, as far as practicable, savings be offered as offsets to additional funds sought in the Appropriation Bills (Nos. 3 and4), 1980-81; and
(iii) The results of efforts by Departmental management to improve efficiency and thereby reduce costs.

Underspending ofEstimates: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs
(Question No.n08)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:
(1) On what basis were the original 1980-81 appropriations made for division (a) 360-Administrative and (b) 364Overseas service.
(2) Has there been an underspending in these divisions by the estimate contained in the Department of Finance Information Paper, Statement of savings expected in annual appropriations made by Acts Nos. 141 and 142-Appropriation Acts (Nos. 1 and 2) 1980-81; ifso, what are the reasons.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
I refer the honourable member's attention to answer No. 1101 given by the Treasurer on behalf of the Minister for Finance in Hansard of 13 May 1981, page 2374.

Social Security Appeals Tribunal
(Question No. 1189)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:
(1) When did it become mandatory for one position on the Social Security Appeals Tribunal in each State to be set aside for a medical representative.
(2) Can the tribunals function without a medical representative.
(3) For what periods have the tribunals been without a medical representative.
(4) What is the remuneration made available to a medical representative on the tribunal.
(5) Does the remuneration differ among tribunal members.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) On 9 September 1980 the former Minister for Social Security announced that suitably qualified medical practitioners would be appointed to Social Security Appeals Tribunals to enable those tribunals to consider appeals against decisions of the Department of Social Security which involve medical assessment.
(2) Yes, for the purpose of considering appeals of a nonmedical nature.
(3) Medical practitioners were first appointed to the Social Security Appeals Tribunals in Victoria, Western Australia, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory in December 1980, in South Australia in January 1981, in New South Wales in February 1981, in the Northern Territory in March 1981, andin Queensland in May 1981.
(4) Medical practitioners appointed to the Social Security Appeals Tribunals receive remuneration, in accordance with a determination made by the Remuneration Tribunal, at rates equivalent to the sessional fees payable from time to time to senior medical specialists visiting Repatriation Institutions. The current rate is $34.50 per hour.
(5) Yes. Non-medicalmcmbers of Social Security Appeals Tribunals receive remuneration at the rates of $135 per day (Chairman) or $115 per day (other member), in accordance with a determination made by the Remuneration Tribunal. Such members receive 50 per cent of the daily rate for meetings ofless than three hours' duration.

(i) Capital, salary, equipment, maintenance subsidies and Handicapped Children's Benefit have been paid under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act
(ii) Three residential projects have been approved under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act for rental subsidy commencing 1981-82.

Integration of Handicapped Children into Regular Schools
(Question No. 1195)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to the estimate of the Director of Child and Adolescent Psychiatric Services at Melbourne's Austin Hospital, Dr Bruce Tonge, that more than 20 per cent of children under 18 years of age suffer from chronic illness or disability.
(2) If so, does Dr Tonge estimate that this percentage is increasing.
(3) What is the Government's commitment in respect of the integration of handicapped children into regular schools.
(4) Will the total 1980 allocation of$lm for the integration of handicapped children into regular schools be increased for the next school year.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) and (2) Although I am unaware of the basis of Dr Tonge's estimate, the Australian Health Survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) in 1977-78 revealed that 19 per cent of children under 5 years, 27 per cent of persons between the ages of 5 and 14 years and 32 per cent of persons aged 15 to 24 had a chronic condition (ie. any permanent disability; any illness, injury or impairment which a respondent claims to have had for more than six months; illnesses under control e.g. diabetes, epilepsy).
Because a dissection of the above data by single year ages is not available, the percentage relating to such persons under the age of 18 years cannot be accurately determined.
The ABS plans to repeat the Australian Health Survey in 1983. No later figures for comparative purposes will be available until the survey is completed.
The definition of a chronic condition used in the Health Survey covers a wide range of illnesses and disabilities of varying levels of severity. I presume many of the children of school age who are included could be attending normal schools. The

3494 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

relevance of the Survey to the Government's supplementary program to assist, the integration of handicapped children into normal schools cannot be readily assessed.
(3) The Government's commitment in respect of the integration of handicapped children into regular schools is to provide $lm (subject to norma! allowance for price rises) in 198! for:
(a) projects that will result in the movement of as many children as possible from special to regular schools;
(b) support to enable isolated handicapped children to attend neighbourhood regular schools;
(c) projects designed to test new ways of fully or partially assisting handicapped children already integrated into regular schools;
(d) facilitating the enrolment of handicapped children who are beginning their formal schooling into regular primary schools.
Of these purposes it is intended that priority should be given to the first one, which is concerned with the movement of children from special to regular schools. '
Applications from systems and their schools and from nonsystemic schools are appraised by panels in the States and the Northern Territory representative of Education Departments, Catholic Education Commissions, Associations of Independent Schools and the Schools Commission. The recommendations of appraisal panels are submitted for my approval. Grants are offered and payments are made to systems and individual schools for approved projects.
(4) For 1982 the Government has maintained expenditure, in real terms, on the integration of handicapped children into regular schools. This expenditure will be more closely related to the special education programs for government and nongovernment schools by being incorporated as an element of these programs in 1982.

Employment of Private Consultants: Department of Housing and Construction
(Question No. 1282)
Mr Dungey asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on9 April1981:
Were any private consultants or consultancy firms employed by his Department in 1979-80; if so, (a) how many were employed, (b) who were they, (c) for what purpose was each employed and (d) what payments were made to each consultant or consultancy firm.

Mr McVeigh-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Yes. The Department of Housing and Construction is a major user of private consulting firms, particularly architects, engineers, quantity surveyors and other associated professional and technical disciplines. The Department also places contracts with firms for technical personnel services.
Private consultants are employed for planning and design of Commonwealth building and engineering works.
Approximately 1,200 contracts were placed with consultants and contract personnel firms in 1979-80.
A detailed list covering all of these contracts is too extensive to present in answer to this question; all con~racts over $1,000 are published in the Commonwealth Gazette. The value of individual contracts in 1979-80 varied between $500 and $500,000.

(2) Decisions to relocate units of Government employment to Canberra are taken by Government on the advice of the

Home Telephone Rentals: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs
(Question No. 1535)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1981 :
(I) How many officers and employees of his Department have their home telephone rentals and/or charges (a) fully or (b) partially paid by his Department.
(2) What was the cost to his Department of this expenditure in 1979-80.
MI' Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) (a) and (b) 129 officers employed in my Department in Australia have their telephone rental and part of the charges made paid by the Department. 125 officers in overseas posts also have part of their telephone charges met by the Department. (1n some cases these costs are met as a condition of overseas service.)
(2) The cost of semi-official telephones for officers in Australia in 1979-80 was $16,850. The cost of phones installed in residences of officers overseas in 1979-80 was $16,752.
Recycling of Paper: Department of Social Security
(Question No. 1583)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
Has any action been taken by the Department of Social Security to re-cycle paper; if so, what action.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
The Department of Social Security makes use of facilities to recycle paper.
Generally waste paper from offices in all States and Territories, except Tasmania and the l'lorthern Territory, is recycled. Companies operating under government contract undertake this task. Some waste paper, for example from staff rubbish bins and from offices in country areas where a recycling service is unavailable, has to be burnt.
In Tasmania and the Northern Territory a recycling service is not available and all waste paper is burnt.
Offices in States and Territories bind suitable obsolete paper and it is used by staff as writing pads.
Recycling of Paper: Department of Education
(Question No. 1586)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
Has any action been taken by his Department to recycle paper, if so, what action.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Paper of an unclassified or non-sensitive nature is collected from the Department's offices in Canberra on a daily basis for the purpose of recycling by commercial interests. Similar arrangements exist in the States.

Where the Regional Offices of my Department are located in Commonwealth Government premises, collection is arranged by the Department of Administrative Services.
Recycling of Paper: Department of the Capital Territory
(Question No. 1591)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 9 April 1981 :
Has any action been taken by his Department to recycle paper; if so, what action.
Mr Hodgman-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
No action has been taken by the Department of the Capital Territory to recycle paper. However, for several years the Department has actively encouraged waste paper and cardboard recycling ventures by private enterprise. This initiative has been supported by the National Capital Development Commission through the LD.C. on Waste Disposal.
Collection centres have been established by the Department in Jolly Street, BeIconnen; Botany Street, Phillip and at the BeIconnen and Mugga Lane Landfills. These centres are cleared regularly by Canberra Paper and Cardboard Recycling Company.
It is estimated that in Canberra the company is collecting a total of 10,000 tonnes of recyclable paper and cardboard annually, of which 1,200 tonnes is generated from Government buildings and about 1,000 (onnes from the recycling centres.
Other contractors have entered the paper recycling business in Canberra, but their effect has not been significant.
The volume of material presently being recycled is consistent with the original expectations of the Australian paper manufacturing industry.

Demolition of Commonwealth Dwellings
(Question No. 1770)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(I) How many Commonwealth dwellings in the Australian Capital Territory have been demolished in each of the last three years, and what was the reason for each demolition.

Mr Hodgman-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(2) None.
Telephone Calls by Staff: Department of Veterans' Affairs
(Question No. 1889)
Mr Bungery asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report in the West Australian of 18 July 1979, page 37, that London metropolitan police reduced its telephone bill by $985,000, or about 20 per cent by use of monitoring device which recorded length, time and destination of telephone calls and the extension from which the call was made.
(2) Are personal telephone calls, particularly trunk and STD calls, made by staff of the Department of Veterans' Affairs controlled; if so, in what way.
(3) Has any consideration been given to the' introduction of monitoring devices for telephone calls in the Department; if so, what was the outcome of the consideration.
Mr Thomson-The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) Yes.
(2) Telephones are for official use only, although in an emergency private calls may be made. Private trunk calls are booked through the switchboard operator following approval by the officer's section head and the costs of such calls are to be remitted immediately to the Collector of Public Monies. It is not permitted to use STD for private calls. Where the switchboard equipment permits, STD access is restricted to those extensions where access is considered essential to the efficient operations of the officers concerned. All other extensions are barred from STD and details of trunk calls made from any extension are recorded by the switchboard operator. Where the equipment does not permit STD barring, switchboard operators carry out regular monitoring of calls.
(3) Monitoring devices, when available, are installed to record details of calls made and the information received is reviewed by senior staff members. The limited number of monitoring devices available and costs involved prohibit permanent installation on all extensions.

The Department of Veterans' Affairs is conscious of the need for economies in telephone usage and regular reviews are carried out in all areas of operations. Staff are made aware of Departmental policies in this regard and are encouraged to restrict telephone usage to essential business matter.'
Telephone Calls by Staff: Department of Housing and Construction
(Question No. 1891)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the West Australian of 18 July 1979, page 37, that London metropolitan police reduced its telephone bill by $985,000 or about 20 per cent, by use of a monitoring device which recorded length, time and destination of telephone calls and the extension from which the call was made.
(2) Are personal telephone calls, particularly trunk and STD calls, made by staff of his Department controlled; if so, in what way.
(3) Has any consideration been given to the introduction of monitoring devices for telephone calls in his department; if so, what was the outcome of the consideration.
Mr M"Veigh-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(J)Yes.
(2) .Telephones in the Department of Housing and Construction are STD barred to the maximum extent possible, consistent with efficiency.
Current instructions to staff do not allow access to STD for private calls. An officer making a private call is required to obtain the approval of his supervisor, book a trunk call through the switchboard operator, obtain the cost of the completed call from the operator and pay the Receiver of Public Moneys.
(3) Consideration has been given to the use of telephone monitoring devices. Some of the Department's offices have installed monitoring devices and negotiations are continuing with Telecom to extend this control.
Motor Vehicle Industry
(Question No. 1915)
Mr Burr asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(I) What is the annual cost of providing assistance to the Australian motor vehicle industry by (a) direct subsidy, (b) grant, (c) tariff protection, (d) quota protection and (e) other forms of State or Commonwealth assistance.
(2) Is he able to say how many persons are employed by the motor vehicle industry.
(3) What would be the cost of providing an annual pension to all motor vehicle industry employees at a rate equivalent to male average weekly earnings.
Sir Phillip' Lynch-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) (a) to (e) The assistance package for domestic passenger motor vehicle production is made up of a number of interrelated measures. The protective effect of many of these measures, for example, quotas, local content plan, is difficult to quantify in dollar terms. These difficulties are heightened when estimates of the subsidy equivalent of the protective incidence of the assistance package are aggregated and then evaluated on a 'per employee' basis.

Answers to Questions

10 June 198 [ REPRESENTATIVES 3499

The latest available estimates of assistance accorded to passenger motor vehicle production are contained in the Industries Assistance Commission's draft report 'Passenger Motor Vehicles and Components-Post 1984 Assistance Arrangements', released on 24 February 1981. Discussion of the effect of the assistance package on consumer prices and the allocation of productive resources is contained in Chapter 6 (especially pp 97-103) of the Commission's report. In appendix 8 of the report, the Commission discusses the assumptions under which its analysis has proceeded including some of the limitations of its approach.
(2) The latest available figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics based on the manufacturing census for 1978-79 estimate employment for the motor vehicles and parts industry at 76,664.
The Industries Assistance Commission's analysis of employment in passenger vehicle production is contained on pp 47-48 of the draft report. From evidence received the Commission estimated that in March 1980 about 65,000 persons were employed in the production of passenger vehicles and components. Of these, approximately 60 per cent were employed by the five Plan manufacturers.
The Commission's estimates arc broadly consistent with estimates by the Department of Industry and Commerce which indicate around 69,000 persons are currently employed in the industry-38,500 by the five Plan manufacturers, 400 in assembly outside the Plan and about 30,000 in over 700 establishments engaged in the production of automotive components.
These figures cover employment in the manufacturing sector only and do not include employment in related areas such as importing distribution and servicing. Estimates provided to the Commission by the Dealer's Association indicated that in 1979 dealers employed about 70,000 persons. Employment by importers is estimated at 12,800 in December 1980.
(3) The Australian Bureau of Statistics estimatc of average weekly earnings per employed male unit is $290.00 for the December quarter 1980. On this basis and the lAC and departmental figures provided in (2) above the annual cost of a pension to passenger motor vehicle manufacturing industry employees would be between $980.2m and $1040.5m.
Taxation on Profit from Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort Ltd Share Transactions
(Question No. 1945)
Mr Hurford asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to the reported $16.5m profit taken by Mr Robert Holmes a'Court and his Bell Group from the trading in shares of Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort Ltd.
(2) Is it a fact that this profit will not be taxable pursuant to section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, because the group has sold or is selling a subsidiary company which holds the Elders shares and is not selling the shares recently purchased.
(3) Is it the Government's intention that this profit should be taxable; if so, what action will be taken.
(4) Is it the Government's intention that this profit should be taxed, what is the reason.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2), (3) and (4) Because the secrecy provisions of the income tax law prevent the Commissioner of Taxation from informing either myself or any other person about the affairs

of individual taxpayers, I am not in a position to comment on the tax consequences of the transactions to which the honourable member refers.
I have, however, asked the Commissioner to examine the question of possible weaknesses in section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The matter is one of considerable complexity but I expect to receive a report from the Commissioner soon.
Regulation of Oil Prices
(Question No. 1949)
Mr Hurford asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 28 April 1981 :
(1) Does the recent report of the Prices Justification Tribunal on Prices for petroleum products, state that the Tribunal proposes to remove the return on the retailing investment component from the wholesale list price of motor spirit from January 1982.
(2) If so, is it the Government's intention to require that this price adjustment be made.
(3) Will he ensure that the Tribunal is able to conduct the further inquiries needed to enable the new list prices to be determined.
(4) Is the Government proposing to deregulate oil prices by abolishing the Tribunal at a time when oil companies have been seeking 3c per litre more than the Tribunal is prepared to allow and when there is so much more to be done.
Mr Moore-- The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The Prices Justification Tribunal, in its report of 31 March 1981 into the prices of petroleum products, stated that it proposed to remove the return on retail investment component from the maximum justified wholesale prices of motor spirit in January 1982.
(2), (3) and (4) On 27 May 1981 I introduced legislation into the Parliament to establish a Petroleum Products Pri9ing Authority. This body will have powers similar to those the PJT currently has in relation to petroleum product pricing, and will be able to consider matters such as the extent to which motor spirit prices include a return on investment by the companies in retail outlets.
Industries Assistance Commission Report on Wheelchairs
(Question No. 1954)
!VIr Duffy asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:
(1) Was the final Industries Assistance Commission report on wheelchairs signed on 23 December 1980 and submitted to thc Minister.
(2) If so, when is it expected that the report will be released.
(3) If the recommendations will be dealt with during 1981, will he be mindful of the fact that 1981 is the International Year of Disabled Persons.
Mr Moore-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) r tabled the report in the Parliament on 26 May 1981
following the Government's decision to reduce the tariff on mechanically propelled wheelchairs from 34 per cent to 20 per cent and the tariff on hand propelled wheelchairs from 36

3500 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

per cent to 20 per cent, in each case over a period of two years, as recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission.
(3) The Government was mindful of the fact that 1981 is the International Year of Disabled Persons when it considered the lAC report and made its decision thereon. The Government was also conscious of the scheme it announced in the budget to provide aids, inoluding wheelchairs, free of charge to the disabled, subject to specialist medical prescription.

Students in Tertiary Educational Institutions
(Question No. 2010)
Dr Klugman asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 30 April 1981:
(1) What proportion of schoolleavers proceed to full time tertiary education in (a) Australia (b) The United States of America and (c) Japan.
(2) Is he able to say what proportion of students in tertiary educational institutions in (a) Australia, (b) the USA and (c) Japan pay tuition fees.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) (a) A survey carried out by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in May 1980 revealed that in Australia 22.2 per cent of persons who left secondary school in 1979 studied full time in 1980 at a post-school educational institution (inc1udinguniversity, college of advanced education and technical and further education institutions).
(b) and (c) Comparable information on schoolleavers is not readily available for the USA and Japan. The following table, while not relating specifically to school leavers, does show the proportions of persons of particular ages attending tertiary education institutions (excluding technical and further education institutions in the case of Australia) on a full time basis. These figures are the latest available from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). Interpretation of the figures should take into account such factors as differences in education systems, the emphasis placed on part time education in Australia (particularly through apprenticeships) and deficiencies in the scope and coverage of the statistics. A description of how the education systems in each of the three countries are classified is contained in 'Classification of Educational SystemsSummary Volume' OECD Paris 1975.
TERTIARY PARTICIPATION RATE~) PER CENT 1976

Age Australia

Japan USA

17

8.6

(a) Persons of specified ages enrolled full time in tertiary education as proportions of persons of those ages in the population.
Source: 'Educational Statistics in OECD Countries'- OECD, Paris 1981.
(2) (a) In Australi!!, since 1974, tuition fees have not been imposed at tertiary institutions for vocationally oriented courses, or courses leading to awards. Most students at universities, colleges of advanced education and technical and further education institutions are in this category, the notable

exceptions being TAFE students enrolled in adult education courses. The recently announced decision that tuition fees be re-introduced in universities and colleges of advanced education for students undertaking degrees and diplomas subsequent to an initial tertiary qualification except for recognised double degree or diploma combinations and postgraduate students in receipt of Commonwealth Postgraduate Awards or holders of university and college of advanced education postgraduate awards will take effect for new enrolments from the beginning of 1982.
(b) In the USA I understand that it is general practice for tertiary institutions to charge all undergraduate students tuition fees. Recent information indicates that these fees range from approximately $US200 to $US 1000 per year at state funded institutions. Annual tuition fees at private institutions range up to $USSOOO p.a.
(c) In Japan all undergraduate students pay tuition fees. The scale offees charged is not readily available.
Refugees
(Question No. 2014)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 30 April 1981:
(1) What proportion of the annual expenditure of his Department is allocated for (a) immigrants and (b) refugees, considering that the money allocated under the Galbally Report did not make any specific provisions for refugees.
(2) Were approximately 20,000 refugees allowed into Australia in 1980.
(3) Have there been any specific funds allocated by his Department for the settlement of refugees.
(4) What provisions are there to cater for the specific needs of (a) refugees and (b) the increased number of immigrants, in 1981-82.
(S) For what programs and policies specifically concerning (a) refugees and (b) immigrants is his Department responsible and what sum was allocated to these specific, separate programs in each year since 1977.
(6) What proportion of his Department's expenditure on (a) refugees and (b) immigrants was spent on administrative expenses in each of the same years.
(7) With what other (a) Commonwealth and (b) State departments does his Department share responsibilities for the settlement of (i) refugees and (ii) immigrants.
(8) What consultative mechanisms are there between his Department and the States concerning the settlement of (a) refugees and (b) immigrants.
(9) To what degree are the various States consulted on the number of (a) refugees and (b) immigrants they are capable of settling on a (i) long and (il) short term basis.
(10) What provisions, such as special funds, etc., exist to help the States to cope with the speedy and successful settlement of (a) refugees and (b) immigrants and what sum was paid for this purpose in each year since 1977.
(11) How many (a) refugees and (b) immigrants are currently staying in the various settlement centres in each State.
(12) How many of the (a) refugees, (b) immigrants or (c) other categories received assisted passage since 1977 and what was the country of citizenship of the recipients.
(13) What projects exist to cater for the speedy settlement of (a) refugees and (b) immigrants in each State.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

Answers to Question.I'

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3501

(1) Programs administered by DIEA to facilitate settlement are designed for immigrants. In this respect refugees are regarded as a category of immigrant. In general, no specific allocations are made for the various categories of immigrants.
(2) 21,692 persons entered Australia in 1980 under the Refugee and related programs.
(3) Apart from programs referred to in (i), funds are available to reimburse voluntary agencies for expenditure on clothing and other necessities provided to needy refugees immediately on arrivaL A revolving fund has been established and administered by voluntary agencies (CALFRIC) to provide establishment loans up to a maximum of $600 for refugees. Payment of special benefits by Department of Social Security is payable from day of arrival where required rather than after seven days in the case of certain other immigrants.
(4) This will be taken into consideration in the context of the 1981-82 Budget.
(5) Various programs are administered by DIEA to facilitate the settlement of migrants. Specific programs may be identified from the recommendations of the Galbally Report which the Government accepted in full and is implementing and also from details of votes administered by DIEA within its appropriations.
(6) Total administrative expenses of DIEA are set out in departmental appropriations. No breakdown between the various components of the Department's activities is available.
(7) Department of Social Security, Commonwealth Employment Service, Department of Administrative Services, Department of Education, State Adult Migrant Education Services, State Ministries of Immigration and/or Ethnic Affairs, health authorities and others.
(8) Meetings of Commonwealth and State Ministers for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and meetings of Commonwealth and State officials are held twice a year. Extensive consultative arrangements apply with State Adult Migrant Education Services. There are Migrant Settlement Councils in all States and Territories with Commonwealth and State/Territorial Government representatives on them.
(9) The intake of refugee and other migrants is discussed at each six-monthly meeting of Commonwealth and State Ministers for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs as one of the principal agenda items. There are also regular consultations with the States at official level. Discussions encompass both short-term and long-term considerations.
(10) State Adult Migrant Education Services are responsible for the majority of the Adult Migrant Education Program which is virtually wholly funded by the Commonwealth from funds appropriated to DIEA. Joint funding arrangements are available for State Governments for the employment of interpreters and translators. Details of funds made available for these purposes may be obtained from Budget papers.
(11) As at 11 May 1981, there were the following numbers of refugees and migrants at migrant centres.

Endeavour East Hills Westbridge Cabramatta

In addition, migrant centres provide some accommodation for non-migrants-48 people (mainly apprentices) resided in the centres as at 11 May 1981.
I would draw the honourable member's attention to the fact that some State Government's also run centres which offer accommodation to migrants.
(12) Details can be found in Tables 14 and 23 in. the Australian Immigration Consolidated Statistics 1979. A copy has been forwarded to the honourable member.
(13) See (5). The Community Refugee Settlement Scheme has been established to facilitate the successful settlement of refugees directly into the community.

Immigration
(Question No. 2016)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 30 April 1981 :
(I) How many applications for (a) visitors', (b) permanent settlement and (c) temporary resident visas to Australia have been (i) approved and (ii) rejected since 1978 and from which countries were the (A) successful and (B) unsuccessful applications made.
(2) How many persons permitted to enter Australia without a permanent settlement visa since 1978 have permission to work in Australia.
(3) What provisions were there for (a) housing, (b) education, (c) employment, (d) social security, (e) health or (f) other areas for newly arrived permanent or temporary arrivals since 1978.
Mr Macphee--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) (a) and (c) SeeTableA.
(b) See Table B.
(2) Arrival of persons for temporary residence ('T' category).

3502 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

Period
1977-78 1978-79 1979-80 1980-81
(first six months)

No. of

No. of

workers dependants

27,527 31,908 45,823 22,932

8,991 9,374 8,059 6,041

Total persons
36,518 41,282 53,882 28,973

Note: Visitors are not normally permitted to undertake employment here. In applying for entry, visitors are required to make a declaration that they will not seek employment or undertake formal studies during the period of their intended stay in Australia.
Students may undertake vacation employment and/or employment as an integral part of their course and/or in the form of practical experience at the completion of their . courses. This is normally permitted where it is necessary to obtain registration or acceptance as a member of a professional body and where this necessary work experience cannot be gained in their own country. They may also undertake some part-time employment as long as this does not interfere with their academic progress.
Temporary residents include high level staff for Australian branches of overseas companies, academics for educational and research institutions, entertainers and sportsmen and certain professional and technical workers with special expertise who are often required in the early stages of establishment of some new developmental enterprises, Figures are not available by category by period of stay but the majority of specialised workers come for short periods, Usually temporary residents are eligible to remain for periods up to four years. The dependants of working age of temporary residents are not prohibited from undertaking employment or studies in Australia. The working holiday maker schemes involve reciprocity and the work is incidental to the holiday,

(3) Migrants entering Australia for permanent residence have the same entitlements as ordinary residents of Australia in regard to the matters raised. In more specific terms:
(a) housing-certain migrants and refugees are entitled to initial accommodation in migrant centres; family reunion categories are expected to be accommodated initially at least by a sponsoring close relative; generally permanent arrivals are eligible for State Government provided housing on the same basis as normal Australian residents, waiting periods varying from State to State;
(b) education-migrants and their dependants have the same access to education as other residents but in addition special programs of English language learning are available for both adults and children from funding provided mainly by the Commonwealth;
(c) employment-the facilities of the Commonwealth Employment Service are available for all migrants and refugees;
(d) social security-permanent arrivals are entitled to aU social security provisions on the same basis as other Australian residents-" residential requirements apply in certain instances;
(e) health-most medical and hospital organisations have special arrangements for newly arrived migrants ensuring that they can acquire adequate cover from the date of arrival without any waiting period. The Government has decided that migrants and refugees will be eligible for bulk billing for medical services for six months after arrival. Migrants and refugees are subject to health screening before visas are issued;
(f) other areas-an extensive range of programs is available to facilitate the settlement of migrants and refugees including those covered by recommendations of the Galbally Report.
Access to matters covered hy (a) to (f) by temporary arrivals varies according to the condition of their entry.
