Taxation Avoidance
(Question No. 2021)
Mr Jacobi asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:
(1) Further to my question without notice to him on 9 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1519) in relation to the weakness of section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, is he now able to confirm that (a) a $16.5m tax-free profit was made by the Bell group of companies for its sale of shares in Elder Smith Goldsborough Mort Ltd, and that this transaction reveals a weakness in this section of the Act; (b) in November of 1979 the Bell group made a similar tax-free profit of $llm by selling a subsidiary company, Bell Air Charter, which has purchased shares in Ansett Transport Industries Ltd for the Bell group during a takeover attempt and (c) in August 1980 the Bond group used a similar device to make a tax-free profit of $32m by selling a subsidiary, Narla prospecting company, which had purchased shares in the White Industries organisation.
(2) Was he aware of these manipUlations of the Act lo avoid laxation; if so, should earlier action have been taken to block this blatant lax avoidance.
(3) Will he give an assurance that appropriate action will be taken to strengethen the appropriate provisions of the Act and that this action will be made retrospective.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) and (2) As I mentioned in my reply to the honourable member's question of 9 April 1981 concerning this matter, I

cannot precisely affirm or deny a particular tax position of an individual taxpayer. That is because the secrecy provisions of the income tax law prevent the Commissioner of Taxation from disclosing information about the affairs of any taxpayer.
(3) As I also said in my answer to the honourable member's question of 9 April 1981, I have asked the Commissioner of Taxation to examine the question of possible weakness in section 26AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The matter isby no means free of complexity but I expect to receive the Commissioner's advice soon.
Unemployed Meatworkers: Retraining
(Question No. 2032)

(2) Will unemployed meatworkers be eligible for (a) retraining under the NEAT Scheme and (b) the Relocation Assistance Allowance given the current recession and the uncertain future in the meat processing industry throughoUl Australia.
Mr N. A. Brown-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.

Answers to Questions

(2) (a) and (b) Yes. Subject to their meeting the normal criteria for those programs.
Sale of Publicly-owned Enterprises in Australian Capital Territory
(Question No. 2084)
Mrs Kelly asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
What gift duty or tax will be payable on the sale of publiclyowned enterprises and facilities in the Australian Capital Territory.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The Gift Duty Act 1941 now has no application except in respect of gifts made before I July 1979.
Liability for stamp duty depends upon the nature of a transaction including, in respect of the proposed sales referred to, any conditions ofsale which may be fixed by the Parliament.
Section 6 of the Australian Capital Territory Stamp Duty Act 1969 provides, however, for exemption from stamp duty of conveyances by or in the name of the Commonwealth.
Discontinuance ofProjects in Australian Capital Territory
(Question No. 2116)
Mrs Kelly asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
(1) What sums have been spent on (a) feasibility studies, (b) analysis of client needs and (c) preliminary consultations in drawing up the briefs for the (i) National Biological Standards Laboratory,' (ii) Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Building, (iii) National Library extensions and (iv) Canberra Law Courts in the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) What sums have been spent on (a) design, drafting and plans and (b) site purchase and preparation for each project referred to in,part (I).
(3) Have tenders and/or contracts been let; if so will he provide a list of these and the cost of each.
(4) What work has already been carried out.
(5) What will be the cost of reneging on existing contracts and/or tenders already let.
(6) To what purpose will the proposed sites for these projects now be put, in view of decisions outlined in the Review of Commonwealth Functions (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1838).
Mr Hodgman-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
I am advised by the National Capital Development Commission that:
(1) (a) $26,412 has been expended on feasibility studies for the National Library Extension. Internal resources were used to undertake feasibility studies for the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation Building (Russell Drive Offices) and the Canberra Law Courts and these costs are not separably identifiable.
(1) (b) $37,499 has been expended on operational appraisal studies for the National Library Extension. Internal resources were used to analyse client needs for the Russell Drive Offices and the Canberra Law Courts.
(1) (c) Internal resources were used to conduct preliminary consultations on architectural briefs for the Russell

Drive Offices, National Library Extension and the Canberra Law Courts.
(2) (a) It is estimated that the following sums have been spent on design, drafting and plans:
Russell Drive Offices-$125,000 National Library Extension-$580,696 Canberra Law Courts-$165,371
(2) (b) $33,926 has been expended on site preparation for the Russell Drive Offices. No site preparation work had been undertaken for the National Library Extension or for the Canberra Law Courts. No funds were expended on land acquisition for these projects.
(3) The following contracts had been entered into on the Russell Drive Offices:
Siteworks and excavation-$133,355 Plumbing and drainage-$305,035 Project Management agreement-$420,ooO
Tenders had not been called for the National Library Extension or the Canberra Law Courts.
(4) Siteworks and excavation to the value of $33,926 has been undertaken at Russell Drive Offices. A further $184,622 has been expended on purchase of materials, plant and machinery hire, site establishment and on-site labour.
(5) The estimated cost of terminating the Russell Drive Office contracts is $50,000.
(6) The projects identified by the honourable member have been deferred and the sites will be retained.
I am advised by the Minister for Housing and Construction that:
(1) The following sums are estimated to have been expended on the National Biological Standards Laboratory (NBSL) project:
Development of initial client brief and feasibility study-$130,000
Refinement of client brief and preliminary design- $340,000
Design development and full documentation- $2,200,000
(2) The following contracts have been let for the NBSL project:
Micro-processor and model room-$73,OOO ACT Electricity Authority-$18,900 OCT (site fencing)-$5,830 Site sign-$I,OOO Cladding prototype--$3,700 Site testing-$5,553 Site works-$292,667
(3) The following work has been carried out on the NBSL project:
Micro-processor and model room-60 per cent complete ACT Electricity Authority-complete DCT (site fencing)-80 per cent complete Sign-complete Prototype-complete Site testing-complete Site works-80 per cent complete
(4) All contracts let on the NBSL project will be completed.
(5) The NBSL project has been deferred and the site will be retained.

Taxing of Subsidised Rentals
(Question No. 2160)
Mr Campbell asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
(I) Did he say in his Press release No. 132 of 25 September 1980, that the Government was going to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act in relation to paragraph 26 (e) relating to the taxing of subsidised rentals; if so, when does he expect to introduce the legislation.
(2) Will the coastal towns of the Pilbara Region, Western Australia, be covered by the amended legislation or will they have to rely on an amendment to section 26AAA of the Act.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The Government remains committed to an amendment of the income tax law as outlined in my statement of 25 September 1980 and in my further statement of 13 October in which I indicated that the amendment would apply from the beginning of the 1977-78 income year. The necessary legislation cannot be got ready before the winter recess. It can be expected vcry early in the Budget sittings.
(2) The areas to be covered by the amending legislation will be announced when the legislation is brought forward.
Occupational Safety and Health
(Question No. 2198)
Mr Hawke asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:
(1) Does he regard as appropriate the statements contained in the 1979-80 Annual Report of the Department of Productivity that occupational safety and health is an area of considerable concern to the Department and that the social and economic cost of industrial accidents is known to be massive.
(2) Will he outline the reasons underlying the decision of the Committee for the Review of Commonwealth Functions to abolish two national committees operating in the area of occupational safety and health.
(3) Does he intend that the policing of such an important area of employee welfare should be left in the hands of employers in the private sector.
Mr Thomson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(l) The social and economic cost of industrial accidents is

know to be massive, and the Government will play its part in

efforts to reduce this toll.

.

(2) The Committee for the Review of Commonwealth Functions was charged with reviewing functions to determine which properly belonged to the Commonwealth and which
might more appropriately be handled elsewhere. Its recommendation to scale down activities in the subject area and transfer residual activities to the Department of Industrial
Relations was agreed by Government. The Minister for Industrial Relations will be considering how best to handle the work of the two committees that are to be abolished.

(3) The responsibility for administering safety and health
legislation applying to the workforce rests with the States. The Government will be anxious to co-operate with them in this important area of employee welfare.

Social Security: Reviews of Pension and Benefi t Entitlements
(Question No. 2264)
Mr Humphreys asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:
(1) Did the Minister say in reply to my question No. 750 (Hansard, 2 April 1981, page 1339) that reviews of pension and benefit entitlements in other countries are not carried out by field officers hut are carried out by mail.
(2) If so, is the form of this review similar to what is known in Australia as a P.E.R. Review.
(3) Is the Minister satisfied that this is an adequate way of checking on pension and benefit entitlements, given that under the Social Services Act persons in Australia in receipt of pensions must subject themselves to the scrutiny of Social Security field officers in order to satisfy certain eligibility requirements.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) In reply to Question No. 750 of 10 March 1981 (Hansard, 2 April 1981, page 1339) I said that reviews of pensions payable overseas are generally carried out by mail.
(2) The review known as the P.E.R. review is carried out in respect of pensions payable overseas other than those payable through the Geneva office. In that office a local program similar to the P.E.R. is undertaken. In addition to the scheduled reviews other reviews may be undertaken as and when the need arises.
(3) The Department of Social Security does not have field officers overseas and it does not have staff located in every country where pensions and benefits are payable. The review of pensions payable overseas does, therefore, present problems which do not arise in Australia. However, every efrort is taken to ensure that pensioners and beneficiaries living overseas continue to meet the eligibility conditions as laid down in the Social Services Act.
Tertiary Tuition Fees
(Question No. 2265)
Mr Humphreys asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 13 May 1981 :
Do Honours and Masters Qualifying degrees fall within the category of recognised double degree or combination courses, as referred to in the Review of Commonwealth Functions in connection with tertiary tuition fees (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1843).
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Honours years or Master's qualifying years are undertaken as parts of or as extensions to undergraduate courses and therefore where students undertake these studies in relation to first qualifications they will be exempt from the payment of tuition fees.

Investment Allowances
(Question No. 2277)
Mr Kerin asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:
(I) What items will be classed as certain new plant and equipment for the purposes of the reduced investment allowances referred to in attachment F to the Prime Minister's statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions.
(2) What will be the cost of this change to primary producers.
Mr HowardThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The classification includes all new plant and equipment to which the investment allowance applies. Broadly, the investment allowance applies to plant or articles within the meaning of the depreciation provisions of the income tax law, subject to specifically identified inclusions and exclusions.
The reduced investment allowance rate of 18 per cent will generally apply in respect of expenditure incurred after 30 April 1981 on the acquisition or construction of an eligible unit of property. However, the former rate of 20 per cent will continue to apply where the expenditure is incurred under a contract entered into on or before 30 April 1981, or is incurred in respect of the construction of an eligible unit of property by the taxpayer the construction of which commenced on or before that date.
(2) The increase in income tax payable by primary pr(J-. ducers as a result of the proposed reduction in investment allowance is estimated at about $7m in a full year.
Prices Justification Tribunal
(Question No. 2279)
Mr Kerin asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:
What have been the savings to (a) consumers and (b) primary industry as a result of inquiries by the Prices Justification Tribunal in respect of (i) stevedoring, (ii) spare parts, (iii) fuel and (iv) wool broking.
Mr Moore -The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
A number of PJT inquiries including those into stevedoring, spare parts, petroleum products and wool broking found that prices charged by the companies, or some of the companies, concerned were higher than justified or that proposed price increases were not wholly justified.
In some of those inquiries the PJT determined precisely the justified prices for particular products, but in other cases it indicated the order of price reduction warranted or simply invited companies to review their mark-ups in particular areas of activity.
In the case of petroleum products the oil companies at times have been unable to obtain in particular localities, because of market conditions, not only the prices they had proposed to the PJT but the prices found justified by the P1T.
In view of these and other considerations it is not possible to quantify the savings that may have flowed to consumers or to primary industry as a result of companies' complying with the P1T's findings. Savings to consumers that may have resulted from particular PJT inquiries need to be weighed, against the cost of the PJT's operations, including the direct cost to the Budget, the cost to business in complying with PJTprocedures and the wider effects of price regulation on business investment and the market place.

Answers to Questions

Research Paper on Unemployment Statistics
(Question No. 2311)
Mr Willis asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:

(2) Will the paper be published; irso, when.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social ~ecurity has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) A research paper titled 'U nempl6yment Statistics in Australia' was prepared in the Research and Statistics Branch of the Development Division of the Departmentin 1979. During the preparation of the paper, comments on a draft version were requested and received from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The paper forms part of a series of research papers that have been prepared and distributed by the Development Division of the Department of Social Security.
(2) The research paper was released in July 1979 and was given a wide distribution to such organisations and individuals as Commonwealth and State Departments, researchers at Universities and Colleges of Advanced Education" various community organisations (such as ACOSS) and libraries. Copies of the paper were provided in July 1979 to the ParliamentalY Library. Copies of all the research papers in the series prepared by the Developme!1t Division of the Department of Social Security are available on request.
S,ocial Security: Entrepreneurs
(Question No. 2340)
Dr Klugman asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 27 May 1981:
(1) Is there a special category of entrepreneurs who gain easier entry into Australia.
(2) If so, (a) what are the required'qualifications regarding the financial status of these persons and (b) is it necessary for these persons to have a minimum of $200,000 for investment in Australia.
(3) Was he consulted by the (a) Minister for Health, (b) Minister for Social Security or (c) Prime Minister before entrepreneurs were included in the list of disadvantaged persons eligible for free hospital and medical treatment for six months after arrival in Australia.
Mr Macphee-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Provision does exist for the entry of entrepreneurs who will establish and take an active part in running enterprises which will benefit Australia. The benefit may take the form of introducing new technology, improving exports or increasing employment. Persons who enter under these provisions must satisfy the normal character, health and settlement requirements for migration. Entrepreneurs are exempt from reaching a pass score in the economic factors section of NUMAS, Australia's Numerical Migrant Selection System, as the rules governing the appropriate levels of capital and income required for eligibility are sufficient to guarantee economic viability in Australia.

3510 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

(2) (a) and (b) There are no fixed or minimum financial requirements for entrepreneurs. Entrepreneurs must possess sufficient personal and unencumbered capital to establish the enterprise proposed in their application successfully. The actual amount will depend on the nature and magnitude of the enterprise.
(3) The decision to provide medical and hospital cover for migrants for the first six months in Australia was taken following completion of the usual consultative arrangements.
Bank Mergers
(Question No. 2345)
Dr Jenkins asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice; on 27 May 1981:
Will recent bank mergers cause staff retrenchments in the banking industry; if so, (a) what is the expected number of retrenchments, (b) will his Department initiate retraining programs for retrenched staff and (c) what other measures will his Department provide to assist retrenched staff.

(a) The companies involved in proposed bank mergers have not advised me of the numbers of retrenchments, if any, which might result.
(b) and (c) Any retrenched bank staff would have access to the normal range of retraining programs and services provided by my Department.
Tax Concessions for Land Clearing
(Question No. 2349)
Mr West asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 May 1981:
(I) When applying the provision of tax concessions for land clearing, does the Government make a distinction between environmentally sensitive lands, such as semi-arid lands prone to loss of soil and desertification, and other less sensitive lands, in order to avoid encouraging the loss of fragile environments by discretionary application of the provision.
(2) What estimated sum is lost to revenue as a result of the tax concession.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Section 75A of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, under which deductions are allowable, in equal instalments over 10 years, for expenditure incurred in clearing land on which a business of primary production is carried on, does not provide the Commissioner of Taxation with any discretionary authority of the kind referred to in the honourable member's question.
(2) The available statistics of deductions allowed under section 75A for the various classes of expenditures that qualify for deductions on the basis of that section do not include separate information on the revenue cost of deductions in respect ofland clearing.
Care and Use of Animals in Research
(Question No. 2459)
Mr Humphreys asked the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:
(1) Has the CSIRO drawn up a Code of Practice in respect to the care and use of animals in research.
(2) If so, over which research laboratories does this code have applicability.

(3) Does his Department carry out inspections of laboratories to ensure compliance with this code; if so, how often are inspections made.
Mr Thomson-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) In 1979 the National Health and Medical Research Council and CSIRO prepared and distributed widely a 'Code of Practice for the Care and Use of Animals in Research in Australia' to promote humane behaviour towards experimental animals. Copies of this publication are available from the Australian Government Publishing Service (ISBN 006204640).
(2) This Code of Practice is an adjunct to Commonwealth and State legislation. It is widely used by research laboratories as a guide to good practice.
(3) No. The Code is a guideline, not a law.
Department of Veterans' Affairs: Medical Arrangements
(Question No. 2497)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:
(1) Is there dissatisfaction within the Victorian section of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, in particular, with the medical arrangements.
(2) If so, has the Minister examined the reasons for these complaints which have been detailed by the RSL State President, Mr Bruce Ruxton.
(3) Is there any substance to the complaints: is so, what action has been taken to eliminate the causes for complaint.
Mr Thomson-The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) I am not aware of any general dissatisfaction within the medical arrangements in the Victorian Branch of my Department. However, there has been criticisms of some individual medical opinions given by Department Medical Officers by the Victorian State Executive of the Returned Services League of Australia.
(2) Yes.
(3) The criticisms are based on a very few selected cases and any general criticism on this basis appear to be unwarranted. Departmental Medical Officers should not be judged only on a very few complaints amongst more than 30,000 claims and appeals handled each year. On the rare occasion where a complaint is found to be justified the medical officer concerned has been counselled; however in other cases no justification can be found for the complaints.
War Graves
Mr Thomson-On 28 May 1981 (Hansard, page 2742) Mr Donald Cameron asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, without notice:
Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs been drawn to reports that the Maltese Government is considering bulldozing a war cemetery for the purpose of constructing a housing estate? Is the Minister aware that that cemetery contains the remains of several Australian servicemen? Will the Minister give consideration to an Australian Arlington? Will the Minister cause a costing to be

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3511

done to ascertain how much money would be needed to transfer home the remains of all of Australia's sons and daughters in war cemeteries overseas? In the interim, will the Minister protest to the Maltese Government about this possible desecration?
The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
I am aware of the recent reports in the media that the Maltese Government wants to bulldoze the graves of Commonwealth war dead in Malta. The reports are incorrect.
The Commonwealth War Graves Commission in England, of which Australia and other Commonwealth countries are corporate members, is responsible for the Commonwealth war graves throughout the world, including those in Malta. There are also war graves of nine foreign countries and some 5,000 non-war British burials in the Malta cemeteries.
In 1979, the Maltese Government asked the British to remove the remains of the 7,303 buried in the Capuccini, Pembroke and Pieta cemeteries, and concentrate them in the Mtarfa cemetery where there are 1,440 graves. 200 Australian graves are involved. Considerable extra land would need to be provided at Mtarfa I\nd the cost would run into some millions of dollars.
Australia and the other Commonwealth countries are opposed to the proposed move of the graves except if it can be shown (and it has not so far been done by the Maltese Government) that there was such an overriding and urgent public need for the land to be used for other essential purposes as to justify disturbance of the graves. Australia has been kept fully informed on the negotiations which have been going on with the Maltese Government since the original request was made in 1979. The Commonwealth War Graves Commission has received many requests from relatives to transfer the remains of war dead to their home country. However, the Commission's policy, which was established after the First World War and reaffirmed after the Second World War, is that the graves should not be disturbed except on the grounds of overriding public interest. Agreements have been negotiated with many Foreign Governments on these lines. The Commission is bound to adhere to this policy which was laid down by its Participating Governments, including Australia.
A detailed costing of the transfer of the war graves of all Australian veterans back to Australia and the establishment of a National Cemetery for this purpose, would not be practicalor productive in view of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission's policy. There are Australian war graves in over 2,500 cemeteries throughout the World and it is possible that a very large proportion of the relatives of the war dead would strongly object to the disturbance of the remains. All Australian war dead are commemorated in the Australian War Memorial in Canberra. The Australian Government has also established and maintains Gardens of Remembrance in most of the capital cities for the commemoration of those veterans whose deaths were war-related and who are not officially commemorated in civil cemeteries.
Superannuation: Tax Deductibility
(Question No. 400)
Dr Everingham asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

superannuation provisions and advising that from discussions with the Taxation Office it seemed that the new amendment would exclude ,employees drawing a retiring allowance of up to a year's salary or a limited pension in place of superannuation.
(2) If so, will he clarify who is and who is not entitled to tax deductibility and remove any anomalies.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) Under section 82AAT of the Income Tax Assessment Act a person may be allowed a deduction, up to a limit of $1,200 in an income year, for contributions made in the year to a superannuation fund approved by the Commissioner of Taxation under paragraph 23 (ja) or section 79 of the Act. The deduction is not available where, in relation to the person's service in that year, it could resonably be expected that superannuation benefits would be provided on his or her retirement (or for his or her dependants in the event of death) under an employer-sponsored superannuation fund or statutory superannuation scheme referred to in the legislation.
It is not clear from the form letter referred to whether, and to what extent, the persons referred to would be eligible for the deduction, but the Commissioner of Taxation would provide advice to persons concerned once the relevant facts were placed before him.
Minister for Administrative Services: Staff
(Question No. 442)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:
(I) How many persons are employed on each ministerial staff.
(2) What are the Public Service classifications and salary levels of these persons and what other emoluments (both fiscal and otherwise) are provided to them.
(3) Will he provide similar details in relation to staff employed in each Minister's office in each of the preceding five years.
Mr Newman-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) and (2) The details sought by the honourable member are contained in Tables A and B which have been prepared by my Department.
(3) Compilation of the information requested would require commitment of considerable staff resources which I am not prepared to authorise. However, the current Ministerial staff establishment totals 190 compared to 242 for the previous Government. The following table provides a breakdown of these aggregate figures.

Primary Industry Bank
(Question No. 575)
Mr Les Johnson asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:
(1) What sums have been lent by the Primary Industry Bank to (a) primary producers and (b) others in each of the last 5 years.

$m

Farming and grazing Fishing Other

213.8 3.7
45.4

Total

262.9

Loan approvals made to these groups in each of the years 1979 and 1980 were:

(2) What sums have been allocated or are to be made available to the Primary Industry Bank for allocation to primary producers in each of the next two years.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(l) The Primary Industry Bank of Australia Ltd was established in July 1978 and began providing refinance loan funds to banks and other lenders for on-lending to individual primary producers (including fishermen and foresters) in November 1978. As at 14 January 1981 (the latest date for which such information is available) PIBA retlnance loans outstanding, classified by broad industry group, were as follows:

1979 1980

Fishing Other

108.6 96.0

Total

126.6 11004

(2) Over the next two financial years the greater proportion of PIBA's funding requirements is expected to be raised by public borrowings (as has been the case in the past). To date,
funds totalling $101m, repayable over eight years, have been deposited with PIBA from the Income Equalisaton Deposits Trust Account. (Details of such deposits are provided in
Annual Reports on the operation of Part II of the Primary Industry Bank Act 1977 which arc tabled in the Parliament.) The Government has undertaken to continue its support for
PIBA by the provision of a three year funding commitment
for the bank's operations. This commitment will cover the

3514 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

three financial years beginning 1981-82 and discussions between PIBA and the Commonwealth on the means for giving effect to the commitment are now taking place.
Australian Participation in Resource Projects
(Question No. 600)
Mr Jacobi asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:
(1) Is it a fact that 10 out of the top 14 shareholders of Western Mining Corporation represent holders of 29 per cent of its issued capital and that four out of the top 10 shareholders of Mount Isa Mines representing holders of 11.1 per cent of its non-Asarco-owned issued capital are nominee companies.
(2) Is it also a fact that given the recent inflows of portfolio ~nd investment capital, these holdings, and similar holdings 10, for example, Conzinc Rio Tinto Australia and Pan Continental, means that the Australian participation in existing or proposed resource projects has fallen below the specific guidelines for Australian participation in the natural resource sector.
(3) Will he take up with the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs the question of amendments to the Companies BIll 1980 to require nominee companies to disclose the proportion of their shares registered under names which are held on behalf of a non-resident; if not, how does he propose to ensure that the existing foreign investment guidelines are enforced.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Data released by the Stock Exchange indicate that as at 29 September 1980 10 of the largest 14 shareholders in Western Mining Corporation Holdings Limited were nominee companies and that these companies held 28.9 per cent of the issued capital of WMC. Stock Exchange data also indicate that as at 5 September 1980 four of the top 10 shareholders in MIM Holdings Limited were nominee companies and that these companies held 11.1 per cent of the issued capital of MIM (excluding that held by ASARCO Incorporated).
(2) and (3) In cases where the shareholdings of nominee companies could be of significance in relation to the requirements of foreign investment policy, companies concerned have been asked to ascertain whether the beneficial ownership of the shares they hold in the company is Australian or foreign. Companies have provided such information on request. Section 36 of the Foreign Takeovers Act provides legislative power for information relevant to foreign takeover matters to be sought as necessary but experience to date has been that it has not been necessary to take action in pursuance of that Section. With regard to the provisions of the Companies Bill 1981, Section 261 provides companies with the power to obtain information as to the beneficial ownership of their shares.
Commemorative Gold Coin
(Question No. 667)
Mrs Darling asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 March 1981:
(I) When was the decision made to mint the commemorative koala gold coin.
(2) Was the original estimate of demand for the coin approximately 30,000 and the actual demand for the coin approximately 100,000.
(3) What restrictions were placed by the Royal Australian Mint on the total number of coins to be produced.

(4) Was there a closing date for orders for the coin.

(5) How many coins had been sent as at 1 January 1981.

(6) Who was contracted to deliver the coins.

K(7)~ Wew re ar~ rangements

for

delivery

of

the

coins

cancelled' '

(8) Was Interstate Parcel Express Company (IPEC) contracted to deliver the coins; if so, when.

(9) Was there a contract in writing between IPEC and the Royal Australian Mint for delivery of the coins,

(10) When did IPEC take delivery of the coins and on what dates and in what quantities were the coins despatched by
IPEC.

(11) Is it a fact that periods of more than one week elapsed between the time the coins were received by IPEC from the Mint and the time IPEC despatched them. .

(12) Is it also a fact that on at least one occasion IPEC received a large number of coins for despatch, but did not de~
spatch them and, in due course, returned them to the Mint; if so, (a) what period of time elapsed before IPEC returned the coins and (b) did IPEC offer as a reason for returning the coins that they were experiencing security problems.

(13) When was (a) the Controller of the Mint and (b) he informed (i) of the break-in at fPEC's Melbourne depot and the theft of approximately 40 gold coins and (ii) the loss of ap-
proximately 30 gold coins in a consignment despatched on 25 November 1980 for delivery to Brisbane (lPEC Docket No.
118/775).

(14) Was a telephone call by my office to (a) the office of the Controller of the Mint and (b) to his office on 20 January
1981 the first information either the Controller or he received about the loss of this sccond consignment of 30 gold coins.

(15) When did IPEC inform the Controller of the Mint of the loss of the coins.

(16) Did JPEC inform the Queensland Police or Australian Federal Police of the loss of the second consignment of coins;
If so, when.

(17) Are the New South Wales Police, Queensland Police and Australian Federal Police now investigating the loss of the second consignment; if so, what is the result of their
investigations.

(18) Did his office receive a request from me for him to re-
lease a statement to the media (a) confirming the loss of that consignment, (b) explaining the administrative problems wbich has caused extensive delays to the despatch of coins to those who had ordered them and (c) assuring people who had
already paid for coins as early as September 1980 that they would receive their coins although further delays could be
expected.

(19) Did he issue a statement, in view of the concern of many persons who had ordered the coins but had not received them at that stage; if not, why not.
(20) Is he now able to say whether the coins lost in IPEC consignments will be replaced.

(21) Have those persons whose coins are among those now missing been informed of that fact by the Mint.

(22) With whom are the coins insured and what was the
value of the coins on current market prices as at (a) 1 January 1981 and (b) 25 February 1981.

(23) What is the total current market price of all the missing gold coins.

(24) Has the Mint replied to written inquiries concerning delays in despatching the coins; if so, to how many.

Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3515

(1) The decision to mint the commemorative koala coin was announced on 10July 1979.

(2) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that the
planning estimate for gold proof coins was 30,000 and actual demand was approximately 120,000.

(3) The numher of gold proof coins produced was effectively limited by the Mint's capacity to produce coins of that type bearing in mind the overall production program. No restriction was placed on the production of the uncirculated
coin.

(4) The closing date for gold proof coins was 19 September 1980 and for gold uncirculated coins 12 December 1980.

(5) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that at 1
January 1981 39,192 gold proof coins and 195,247 gold uncirculated coins had been despatched from the Mint.

(6) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that {PEC Pty Ltd and Wards Express were contracted to deliver the gold coins.

(7) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that arrangements to deliver the coins were not cancelled but IPEC
withdrew from the contract stating that the delivery of gold coins was not compatible with IPEC's normal business. Wards
Express continued to deliver go\d coins.

(8) and (9) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that a contract in writing for IPEC to deliver gold coins was signed on 16 October 1980.

(10) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that IPEC
took the first delivery of gold coins on 21 October 1980 and continued on a regular basis until the last delivery was taken on 17 December 1980. During this period IPEC received from the Mint 22,238 gold proof coins and 9,067 uncirculated gold
coins.

(ll) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that there were delays of over one week between IPEC's receipt and delivery of some coin consignments.

(12) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that IPEC returned 6,172 coin consignments to the Mint, 72 because
IPEC could not complete delivery and 6,100 when the company withdrew from the contract.

(I) All these consignments were returned on or before 23 December 1980. These consignments were 'accumulated over approximately one month.

(b) The reason given by IPEC forreturning the 6,100 consignments referred to above is provided in (7) above.

(13) (a) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that:

(i) he was informed of the break-in to IPEC's Melbourne depot orally in early November and this was confirmed in writing on 8 December 1980 in a letter from ITLC (IPEC's insurance company), and

(ii) advice on the Brisbane coin loss was received on 20

January 1981.

'

(b) I was informed (i) of the break-in to IPEC's Melbourne depot on 24 December 1980, and (ii) of the Brisbane
coin loss on 22 January 1981.

(14) The Controller of the Mint has advised (a) Yes; and (b) Yes.

(15) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that IPEC informed him of the Brisbane loss on 21 January 1981.

, (16) The Controller of the Mint has been advised by IPEC that they reported the Brisbane loss to the Queensland Police on 16 December 1980.

(17) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that the Queensland, New South Wales and Victorian Police are

actively engaged in investigating both the Brisbane and Melbourne gold coin losses and at this stage the results of these investigations are confidential to the police forces and IPEe. The involvement of the Australian Federal Police is limited to making enquiries in Canberra on behalf of State police forces.
(18) Yes (to all parts).
(19) A statement was not issued as the people whose coins had been confirmed as stolen were to be contacted directly by the Royal Australian Mint.
(20) I have instructed the Mint to issue replacement coins to substantiated claims involving missing consignments.
(21) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that all clients whose coins have been reported by (PEC as missing have been informed, in writing, that their coins will be replaced.
(22) It was a condition of the contracts with the carriers that appropriate insurance arrangements be made by them. The particular insurers concerned arc a matter between the carriers and those insurers. The market price for the gold coins varies greatly but a guideline price from the larger coin dealers would be in the vicinity of $600 for the proof coin and about $250 for the uncirculated coin. Those prices apply to both dates.
(23) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that the total current market value for all the gold coins reported as missing is approximately $52,000.
(24) The Controller of the Mint has advised me that all written enquiries to the Mint about delays in despatch of gold coins will be answered. At this stage approximately 7,000 replies have been made.
Adelaide Airport
(Question No. 733)
Mr Scott asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 10 March 1981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to reports in certain sections of the Adelaide press that the Adelaide Airport could soon be handed over to the South Australian Government.
(2) If so, is there any substance in the reports.
(3) Does he propose to take any action on this matter, if so, what.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) There is no substance in the reports with regard to Adelaide Airport in particular other than to observe that the Government is continually reviewing its functions to ensure that there is no unnecessary intrusion into areas more appropriate for administration and control by others including the private sector, State and Local Governments.
The Commonwealth's commitment to ensure an efficient and effective national air transport system, its obligations with regard to international agreements relating to civil aViation, and the need to regulate standards to ensure safety, together with the sheer magnitude of the task of operating a capital city trunk route airport, make it unlikely that ownership and control would be passed to a body other than a State Government, City Council or a State Statutory Body.
(3) No action to transfer any State Capital City Airport is currently in hand and certainly would not be contemplated without fullest consultation with relevant State Governments,

3516 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

Adelaide Airport
(Question No. 734)
Mr Scott asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 10 March 1981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to the concern being expressed by residents of Adelaide, South Australia, over the continuous and persistent noise of aircraft utilising Adelaide Airport; if so, (a) will he establish permanent noise monitoring facilities at a suitable location adjacent to or near the end of runways 05 and 23 at Adelaide Airport and (b) make periodical reports of these facilities.
(2) If he will not undertake to do so, what is the reason.
(3) Has his attention been drawn to the number of public meetings held by residents living adjacent to Adelaide Airport who have consistently supported the proposal that an immediate start be made to the establishment of an alternative airport at a more suitable site north of Adelaide, thereby ena~ling more efficient operation of airlines and obviating inconvenience to residents in the area.
(4) Has he a proposal to establish an airport north of Adelaide; if so, what are the details.
(5) Has he had discussions with tlie Government of South Australia; if so, what was the nature of the discussions.
(6) Will he set up a committee to investigate the siting of an alternative airport to the current Adelaide Airport.
(7) Will he give an assurance that (a) the current curfew will be maintained at Adelaide Airport and will not be broken except in the case of emergency, (b) there will be no extensions of the current airport beyond its existing boundaries and (c) the introduction of quieter aircraft and the implementation of aircraft control for quieter aircraft movement will be expedited.
(8) Is action proposed to subsidise overseas travellers for the ,:ost of inter-State connecting flights; if so, what are the detalls.
(9) Will he ensure that Defence Service aircraft will not be permitted to use the Adelaide Airport unless there is some urgent reason which makes use essential.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.
(a) and (b) No.
(2) The information that would be obtained from a permanent noise monitoring facility at Adelaide Airport would not justify the cost of an installation, particularly since the noise levels of aircraft operating in Australia are known.
(3) Yes. 1 understand that there are a number of residents' groups from areas under the flight paths associated with Adelaide Airport who are pressing for its relocation.
(4) No.
(5) and (6) In December 19801 met with the South Australian Minister of Transport. Among other things we agreed to set up a South Australian Airfields Committee comprising both Commonwealth and State officials. The task of this Committee will include oversighting the implementation of agreed recommendations of the Joint Government Advisory Committee on Adelaide's Airline-Airport Requirements. Two important points made by that Committee were:
the Commonwealth and State Governments should adopt policies to retain and develop the existing Adelaide Airport as the primary regular public transport airport for the Adelaide region through to the year 2005

for the longer term aviation needs of the region action should be taken to secure the availability of an alternative major airport site in the Two Wells/Virginia area.
(7) (a) At this time, there are no plans to change the curfew at Adelaide Airport. The existing curfew conditions permit operations by jet aircraft in circumstances other than an emergency; for example, for extreme passenger hardship. It is my intention that this provision continue.
(b) There are currently no proposals to extend the airport beyond its existing boundaries.
(c) It is a requirement that all Australian-registered jet aircraft operating, or expected to operate, at Adelaide Airport meet, or will meet, the noise certification standards of the International Civil Aviation Organisation.
(8) No. Intending international travellers to and from Adelaide may take advantage of Australian-originating 'add-on' fares and 'See-Australia' fares. These fares were introduced in 1979 to extend the benefits travelling to and from non-gateway ports. The Australian-originating 'add-on' fares offer a 30 per cent discount off the normal economy fare for domestic travel in conjunction with advance purchase international air travel. The 'See-Australia' fares are available for travel within Australia in conjunction with international promotional fares such as apex or excursion fares at 30 per cent discount off the normal economy fare.
(9) Operations by Department of Defence aircraft at Adelaide Airport are carried out from time to time in order to ensure the most economic use of resources and to enhance efficiency. It is not proposed to embargo use of Adelaide Airport by military aircraft.
Department of Transport: Television Advertising
(Question No. 946)
Mr Mountford asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:
(1) What sum was spent on television advertising by his Department and instrumentalities under his control in 1979-80.
(2) What proportion of this expenditure was incurred during the months of (a) December 1979 and (b) January 1980.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) No expenditure was incurred by the Department of Transport on television advertising during 1979-80.
The Australian National Line spent $4,182 Trans-Australia Airlines spent $1,447,275, Qantas spent $240,865.
Australian National Railways undertook no television advertising in its own right during 1979-80. However a contribution for advertising was made to Railway of Australia Committee (ROA) , the Melbourne based Secretariat which represents all Government owned rail systems.
Australian National Railways contribution to ROA's 1979-80 Advertising and Publicity Budget was $89,407 of which $27,000 was spent on direct television advertising.
(2) Australian National Line (a) $2,202, (b) Nil, Trans-Australia Airlines (a) $62,649, (b) $104,049, Qantas (a) $9,634, (b) $4,817.
Specific details on ROA expenditure are not available.

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3517

Cost of Epidemiological Study of Vietnam Veterans
(Question No. 993)
Mr Holding asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:
(1) What is the total estimated cost of the Commonwealth Institute of Health epidemiological study of Vietnam veterans, as at 31 March 1981, and what is the period for which this estimate has been made.
(2) Does this estimate represent a ten-fold increase in cost over earlier estimates.
(3) If the estimated cost has increased, what is the reason for the increase.
(4) Has the Commonwealth Institute of Health identified a control group for the epidemiological study, as at 31 March 1981, if so, (a) what is the size of that control group, (b) in what way are the ages and health profiles of the control group comparable to those of the Vietnam veterans and (c) what steps has the Commonwealth Institute of Health taken to ensure that the control group has not been exposed to chemicals, such as those used in Vietnam whether used by civilians or the military, since the end of hostilities and the spraying program in Vietnam.
(5) Is it a fact that his News Release of 22 March 1981, released in Adelaide, was designed to prepare both the general public and Vietnam veterans for the Government's decision to phase out completely the Commonwealth Institute of Health epidemiological study; if so, will this occur and what other steps is the Government taking to examine and determine the claims of both Vietnam veterans and public servants, who served in Vietnam during the war.
(6) What has been the cost to the Government of the Commonwealth Institute of Health epidemiological study to 31 March 1981.
Mr Thomson-The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) The estimated cost of the Commonwealth Institute of Health epidemiological study of the Vietnam veterans for the year 1980-81 is $300,000. The original estimate of the total cost of the study was $2m. The eventual total cost will depend on the methodology adopted as a result of the pilot study now in progress.
(2) and (3) See answer to question (1).
(4) Yes.
(a) 10,600 (approximately).
(b) Age similar to those who served in Vietnam. Health as yet unknown.
(c) Information will be gathered during the course of the study. Appropriate adjustments will be made in analysis if other exposure is detected.
(5) No. It represents an update on the progress of various aspects of problems of Vietnam veterans.
(6) $140,000.
Defence Service Home Loans
(Question No. 1006)
Mr Les McMahon asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

(1) How many persons were on the waiting list for Defence Service Home Loans as at 1March 1981.
(2) What sum was available for Defence Service Home Loans as at 1 March 1981.
(3) What are the terms of repayment of these loans.
Mr Thomson-The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) At 1 March 1981, 2,538 applicants were awaiting settlement of a loan upon the expiration of the waiting period. The loans were due for settlement between March 1981 and December 1981.
(2) New lending is financed mainly from internally generated funds, of which the major element is principal repayments by current borrowers that are received throughout the year. Thus, it is not practicable to nominate a sum available at I March 1981 for loans. The Budget estimate of funds to become available for lending in 1980-81 was $111.5 million.
(3) Loans are normally repayable over a maximum term of 32 years by equal monthly instalments. Interest is charged at the rate of 3.75 per cent per annum on the first $12,000 at 7.25 per cent per annum on amounts between $12,001 and $15,000 and at 10 per cent on the amount of the loan exceeding $15,000. The average interest rate on a maximum loan of $25,000 is approximately 6.9 per cent per annum. The normal monthly instalment on a loan of $25,000 is $160.75.
Fuel Ethanol
(Question No. 1043)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:
(1) How many experimenter's licences for fuel ethanol production have been issued to (a) farmers, (b) other individuals, (c) educational institutions and organisations, (d) other nonprofit organisations, (e) companies and (f) other bodies.
(2) What output is envisaged from each of these producers.
(3) What measures has the Government established to monitor the output of the producers, the safety and success of the operations.
Mr Moore-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) (a) 8, (b) 3, (c) 2,(d) I, (e) 4, (f) O.
(2) Output of fuel ethanol to date has been negligible. It is not envisaged that any experimenter will be in substantial production this year due to long lead-times involved in both equipment and foodstock-crop development.
(3) The Experimenter's licence scheme is jointly administered by the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the Department of National Development and Energy. The Department of Business and Consumer Affairs is responsible for providing the legal basis for the scheme and for ensuring that any ethanol produced is accounted for. The Department of National Development and Energy is monitoring production by means of periodic reports from experimenters, and will be conducting workshops from time to time to enable experimenters to compare notes and assist each other through sharing of experience. That Department has also produced a brochure for experimenters which includes safety matters both in respect of the production of ethanol and of its experimental use in internal combustion engines.

3518 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

Underspending of Estimates: Department of Transport
(Questiou No. 1105)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:
(I) On what basis were the original 1980-81 appropriations made for division (a) 655-Administrative and (b) 685Bureau of Transport Economics.
(2) Has there been an underspending in these divisions by the estimate contained in the Department of Finance Information Paper, 'Statement of savings expected in annual appropriations made by Acts Nos. 141 and 142Appropriation Acts (Nos I and 2) 1980-81', ifso, what are the reasons.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The or;ginal 1980-81 appropriations made for division 655-Administrative and 658-Bureau of Transport Economics were based on agreed estimates which were determined in accordance with the principles outlined by the Treasurer in his reply to Question 1101.
(2) The expected savings referred to in the Department of Finance Information Paper were offered as a result of circumstances given by the Treasurer.
Cost of Abolishing Means Test for Age Pensions
(Question No.nSl)
Dr Klugman asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:
(1 ) What is the estimated cost at current rates of abolishing (a) the means test for age pensions (i) for women aged 60 to 64 years and (ii) for both sexes aged 65 to 69 years, (b) the partial means test for those persons aged 70 years and over and (c) the means test for service pensioners.
(2) Would approximately one-third of these sums be recovered via the taxation clawback.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(l) (a) the additional full year cost at the rates current on 8 April of abolishing the income test on age pensions is estimated to be
(i) some $410m for women aged 60 to 64 years; and (ii) some $390m for men and women aged 65 to 69 years.
(b) the additional full year cost at the rates current on 8 April of abolishing the income testing of pension increases on age pensions for persons aged 70 years and over is estimated to besome$153m.
(c) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has advised that the additional full year cost at the rates current on 8 April of abolishing the income test on current service pensions is estimated to be: $18.1m for those aged 65 to 69 years, $28.7m for those aged 60 to 64 years, $13.lm for those aged 55 to 59 years, and $4.2m for those aged under 55 years.
The additional full year cost of abolishing the income test on pension increases for service pensioners aged 70 years and over is estimated to be $9.7m.
The above figures include the additional cost for male service pensioners and their spouses and also female veterans receiving pensions in their own right. In addition, it is estimated that there are 272,000 surviving veterans (plus 201,300 wives)

who have not yet tested their eligibility for service pension. Of this group, it is estimated that 30,000 have already reached age pension age and are included in I (a). A further 188,000 have not yet reached the qualifying age for service pension. The cost of abolishing the income test in respect of the remainder, who would qualify for service pension, that is 54,000 veterans and 39,960 wives, is estimated at $267.3m in a full year.
These estimates are gross costs, as they make no allowance for the revenue that would be gained from taxation of the payments concerned.
(2) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that the additional income tax that would be payable if the income test were to be abolished in respect of these payments would be almost one-third of the estimated cost.

Recycling of Paper: Department of Business and Consumer Affairs
(Question No. 1590)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 9 Apri11981:
Has any action been taken by his Department to recycle paper; if so, what action.
Mr Moore-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Paper is recycled in the Australian Capital Territory, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia, and Western Australia by contracts between various paper recycling companies and the Department of Administrative Services. No action is taken in Tasmania and the Northern Territory as amounts of paper are too insignificant to warrant contracts from companies. New South Wales officers are mostly in leased premises and office waste is removed by the building contractor.

Tea Services: Department of Employment and Youth Affairs
(Question No. 1607)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(I) How many (a) full time and (b) part time staff are employed on tea making and distribution in (i) the Head Office and (ii) other offices of his Department.
(2) What was the cost of (a) salaries and (b) other charges in the provision of tea services in his Department in 1979-80.
Mr N. A. Brown-The answer to the honourable member's questionis as follows:
(I) (a) (i) Head Office Melbourne-l full time.
(a) (ii) Nil.
(b) (i) Head Office Canberra-I part time.
(b) (ii) Regional Offices-4 part time.
(2) (a) $56,885-including $27,160 paid to Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services (CACS) Ltd. This service is used in offices where cafeterias are located in the same building as the Department.
(b) Other charges are not separately identified in the Department's accounting records.

Transport Australia Calendar

(Question No. 1684)

Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

(1) What was the cost of the Transport Australia calendar

for 1981.

'

(2) How many copies were produced and to whom were they given.

(3) What benefit is anticipated to Transport Australia by production and distribution of the calendar.

Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) $6,623.

(2) (a) 10,000.

(b) (i) One thousand five hundred to each Regional Director of the Department for distribution outside the Department to industry, State Government Departments and

instrumentalities, service organisations, aero and boat clubs, media, etc. It was not meant for internal office use, apart from those areas which are visited by members of the public or industry. There are five regions viz. New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia/Northern Territory, Victoria/ Tasmania, Western Australia.
(ii) One thousand to the Divisions of the Department, to cover areas not covered in (b) (i) above.
(iii) One thousand two hundred copies sent to specific addresses, who have close ties with the Department of an official nature. Areas covered included all modes of transport, air, land and sea. Recipients of the calendar commented favourably on the purpose and content of the calendar.
(3) The aim of the calendar was to place before industry and outside agencies the wide range of activities of the Department, especially Commonwealth contributions to safety in all modes.

Telephone Calls by Staff: Department of Business and Consumer Affairs
(Question No. 1887)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 9 Apri11981:

3520 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

(1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in the West Australian of 18 July 1979, page 37, that London metropolitan police reduced its telephone bill by $985,000, or about 20 per cent by use of a monitoring device which recorded length, time and destination.of telephone calls and the extension from which the call was made.
(2) Are personal telephone calls, particularly trunk and STD calls, made by staff of his Department controlled; if so, in what way.
(3) Has any consideration been given to the introduction of monitoring devices for telephone calls in his Department; if so, what was the outcome of the consideration.
Mr Moore-The answer -to 'the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2) Yes. In State offices (other than Western"'Australia) all extensions except those of senior officers are barred to STD. In the Fremantle office, technical difficulties prevent the barring of extensions toSTD, whilst in Perth SUbscription to the PABX rests with Department of Veterans' Affairs which has been advised that there are no objections to total barring.
In Central Office very few extensions are barred to STD. Personal trunk calls are required to be booked through the departmental switchboard operator. Prior to booking the call the caller must obtain approval from the accountant. The switchboard operator will then place the booking through the trunks operator. After thecall, the cost is obtained and a voucher forwarded to the accountant who then debits the caller with the cost of the call. See also (3) below.
(3) Yes. The Department of Business and Consumer Affairs in 'Canberra is the subscriber to a multi user telephone exchange. It is arninging the installation of extension metering equipment which, when connected, will allow better monitoring by providing information on an individual departmental user basis. In addition, new telephone technology, sucli as a Stored Programme Control (SPC) PABX, is ~urrently under active consideration by the Department.
Urban Public Transport
(Question No. 1907)
Mr Milton asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(I) Has his attention been drawn to the article which appeared in the Age of Saturday 4 April 1981, in which he was reported as having said that it was doubtful that the $75m allocated as additional funds for developing urban public transport by the Government would be distributed, in view of the need to restrain Commonwealth budgetary outlay.
(2) If so, is there any substance to the report.
(3) If the report is correct, were these additional funds to be allocated as part of the Government's election program.
(4) Is there any substance to the claim that Victoria will now lose $22.5m of the additional funds which could have been used to build more trams and trains.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2), (3) and (4) Following the recent Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Commonwealth has decided to discontinue specific purpose grants to the States for urban public transport after 30 June 1981. At the Premiers' Conference on 4 May 1981, the Commonwealth announced that the States' overall entitlements for 1981-82 under the tax sharing arrangements would include a specific adjustment to take

account of the termination of a number of specific purpose payments, including $50m f9r urban public transport.
Whereas the urban public transport program was due to expire in 1982-83, the $50m incremental adjustment to the 1981-82 tax sharing arrangements now forms part of the base for the calculation of total tax sharing c<ntitiements in future years. The new arrangements allow each State to determine how much will be allocated for urban public transport in light of its own assessment of relative State priorities.
Insurance Industry
(Question No. 1976)
Dr Klugman asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 April 1981 :
(1) Has his attention been drawn to the Australian insurance industry's underwriting loss of $73m in 1978-79 and a prediction by the Federal Insurance Commissioner, Mr Kirkpatrick, of a loss exceeding $1 OOm in 1979-80.
(2) What were the non-underwriting profits of the industry during those years.
(3) Is he concerned about the industry's ability to meet its commitments.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The underwriting loss of $73m referred to by the honourable member was incurred by private sector direct underwriters for the calendar year 1979. The underwriting loss for the year 1978-79 was approximately $38m. I am aware of the comment made by the Insurance Commissioner that a predicted $100m underwriting loss for the year ended 30 June 1980 was conservative. Actual figures now available for this period show that private sector direct underwriters incurred underWriting losses totalling approximately $151m.
(2) For the 1978-79 and 1979-80 financial years nonunderwriting profits for private sector direct underwriters were approximately $254m and $316m respectively.
(3) It is well known that a very competitive situation has existed in the industry for some time, with resulting pressure on underwriting results, and the industry is having to cope with other factors adversely affecting these results. However I am aware of no reason to suggest that the industry does not have the overall financial strength to meet its obligations. It might be noted that, on the basis of data compiled by the Insurance Commissioner, in the two years 1978-79 and 1979-80 net profit from the insurance business of private sector direct underwriters totalled $317m. I would also draw the honourable member's attention to pages 18 and 19 of the Insurance Commissioner's Annual Report for 1979-80 which indicate that in recent years up to 1978-79 (the latest year for which this information is available) there has been continued overall improvement in the assessed solvency margins of direct underwriters in the private sector.
Import Duty on Spare Parts
(Question No. 2011)
Mr Milton asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 30 April 198J :
(1) Is it a fact that import duty on spare parts is making the cost of repairing many machines an uneconomical practice.
(2) Is the gear-box assembly of a Robin Brush Cutter subjected to full import duty whereas the machine itself has little or no duty placed on it; if so, what is the reason for this.
Mr Moore-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3521

(I) In the absence of detailed descriptions of the machines and specific parts to which the question refers, it is not possible to answer this question.
(2) Based on information available to the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, a Robin Brush Cutter, imported as a complete entity, would be classified within item 84.49 of the Customs Tariff, and would be dutiable at 2 per cent. However, a gear-box for the cutter, if imported separately, would be classified within item 84.63.69 and would be subject to duty at rates ranging from 7.5 per cent to 25 per cent depending on the country of origin of the gear-box.
Entry of a gear-box at a concessional rate of 2 per cent may be appropriate under the Customs By-law system. This would need to be discussed with the By-law Branch of the Department of Business and Consumer AITairs.
Rural Loans to Fishermen
(Question No. 2027)
Mr Humphreys asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:
(1) What was the (a) number and (b) total sums of rural loan approvals to fishermen which were refinanced by the Primary Industry Bank in 1980.
(2) Did he state in December 1980 that increases in bank overdraft interest rates would not apply in drought areas; if so, will fishermen be exempted from the recent increases.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The Primary Industry Bank of Australia has advised that it approved refinance loans in 'respect of 17 endborrowcrs in the fishing industry during calendar year 1980 to a total value of $1.6m.
(2) The facts of the understanding reached with the banks in December 1980 in relation to bank interest rates in drought-declared areas are:
rises in interest rates following the raising of the official ceiling on small bank advances effective from 3 December 1980 will not apply to those adversely affected by drought in drought-declared areas for the duration of the drought;
those affected in drought areas may include people other than primary producers;
the interest rate concession will be administered by banks on a case-by-case basis on application by individual borrowers to the respective banks;
the arrangements will apply to interest rates on both new and existing loans.
Company Takeovers
(Question No. 2035)
Mr Hurford asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 5 May 1981 :
(l) Further to his answer to part (4) of my question No. 725 (Hansard, 29 April 1981, page 1775) what reasons did the Trade Practices Commission give for threatening to take proceedings for a contravention of section 50 of the Trade Practices Act in respect of the attempted takeover of the Herald and Weekly Times Group by News Limited.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to statements issued at the time of the attempted takeover referred to in part (1) on behalf of the News Limited group making it clear that the group was not dropping its takeover bid because of proposed action by the Trade Practices Commission and that the group did not

consider itself to be in breach of section 50 of the Trade PracticesAct.
(3) How would the present set of merger criteria detailed in the Act have prevented News Limited from taking over the State operations, includingVictoria, of the Herald and Weekly Times Group where the takeover of that State operation would not give News Limited control or dominance in that market or increase News Limited's control or dominance in that market.
(4) Is he able to say whether it is because of the inability of the post-1977 provisions of the Trade Practices Act to regulate the type of control referred to in part (3), that the Victorian State Government set up its current inquiry into that State's newspaper industry.
Mr Moore-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(l) In a media release dated 30 November 1979 the Trade Practices Commission stated it had been prepared to take proceedings against News Limited because its proposal to acquire marginally more than 50 per cent of the shares in Herald and Weekly Times Limited would have given it control of that company and consequently one-company dominance in a number of markets.
(2) I am not aware of statements of the kind referred to in the question and a search by my Department of the press clippings it has relating to the attempted takeover did not, I understand, reveal reference to such statements in the press reports. I am informed, however, that News Limited ,issued a statement on 22 November 1979 which said, in part "Mr Rupert Murdoch, chief executive of the News group of companies, today announced that in view of e'vents in the last 48 hours, including the unwarranted intervention of the Trade Practices Commission, the News group at this time does not intend to make an offer to all the ordinary shareholders of Herald and Weekly Times Ltd to acquire marginally in excess of 50 per cent of the issued ordinary capital of that company.".
(3) See my answer to (1).
(4) I am unable to comment on the reasons of the Victorifln State Government in deciding to set up the inquiry referred to, other than to note that the Victorian 'Premier was reported as saying, at the time the inquiry was announced, that the inquiry had not been prompted by the News Limited/Herald and Weekly Times takeover bid.

Perth Airport
(Question No. 1069)
Mr Beazley asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
(I) Has a leaflet entitled 'Perth Airport Western Australia' been distributed by his Department in association with its invitation for public comment on proposed changes to Perth Airport, Western Australia.
(2) If so, is there a claim on page 2 of the leaflet that the Joint Governments' Advisory Committee recommended that Perth Airport be retained and further developed as the sole primary airport for the Perth region.
(3) Did the whole recommendation of the Joint Committee deal with the period 1975-2004 and in fact recommend that Perth Airport be retained and further developed as the sole

primary airport for the Perth region and that the Perth Airport master plan be published as soon as practicable and that the master plan should be based on a detailed analysis of airport development options and their impact on the environment and land use.
(4) [f so, why was the whole recommendation and the specified time period not put before the general public.
(5) Does the Joint Government Committee's report qualify the statement "further developed" in its recommendation by reference to a master plan that has not yet been published.
(6) If so, why is the Government proceeding with a major development in advance of production of a master plan.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I), (2) and (3) Yes.
(4) The leaflet was published to inform the public of development proposals at Perth Airport and seek comments, particularly on environmental issues. Extracts of the Joint Government Committee recommendation relevant to this purpose were included in the pamphlet. The public has previously been informed of the recommendations of the Committee in a press release in August 1979 and its 'Report on the Aviation Requirements for the Perth Region' which has been made available to the public through the Australian Government Publishing Service.
(5) Not directly. However, it is appreciated that forward planning must precede major development whenever possible, and planning studies are being undertaken in order to determine appropriate sites for development projects on Perth Airport.
(6) The new international terminal project is still in the early planning stages and work cannot commence until the project first receives specific Government approval and then Parliamentary approval after examination by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works (PWC). A master plan document for Perth Airport, will be produced prior to the PWC hearing. It is not anticipated that the findings of the master plan will necessitate a reversal of the decision on the location of the new international terminal complex.
Bendigo Ordnance Factory
(Question No. 2075)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
On what grounds other than opposition to national enterprises has the Government decided to sell the Bendigo Ordnance Factory to private enterprise.
Sir Phillip Lynch-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The Government's decision to offer the factory for sale was based on its views that Government should not be involved in activities which are capable of being performed by the private sector and that greater reliance should be placed on private industry for production of stores for the armed Services.

(Question No. 2076)

Will the Government consider revising and reversing the decisions announced to date in respect of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory.
