No.
Bendigo Ordnance Factory
(Question No. 2077)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
(1) At what minimum price does the Government intend to sell the Bendigo Ordnance Factory.
(2) Will the sale be effected by private treaty or public tender.
Sir Phillip Lynch-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(l) and (2) The Government has sought expressions of interest from the private sector and it is expected that at a later stage suitable registrants will be invited to submit formal tenders. The Department of Administrative Services which is the Disposal Authority for the Commonwealth proposes to obtain a valuation by an independent firm of valuers for use as a basis for consideration of offers.
Bendigo Ordnance Factory
(Question No. 2079)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
(1) Have any negotiations been held or has the Government received any approaches from any private firm in any

form during 1981 to purchase the Bendigo Ordnance Factory; if so, what are the details.
(2) Has the Government made any approaches to any firms during 1981 to buy the Factory; if so, what are the details.
Sir Phillip Lynch-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) There have been no negotiations but several firms have made exploratory inquiries which have revealed a promising degree of interest in the Factory. Their inquiries are treated as confidential.
(2) No firms have been directly approached but expressions of interest have been invited from the private sector, through newspaper advertisements.

Bendigo Ordnance Factory
(Question No. 2081)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
Did the Government request an assessment from the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Victorian Minister for State Development, or other related bodies of the effects that selling the Bendigo Ordnance Factory would have on the workforce at the factory and on the economy of Bendigo, prior to making the decision to sell.
Sir Phillip Lyncb-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
At this stage there have been no requests made for assessments from such bodies as referred to by the honourable member. If at a later stage of consideration of the question of

the future of the Factory assessments are considered relevant, they will be sought. It could be expected that a private sector owner could use the Bendigo facilities to greatly expand activity in support of large scale industrial and minerals developments, as well as continue to engage in defence work, and thereby provide continuing employment opportunities in Bendigo.
Bendigo Ordinance Factory
(Question No. 2082)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
(1) What sections of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory's work are to be transferred to Maribyrnong, Victoria, on what date, and how many employees are to be affected by the transfers.

3524 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

(2) Was the honourable member for Bendigo consulted in advance; if so, at what stage, and how was the member notified or consulted about moves by the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions in respect to the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo.
(3) Did the honourable member for Bendigo indicate any opposition to the proposal at any stage prior to the announcement in the House by the Prime Minister that the Factory would be sold; if so, in what form.
Sir Phillip Lynch-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) No decisions have yet been taken on what, if any, sections of the Factory's work may be transferred to Maribyrnang, or when they might be transferred. This will depend on assessments of Defence requirements now being undertaken and may also be influenced by the outcome of the Government's enquiries regarding the interest of the private sector in undertaking certain classes of work at Bendigo.
(2) and (3) The honourable member for Bendigo was given written notice of the decision to offer the Ordnance Factory Bendigo for sale as a going concern, shortly before the announcement in the House by the Prime Minister. Tdo not propose to make public details of my discussions with members of parliament or other persons concerning matters under consideration by the Government.

Issue of Plants to Homeowners, Australian Capital Territory
(Question No. 2105)

to homeowners in the Australian Capital Territory (Hansard

30 April 1981, page 1842) mean that the Government has

abandoned the garden city concept for Canberra; if so, what

alternative theme will be used in promotional publicity for the

national capital.

.

(2) Is he able to provide a list of all private landscaping contractors in the Australian Capital Territory and their professional qualifications.

Mr Hodgman-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

keep such a list. The Yellow Pages of the Canberra District Telephone Directory provide a comprehensive list of landscape contractors.

There are quite a number of contractors in the Australian Capital Territory with varying degrees of qualifications and the number of these varies from year to year.

(3) Landscape development of public areas in Canberra is undertaken by the National Capital Development Com-
mission. The high standards which have been achieved are due to a number of factors, which include: established design and specification guidelines; Landscape Architects engaged by the
Commission to prepare landscape designs; construction of landscape projects being closely supervised by Landscape Architects. Another factor is the level of expertise which has de-
veloped in the local landscape construction industry in recent years.

Reduction ofStaff and Functions: Department of Social Security
(Question No. 2131)

Redevelopment of Perth Airport
(Question No. 2188)
Mr Beazley asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 7 May 1981 :
(l) Is it a fact that the Commonwealth-State Advisory Committee studying Western Australia's airport requirements considered two basic sets of options for the redevelopment of Perth Airport, on contemplating developments based on existing runway configuration and the other based on a widely spaced north/south runway development.
(2) Is it also a fact that the Committee recommended neither option but concluded that a much more detailed analysis of the airport master planning options and their environmental impact is necessary before a final decision is taken on the master plan for Perth Airport.
(3) Has that analysis been undertaken; if so, what was its result.
(4) If that analysis has not been undertaken, why has the decision been taken to locate the new terminal near the northern corner of the airport precluding a new parallel runway as an effective option.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(J) and (2) Yes.
(3) This analysis is currently being undertaken and will form part of the master plan document for Perth Airport.
(4) The siting of the new terminal will not preclude the construction of a new parallel runway.
Pollution of the Sea by Oil
(Question No. 2204)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:
(I) Did the Assembly of the Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative Organisation in 1971 adopt an amendment to the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution of the Sea by Oil, 1954, aimed at providing special protection for the Great Barrier Reef area by regarding the area as if it were a part of the land.
(2) Has this amendment been ratified by 25 IMCO Members, including Canada, France, New Zealand, The

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3525

Philippines and the USSR in the Pacific, but does it need 42 ratifications for its entry into force,
(3) Have approaches been made by Australia to (a) the United States of America, (b) Japan, (c) the People's Republic of China, (d) other members of ASEAN, (e) other members of the South Pacific Forum or (f) any South American countries to secure at least 42 ratifications; if so, on what occasions and with what responses.
(4) What steps has Australia taken to ratify the amendment.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) The amendment has been ratified by 25 IMCO Members including Canada, France, New Zealand, The Philippines and the USSR as notified by IMCO at 10 March 1981. A total of 44 ratifications are required to bring the amendment into force.
(3) No approaches have been made to other countries with a view to securing at least 44 ratifications. It would be inappropriate for Australia to suggest ratification of the amendment to other countries until it has completed its own processes towards acceptance of the amendments.
(4) The Protection of the Sea (Discharge of Oil from Ships) Act 1981 which received the Royal Assent on 14 April 1981 will enable Australia to ratify the Convention. Those sections of the Act relating to the Great Barrier Reef amendment will be proclaimed when the amendment comes into force.
Drug Detection
(Question No. 2245)
Mr Jull asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:
(I) Are sniffer dogs now used by Customs Officers at all international gateways into Australia for the purpose of drug detection.
(2) If so, for how long have the dogs been used.
(3) What success has been achieved by this process.
(4) Has there been an appreciable increase in the volume of narcotics detected by using these dogs.
Mr MooreThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes. Narcotic drug detector dogs are located at all capital cities with the exception of Hobart. Dogs and handlers from Melbourne are used in Hobart for specific operations until dogs and handlers presently being trained for location at Hobart finish their training.
(2) Dogs were first introduced as follows: SydneySeptember' 1976; Melbourne-September 1978; BrisbaneDecember 1979; Adelaide~December 1979; Perth-March 1980;Darwin-~November 1980.
(3) Dogs have been used in exercises which have resulted in 311 separate seizures of narcotic drugs. These seizures include separate consignments of:
1,000 kg Hashish in Sydney, 10.5 kg Heroin at Sydney International Airport, 30 kg Cannabis Oil in Melbourne, 100.7 kg Marihuana at Sydney International Airport, 90 kg Hashish at Sydney International Airport, 4.5 kg Hashish in Adelaide, 68 grams Cocaine in Perth.

(4) It is not yet possible to detect any appreciable change in the pattern of drug seizures which could be solely attributed to the use of dogs. The Detector Dog Unit is an integral part of the total Customs effort and provides Customs officers with an additional effective method of detecting drugs illegally entering Australia.
Coastal Surveillance
(Question No. 2284)
Mr Morris asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:
(1) What specific circumstance led to the hire of light twinengined aircraft for coastal surveillance from Arnhem Air Charter Pty Ltd at a cost of $6,975.66 referred to on page 76 of Commonwealth of Australia Gazette G 18 of 5 May 1981, reference SUR 15.
(2) What sections of coastline were subject to surveillance and for what periods under the contract.
(3) Who were the unsuccessful tenderers.
(4) Who performed the surveillance duties covered by the contract (a) prior to and (b) since the period covered by the contract.
Mr Hunt-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Cessation of operations by Northern Airlines.
(2) The coastlines of Bathurst/Melville Islands and from Darwin to Millingimbi on 10, 11, 12 and 13 February 1981.
(3) There were no unsuccessful tenderers. At the time Arnhem Air Charter was the only operator in Darwin with suitable aircraft available and holding appropriate operationallicences.
(4) (a) Northern Airlines.
(b) Transecutive Airlines (subcontracting to Northern Airlines) from 14 February to 10 April inclusive, Arnhem Air Charter from 11 April to 14 April inclusive, then Northern Territory Aerial Work Pty Ltd (a wholly owned subsidiary of Ansett Transport Industries) from 15 April to date.

Agent Orange
(Question No. 2303)
Dr Everingham asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veteran's Affairs, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:
(1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the article 'Agent Orange and the Repatriation Commission' at pages 103 to 117 of Debrief, February-April 1981.
(2) If so, does the author allege suppression by the head of the Department of Veterans' Affairs of information, including a report by Dr Fleming relevant to determinations of claims on the Repatriation Commission by veterans in respect of war-caused disability associated with exposure to herbicides.
(3) Will the Minister (a) have tabled in the House documents provided to the Government by herbicide manufacturing interests and (b) direct that all relevant expert opinions in the possession of the Department of Veterans' Affairs be provided to the Commission and Boards in accordance with sections 24AB, 47 and 48 of the Repatriation Act.
(4) Will action be taken against any person who appears, prima facie, to have breached sections 34 (b), 42, 43 or 86 of the Crimes Act in relation to the judicial functions of the Commission; if not, why not.
Mr Thomson-The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) Yes.
(2) An unidentified author alleges in the article that the Permanent Head of the Department of Veterans' Affairs has refused to have evidence of pesticides summarised and placed

on files on pesticide claims, and that as a consequence, medical practitioners have insufficient information to give an informed and balanced opinion on the possibility of disability claims being attributed to pesticide poisoning. The author also alleges that the Department of Veterans' Affairs has refused to release a report said to have been prepared for the Department by Dr Keith Fleming.
The facts are that the Department has been gathering information on the long-term effects of herbicides on human health since well before December 1979 when the herbicides controversy arose in Australia and has been circulating this information throughout the Repatriation system.
The so called 'report' by Dr Fleming is a compilation of extracts from scientific and other articles which were obtained from Mr John Evans of Melbourne, an adviser to the Vietnam Veterans Association, and which, in his opinion, supported the Association's claims. Subsequent independent evaluation of the compilation indicated that the compilation did not present an adequate up-to-date and comprehensive coverage of the scientific literature on the subject.
However, copies of the full texts of the reports and articles quoted by Mr John Evans together with a number of other scientific reports have been distributed to Departmental Medical Officers dealing with claims of health effects from contact with toxic chemicals in Vietnam.
(3) (a) A search has revealed that the Department has received the following papers from what is referred to as herbicide manufacturing interests:
(i) A copy of a paper presented to the United Services Club in Brisbane on 19 March 1980 by the Queensland Manager of Nufarm Chemicals which is entitled 'Do You Want Three Feeds a Day?'
(ii) A copy of a paper presented to the Pesticides Science Group by the Chairman of the South Australian Division of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association of' Australia on 16 March 1981.
(iii) A letter dated 30 April 1980, addressed to my predecessor, the Hon. A. E. Adermann, M.P., from I.e.I. Australia Limited to which was attached a one page summary concerning the toxicology of the herbicides "Gramoxone" and "Reglone".
(iv) A tetter dated 23 February 1981, addressed to me from the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association of Australia to which was attached a booklet entitled 'Public Concerns About 2,4,5-T' by W. R. Mullison, Ph.D.
This material is available and could be tabled if required.
(d) My Department seeks to ensure that all relevant scientific evidence is taken into account by Departmental Medical Officers when giving opinions under the terms of section 48 of the Repatriation Act, by providing them With copies of published articles dealing with the possible toxic effects of herbicides and other toxic chemicals. Repatriation Boards and delegates of the Commission are well aware and have been reminded that all of this material is available to them whenever they think it could be relevant to a particular claim.
(4) No person appears to have breached the various provisions of the Crimes Act referred to.
Sale of Bendigo Ordnance Factory
(Question No. 2356)
MI' Hurford asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 28 May 198 I:
(I) How many apprentices are presently employed hy the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo, Victoria.

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3527

(2) Will the Government ensure that the current level of

apprenticeship 'training at the Ordnance Factory, Bendigo,

will be maintained following -its sale to private enterprise

(Hansard, 30 April1981, page 1846); if so, how will this be

achieved.

'

Sir Phillip Lynch-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) One hundred and four. There are also 21 other apprentices at the factory who are being sponsored by industry and are receiving their basic trade training under the Group OneYear Apprentice-Scheme.
(2) It is the Government's aim to ensure the continued operation of the factory, and the Government is of the view that in the hands of a private owner activity in the factory in support of large scale mineral and industrial developments could be expanded, so providing continuing employment and training opportunities. The Government cannot give a guarantee at.this stage as to the level of apprenticeship training which will be provided as this would be a matter for the owner. Government incentives generally available to industry to train apprenticc;s would of course be available to a private-sector owner.

Legal Assistance for Persons Charged with Criminal Offences
(Question No.7)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon --notice, on 26 November 1980:
(I) Does article 14 of the 1966 International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which Australia signed in December 1972 and ratified in August 1980, guarantee that everyone charged with a criminal offence shall be entitled to have adequate time and facilities for the preparation of his defence and to defend himself through legal assistance of his own choosing.
(2) Has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to the judgment of Justice Murphy in Mcinnis v. The Queen on 19 December 1979 wherein the view was expressed that the laws and practices of Western Australia do not fulfil these guarantees.

(3) Did the Attorney-General, on 5 August 1980, establish within the Attorney-General's Department the Human Rights Bureau, whose functions are, at the Attorney General's request, to inquire into any federal infringements of the Covenant and, at the Attorney-General's direction, to discuss relevant human rights issues with State authorities.
(4) If so, has the Attorney-General (a) requested the Bureau to inquire into federal laws and (b) directed the Bureau to discuss with Western Australia the State laws on legal assistance for persons charged with criminal offences.
Mr Viner-The Attorney-General has provided the following answers to the honourable member's question:
(I) Sub-Article 14(3) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights provides:
'3. In the determination of any criminal charge against him, everyone shall be entitled to the following minimum guarantees, in full equality:
(b) To have adequate time and facilities for the preparation of his defence and to communicate with counsel of his choosing;
(c) To be tried in his presence, and to defend himself in person or through legal assistance of his choosing; to be informed, if he does not have legal assistance, of this right; and to have legal assistance assigned to him, in any case where the interests of justice so require, and without payment by him in any such case if he does not have sufficient means to pay for it . . .'
(2) lam awareofthejudgmentofMr Justice Murphy.
(3) I did, on 5 August 1980, establish the Human Rights Bureau with functions, inter alia, of inquiring into and reporting to me in relation to complaints referred by me to the Bureau whether any act or practice under a law of the Commonwealth or a Territory infringes human rights as defined in the Covenant, and under my direction of continuing discussions with appropriate State authorities about co-operative arrangements and relevant issues in the human rights field.
(4) (a) and (b) No.
Australian Law Reform Commission Reports
(Question No. 20)
Mr Holding asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:
(I) Further to the AttorneycGeneral's answer to Question No. 5321 (Hansard, 21 April 1980, page 2045), will legislative action be taken by the Government on the following Australian Law Reform Commission Reports: (a) Complaints Against the Police (First Report presented 7 August 1975, Supplementary Report presented 9 June 1978), (b) Criminal Investigation (8 November 1979), (c) Insolvency: The RegularPaymentofDebts (4November 1977), (d) Unfair Publication: Defamation and Privacy (29 December 1978), (e) Privacy and the Census (26 September 1979) and (f) Lands Acquisition and Compensation (12 March 1980); if so, when in each case.
(2) If no legislative action is planned, is other action planned in each case; if so, what.
Mr Viner-The Attorney-General has supplied the following answers to the honourable member's question:
(I) The present position in relation to each of the reports listed in the question is as follows:

3528 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

(a) The Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 was assented to on 9 April 1981 but has not yet been proclaimed to Commence.
(b) As I informed the Senate on 5 Maryh 1981 (Senate Hansard, page 354), a further draft of the Criminal Investigation Bill has been prepared having regard to the comments on and criticisms of the Criminal Investigation Bill 1977. That draft Bill is now being considered.
(c) The Department of Business and Consumer Affairs has held discussions on this Report with interested parties. Consideration is now being given to what legislative, or other, action may be appropriate.
(d) This Report is still being considered within the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.
(e) I refer the honourable member to the statement tabled in the Parliament by the Treasurer on 10 September 1980 (House of Representatives Hansard, page 1081). The Census and Statistics Amendment Bill 1981 was introduced into the Parliament on 30 April 1981. The main purpose of this Bill was to amend the Census and Statistics Act 1905 to incorporate those Government decisions on the recommendations made by the Law Reform Commission in its report on 'Privacy and the Census' which require legislative action prior to the conduct of the 1981 Population Census. Legislative action to implement the other Government decisions on the Commission's recommendations requiring such action is still under consideration.
(f) This Report is still under consideration within the Government.
(2) See (1) above.
Interest Rates
(Question No. 262)
Mr Humphreys asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 December 1980:
(1) Do the terms of reference of the Campbell Inquiry into the financial industry include rationalising the mode of expressing interest rates.
(2) Are interest rates currently expressed according to (a) a fiat rate, for simple interest, per annum, (b) a nominal rate per month and (c) an effective rate for compound interest; if so, is there a need for simplifying the mode of expression of interest from the consumer's point of view.
Mr HQward-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Its terms of reference would encompass such a matter if the Inquiry thought it an issue requiring comment.
(2) Such differences can arise between various categories of financial institutions and different types of deposit or loan. From the consumers' point of view there presumably would be advantage in having sufficient information available to enable accurate comparison between different rates of interest.
Legal Aid Commission
(Question No. 323)
Mr Les Johnson asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:
(1) Which of the recommendations contained in the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission Annual Report for 1979-80 has the Government (a) accepted and (h) rejected.

(2) What progress has been achieved in the implementation of the recommendations which were accepted.
Mr Viner The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
With regard to each of the 7 recommendations the position is as follows:
Recommendation No.1- -Statutory Interest on Solicitors' Trust Accounts In so far as the Australian Capital Territory is concerned the recommendation has not been accepted. The recommendation could not be adopted without prior consultation with banks and the Law Society of the Australian Capital Territory. In so far as the recommendation concerns participating States it has been brought to their attention.
Recommendation No.2 --Estimates of ExpenditureThe recommendation as it relates to Commonwealth funding has not been accepted. The recommendation has been brought to the attention of participating States.
Recommendation No.3- --Grants to Voluntary and Community Legal Services -In accordance with the recommendation the Government has established an on-going funding program for these bodies.
Recommendation No.4-Grants for Migrant Legal Education --I brought this recommendation to the attention of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and officers of his Department have had discussions in relation to the matter with officers of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission. With the assistance of these officers the Department has prepared orientation information for newly arrived migrants explaining aspects of the law that are likely to be of concern to them.
Recommendation No.5-Aboriginal Legal AidThe House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, to which this recommendation was made, did not agree that a national secretariat of Ahoriginallegal services should be establishedsee Chapter 17 of the Committee's Report tabled on 27 August 1980.
Recommendation No. 6-- -Provision of Legal Advice-In the Australian Capital Territory the recommendation as it relates to thc availability of legal advice has not been formally accepted by the Legal Aid Commission as the Commission has always acted generally in accordance with the recommendation. The Commission has not accepted the recommendation as it relates to voluntary and community based services as it considers that the only community based service in the Territory duplicates the legal advice services provided by the Commission. In so far as the recommendations concern participating States it has been brought to their attention.
Recommendation No.7-Administrative Review Council-In relation to the Australian Capital Territory similar recommendations to those contained in paragraphs (a), (b) and (e) of the recommendation have been made by the Administrative Review Council-see pages 22 and 23 of The Council's Fourth Annual Report tabled on 18 September 1980. The Government has accepted the recommendations of the Council. In so far as these recommendations concern participating States it has been brought to their attention.
Telephone Facilities for Deaf People
(Question No. 380)
Mr Adermann asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3529

(1) Has his attention been drawn to the special telephone handset available in Australia using a print out enabling totally deaf people to use the telephone.
(2) As the use of the phone necessitates a similar handset at the receiver's end, will he have his Department investigate the possibility of installing at least one receiver in the State Branch of each Commonwealth Department so that the totally deaf might have an access service previously denied to them.
(3) Would this be an appropriate Government initiative for 1981, the International Year of the Disabled Person.
Mr Malcolm Fraser-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(l) Yes. Special telephone handset equipment for the totally deaf called the Porta Printer IT has been available to the public through a private company, Intercept Communications, P:O. Box 297, Camberwell, Victoria 3124, priced in the range $800-$1,000. Telecom Australia permitted its connection to the telephone network and, I am advised, some 80 units have been sold to date.
A recent upsurge of demand for the equipment in the United States of America has exhausted supplies, including items earmarked for Australia. Alternative equipment, the Porta Printer Plus, could be available through Intercept Communications by mid 1981. One of these printers has already been leased by Telecom for evaluation and testing for compatibility with the Porta Printer II. Telecom's intention, as part of its contribution to the International Year of the Disabled Person, is to act as a distributing agent for the unit.
(2) and (3) The Government is concerned to improve the opportunities and access to services of disabled people wherever practicable. Telecom has prepared a booklet, entitled 'International Year of Disabled Persons 1981-Telecom Australia's Program of Activities', which includes information about handsets for the deaf. Several thousand copies have already been distributed, both inside and outside of Telecom, and to relevant Government Departments and Authorities.
The Government currently has under consideration the question of policy on practical steps that Departments should take to assist the disabled. [ will advise the honourable member in due course of the outcome with respect to the provision of receivers in Departments that can be accessed by the totally deaf.
Department of Aboriginal Affairs: Tmnsfer of Functions
(Question No. 581)
Mr Beazley asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:
(l) Is the Government planning to distribute some of the functions of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to any other department or statutory authority.
(2) If so, (a) which functions are to be transferred and (b) to what Department and/or authorities will they be transferred.
(3) When is it intended that the process will be completed.
(4) Has the National Aboriginal Conference been consulted on this matter; if so, what opinion was expressed by it.
Mr Malcolm Fraser-- The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2) Responsibility for Aboriginal housing grants (other than those to the States) is to be transferred to the Aboriginal Development Commission. States Grants for Aboriginal

Housing are to be integrated in the Commonwealth/State Housing Agreement and administered by the Department of Housing and Construction. Funding of the Sacred Sites Protection Authority will be transferred to the Northern Territory Government.
(3) 1 July 1981.
(4) The National Aboriginal Conference was informed of the proposed transfer of Aboriginal housing grants (other than those to the States) to the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Chairman of the Conference indicated last November that his Executive's view was that it would be appropriate for the deadline of 1 July 1981 to be extended to allow the Aboriginal Development Commission more time to consolidate its present functions and to plan future developments. The Minister has informed the NAC that he recognised its concern, and that a joint DAA/ADC Steering Group has been established to ensure that the ADC will have adequate resources to manage the programs to be transferred. This transfer with effect from 1 July 1981 is a firm Government commitment designed to assist Aboriginal people to achieve greater management and determination of their own affairs.

Expenditure on Defence Facilities
(Question No. 635)
Mr Morrison asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:
(1) What was the proportion of defence expenditure spent on defence facilities for each year from 1975-76 to 1979-80 and what is the estimated expenditure for 1980-81.
(2) Did the November 1976 White Paper on Defence propose an increase in defence expenditure on defence facilities from 6.2 per cent in 1975-76 to over 7 per cent in 1980-81.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

3530 REPRESENTATIVES \0 June 1981

Answers to Questions

(1) 1975-766.2 per cent; 1976-77 5.6 per cent; 1977-784.9 per cent; 1978-79 3.6 per cent; 1979-803.2 per cent; 1980-81 3.5 per cent (estimated).
(2) As I have explained to the Parliament on several occasions, the Government's overall economic objectives have required adjustments to the pace of proceeding with the objectives in the 1976 White Paper. Indeed. the 1976 White Paper emphasised that the provisional allocations for Defence Outlay in the period 1976-81 were subject to review and adjustment according to actual timing of project developments. Budget consideration and the circumstances prevailing at the time that major decisions need to be taken. The planning. in the 1976 White Paper. to increase defence expenditure on Defence facilities to over 7 per cent of total Defence expenditure in 1980-81 must be seen in this context.
In addition to the need for general restraint on public expenditure as part of the Government's overall economic strategy. factors sucr as the timing of decisions on facilities for the Australian Defence Force Academy and the New Tactical Fighter and the need to consider the recommendations of the report 'Accommodation for Married Servicemen', by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, inevitably affected previously planned achievements.
Bankcard Interest Rates
(Question No. 8(9)
Mr Humphreys asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 25 March 1981:
(1) Did he say in answer to my question No. 273 (Hansard, 4 March 1981, page 442) that Bankcard interest rates which. are quoted at 18 per cent per annum, are not compounded daily, and that a true rate of interest of 19.7 per cent per annum does not occur.
(2) If so, what interest would Bankcard charge on a deht of $2,000, if the principal sum to be repaid had not been reduced at the end of a 12 month period.
(3) Would this figure be identical to that which would have been the case if Bankcard had quoted an effective rate of interest on 19.7 per cent per annum.
Mr Moore-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) No. In answer to Question No. 273 (Hansard,4March 1981) I stated that I had been advised that Bankcard credit charges are not compounded daily, that is, interest is not charged on interest.
(2) The interest charged by Bankcard depends upon whether the debt is generated by a cash advance or a purchase of merchandise. [ am advised that if a debt of $2,000 is generated by a cash advance on 1 January and is not reduced over the ensuing twelve month period the interest charged for that period would be $358.98 which is an effective rate of 17.95 per cent per annum. If the debt is generated by a purchase of merchandise the interest charged would vary between $331.78 and $359.39. depending on the length of the interest free period; this is an effective rate varying between 16.59 per cent and 17.97 per cent per annum. It should be noted, however. that these examples assume a departure from the condition upon which a Bankcard is issued, that a card holder may make a payment of at least 5 per cent of the amount owing at the end of each settlement period. If this condition were met the amounts of interest quoted above would be reduced accordingly.
(3) No. However I am advised that if the interest charged were to be compounded daily, which as [have indicated is not the case, it would produce an effective rate of 19.7 per cent per annum. Such a compounding would result in an annual

interest charge of $394 compared with the amounts referred to in the answer to the second part of this question. For the sake of completeness let me stress that I am advised that there is no compounding effect of any kind in the computation of Bankcard interest. After an initial credit charge of 1.5 per cent for extending credit on merchandise purchases (which would normally be applied on the second monthly statement in which the balance outstanding in respect of a particular purchase appears) and for cash advances Bankcard interest is computed on reducing principal at daily rests basis. The total interest component (including the 1.5 per cent credit charge referred to above) included in amounts owing is segregated and disregarded for the purpose of interest calculations. I understand that this differs from many methods of computing interest in Australia.
Imported School Work Books
(Question No. 873)
Mr Holding asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 25 March 1981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to an article headed 'Problems with Photocopying' in the Booksellers Fair advertising Impplement in the Age, 23 March 1981, page 2.
(2) Is it a fact, as alleged in that article, that the Government has decided to charge import duty and sales tax on imported school work books.
(3) If so, would this action confiict with the Florence Agreement.
(4) What is the full title of the Florence Agreement, when was it signed and or ratified by Australia, and what is its purpose.
(5) What is the Government's attitude towards the payment of import duty and sales tax on imported school work books.
(6) Has his Department, or any statutory authority under its control, made any investigation of the claim that import duty and sales tax will probably cause the cost of imported school work books to double; if so, is there any substance to this claim.
(7) If an investigation has not been made, will he now cause it to take place.
Mr MooreThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) No. Until recently work books, which are accepted as being combined exercise and text books, were generally classified under Item 48.18 of the Customs Tariff which is the item for exercise books and were dutiable at the rate of 25 per cent.
The 25 per cent duty rate for exercise books was imposed on 28 September 1979 following the Government decision on the report by the Industries Assistance Commission on Paper Products dated 16 May 1979.
Following a legal challenge and subsequent discussion it was agreed that the tariff classification of work books should be modified as follows:
Work books designed essentially for writing in by users in which the printed text comprises a minor and clearly incidental aspect of the book will, as before, continue to fall to Tariff Item 48.18 and be dutiable at 25 per cent.
Work books designed primarily to pose question and answer exercises with provision for answers therein will be classified under Tariff Item 49.01, which is the item for textbooks, and be entered free of duty.

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3531

Work books comprising text material together with question and answer exercises will also continue to be entered under Tariff Item 49.01.
In relation to the question of sales tax the following ruling currently applies:
Books either imported or locally produced, which deal with educational subjects of a kind taught in non-profit schools or universities and which contain sets of questions or problems to be answered or worked out in spaces provided have been ruled exempt from sales tax under Item 51 (I) First Schedule, Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act.
(3) No.
(4) The full title of the Florence Agreement is the UNESCO Agreement on the Importation of Educational Scientific and Cultural Materials. Its primary objective is to encourage the free flow of educational, scientific and cultural materials. Australia has not formally ratified the Florence Agreement; however it has in practice sought to give effect to the spirit of the Agreement's aims and objectives.
(5} See 2 above.
(6) No such investigation has been made.
(7) No. The Government does not make changes in rates of duty on imported goods without first seeking advice from the Industries Assistance Commission. In this case the lAC submitted its report recommending a 25 per cent ad valorem duty, and the recommendation was accepted by the Government.
Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme
(Question No. 888)
Mr Les McMahon asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 25 March 1981.
(I) How many (a) men and (b) women, previously on unemployment benefits, have transferred to Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) benefit during (i) 1978 and (ii) 1979.
(2) How many applications for TEAS benefits from, (a) men and (b) women previously on unemployment benefits, havebeenprocessed,asat I March 1981.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Although applicants for assistance under TEAS are required to indicate whether they have recently claimed, or are currently receiving a benefit, pension or allowance from the Department of Social Security, this information is used purely for the administrative purpose of avoiding dual payments of assistance, and is not compiled in statistical form. Statistics of unemployment beneficiaries transferring to TEAS therefore are not available.
Uranium: Westinghouse Case
(Question No. 921)
Dr Everingham asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:
(I) Has the Government abandoned defence of 3 Australian uranium suppliers in courts in the United States of America.
(2) If so, does this render useless legislation designed to protect Australian interest in such cases.
(3) Have the 3 companies withdrawn their defence because of commercial threats to their future trade by Westinghouse or government authorities or companies subject to

the influence of Westinghouse; if not, to what commercial pressures have the defendant companies yielded.
(4) Do these commercial pressures favour big companies in disputes with Australian companies, leading to more concentration of corporate power than the alleged cartel, on account of which Westinghouse initiated its action.
(5) What will be the prima facie Joss to the Australian companies because of the settlement accepted due to the Westinghouse action.
(6) How much of this Joss will be debited to the Australian Government shareholding in uranium mining, and what would this amount have been if the Australian Government had not sold any of its uranium mining interests.
(7) What is the (a) total value of uranium mining shares in Australia, at current market prices, (b) peak value of these shares and when was this peak reached, (c) net increases in value of (i) capital assets and (ii) ore reserves of the companies at current prices since the peak value was reached and (d) net non-capital income of the companies since their peak value was reached.
Mr Viner-The Attorney-General has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) No.
(2) The operation effect of the Foreign Proceedings (Prohibition of Certain Evidence) Act 1976 and the Foreign Antitrust Judgements (Restriction of Enforcement) Act 1979 remain unchanged by the settlement of the Westinghouse proceedings.
(3) and (4) Each of the companies has issued a press statement indicating its commercial reasons for having entered into settlement agreement with Westinghouse.
(5) The Australian companies have publicly disclosed their individual payments to the settlement.
Those payments were:
CRA Limited-$6,800,000; Pancontinential Mining Limited-$2,600,000; Mary Kathleen Uranium Limited -$870,000; Queensland Mines Limited-$878,000.
(6) The Commonwealth has a 41.6 per cent shareholding in Mary Kathleen Uranium (MKU). The payment made by MKU to Westinghouse will not be debited against particular shareholdings as such but, as with other items of expenditure, it will be reflected in the company's profit and loss account.
(7) The detailed commercial information sought relating to individual companies is not known to me or my Department.

Uranium Advisory Council
(Question No. 1004)
Mr Scott asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 1 April 1981 :
(1) Does the Uranium Advisory Council's Annual Report for 1979-80 state that he has indicated that the Council may expect its advice will be made public in due course, when referring to the Harrisburg Three Mile Island Accident Report.
(2) Has the report been stated to be confidential both by his office and by the Secretary of the Uranium Advisory Council; ifso, why.
(3) Is it his intention to release the report to the public; if so, when; if not, why not.
Mr AnthonyThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2) Release of the report was delayed pending the Government's consideration of the Report prepared by the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council on the research and development activities of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission for which it had implications.
(3) I understand it is the Uranium Advisory Council's intention to publish its advice to the Government on this matter with its 1980-81 Annual Report.
Natural Disaster Insurance Scheme
(Question No. 1049)
Mrs Darling asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 April 1981:
(l) What sum did the Budget estimates provide in total Commonwealth Government assistance to State Governments for disaster relief in 1980-81 and what sum has been expended as at 1 April 1981.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to the fact that Mr Fred Murdoch, Executive Director of Willis, Faber and Dumas, an international insurance company of London, United Kingdom, on a recent stopover in Brisbane, expressed surprise that Australia did not have a natural disaster insurance scheme.
(3) Is he able to say whether Britain, Switzerland and New Zealand each have disaster insurance schemes.
(4) Did the then Treasurer and Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party in 1976 pledge the Government of the day to a natural disaster insurance scheme.
(5) Has his attention been drawn to Mr Murdoch's proposal for a scheme that would include (a) agreement between Government and insurance companies on the upper limits of liability, (b) the establishment of a low premium to allow subscription by low income earners, (c) the pooling of all premiums in a central fund open to annual audit and (d) provision for re-insurance internationally against levels of liability exceeding those anticipated.
(6) Will his Government consider this proposal in view of the frequent disasters suffered in Australia.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) $12,802,000 was provided in the 1980-81 Budget for Commonwealth assistance to the States under the natural disaster relief arrangements. As at April 1981, $37,435,364 had been provided in the form of advances and payments to the States in 1980-81.
(2) I am aware of Press comments along the lines mentioned that have been attributed to Mr Murdoch.
(3) I understand that national schemes or other arrangements exist in those countries for insurance cover to be provided against certain but not necessarily all forms of natural hazard.
(4) In his Press release of 4 March 1976 the then Treasurer announced that the Government had agreed, in principle, to the introduction of a natural disaster insurance scheme, and had approved the establishment of a working party of officials to formulate a detailed scheme in consultation with the insurance industry and, as necessary, with the States. In December 1976 a discussion paper based on the working party's report was tabled in Parliament for the purpose of seeking public comment on a possible natural disaster insurance scheme. Following a detailed assessment of this matter, including comments received from the States, the insurance industry and other interested parties, the Government concluded that a natural disaster insurance scheme of the type outlined in the discussion paper would not be a cost-effective way of assisting in solutions to the problems identified and that a number of practical measures dealing more directly with the problems and involving less Government intervention would be more appropriate. Work on this matter is proceeding. Further background on the Government's decisions in this area is contained in my press release of 17 January 1979 and in a Policy Information Paper which I tabled in Parliament on 4 June 1979.
(5) Yes.
(6) No. Suggestions broadly along these lines were considered in the course of the detailed assessment which preceded the Government's decisions mentioned in (4) above.
Labelling of Cigarettes
(Question No. 1072)
Dr Blewett asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 7 Aprill981:
(1) Are negotiations currently in progress between officers of his Department and the tobacco industry about compulsory labelling on packets, of tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide levels of cigarettes.
(2) Has the tobacco industry's maximum offer been only (a) minimal banding and (b) indicating low, medium or high tar content.
(3) Is his Department prepared to accept this offer as final.
Mr MacKellarThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(J) In accordance with the Government's decision to accept Recommendations 40 and 41 of the Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare: 'Drug Problems in Australia-an Intoxicated Society?', consultations with the tobacco industry are proceeding concerning implementation of plans for the printing of tar and nicotine yields on cigarette packets; the establishment of upper limits for tar a.nd nicotine yields of cigarettes; and the progressive reduction of permitted levels of tar and nicotine in cigarettes.
Although action is presently underway to obtain agreement with industry on a uniform testing methodology for determining the carbon monoxide yields of cigarettes, proposals for implementation action are being developed only in relation to

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3533

tar and nicotine yields, at this stage, in the terms of the Government's decision referred to above.
(2) and (3) Consultations with industry, involving detailed consideration of a number of complex issues, are continuing. Following these consultations, it is envisaged that proposals as regards implementation will be submitted to me for consideration.
Under these circumstances, it is inappropriate for me to comment further.

Tax Avoidance
(Question No. 1197)
Mr Jacobi asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 8 April 1981 :
(1) Is it a fact that on the issue of tax avoidance, whatever amendments are proposed to strengthen sections 136 and 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act the High Court and its interpretation of the taxation laws will be of crucial importance.
(2) Has the Attorney-General's attention been drawn to the recent decision of the House of Lords in W.T. Ramsay Limited v Inland Revenue Commissioner, in which the House of Lords specifIcally rejected the judgment in particular of the former Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia in the Westraders Case.
(3) Is it a fact that the House of Lords were able to arrive at this decision, despite the absence of a blanket provision such as section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.
(4) Will the Attorney-General now consider the enactment of an appropriate amendment to oblige Australian Courts to alter their canons of construction of taxatiorllaws so that such laws are applied in accordance with the intent of Parliament.
(5) Is such an amendment necessary to strengthen any redrafted section 260 or 136 of the Act.
Mr Viner-The Attorney-General has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) to (5) My attention has been drawn to the decision. The honourable member will be aware that amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act have been introduced this session. In addition the Statute Law Revision Act, which I introduced into Parliament on 27 May 1981, amends, amongst other things, the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 so as to require a court, when interpreting a provision of an Act, to have regard to the generallegisIative pUrpose or object underlyingthe Act (see Hansard page 2166).

Recycling of Paper: Department of Finance
(Question No. 1580)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
Has any action been taken by the Department of Finance to re-cycle paper; if so, what action.
Mr Howard-The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
The Department of Finance has not taken action to recycle paper because the Department of Administrative Services arranges contracts for removal of waste paper from Commonwealth owned and leased buildings which are occupied by the Department of Finance in Canberra, Darwin and the State capitals. I am advised that that Department has arranged for clean waste to be re-cycled wherever practicable.

Tea Services: Department of Business and Consumer Affairs
(Question No. 1616)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1981 :
(1) How many (a) full time and (b) part time staff are employed on tea making and distribution in (i) the Head Office and (ii) other offices of his Department.
(2) What was the cost of (a) salaries and (b) other charges in the provision of tea services in his Department in 1979-80.
Mr Moore-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) (a) (i) 9; (a) (ii) 3; (b) (i) 1; (b) (ii) 2.
(2) (a) $108,105.98; (b) nil.
The Melbourne and Brisbane offices are serviced by the Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services Ltd. Please refer to the answer provided by the Minister for Administrative Services to Question No. 1615 regarding these offices.
Patrol Boat Base in North-western Australia
(Question No. 1654)
Mr .Bungey asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
Has a decision yet been made on the location of a patrol boat base in north-western Australia; if not, when is a decision expected.
Mr KiIlen-The answer to the. honourable member's question is as follows:
No decision has yet been taken to acquire a particular site for a possible future patrol boat base in the north west of Australia.
If it is necessary to acquire the preferred site, to secure the future option of constructing facilities there for the support of patrol boat operations, provision will be made in the 1981-82 Acquisition Program.
Telephone Calls by Staff: Department of Health
(Question No-. 1882)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 9 April 1981 :
(1) Has his attention been drawn to a report in .the West Australian of 18 July 1979, page 37, that London metropolitan police reduced its telephone bill by $985 000, or about 20 per cent by use of a monitoring device which recorded length, time and destination of telephone calls and the extension from which the call was made.
(2) Are personal telephone calls, particularly trunk and STD calls, made by staff of his Department controlled; if so, in what way.
(3) Has any consideration been given to the introduction of monitoring devices for telephone cal1s iIi his Department; if so, what was the outcome of the consideration.
Mr MaeKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2) Yes. Departmental instructions to staff advise that private calls are to be kept to a minimum and only made with prior approval of an authorised officer. Private trunk cal1s

must be booked through the switchboard operator and the cost reimbursed to the Department.
Metering devices, where installed, are read on a regular basis and unusual levels of telephone usage are investigated. Selective STD barring is used where technical1y feasible, and inVestigations are proceeding as to the possibility of introducing selective barring on equipment at other locations.
(3) Yes. Metering equipment is extensively used and a device which analyses calls is in use at one regional office. Having regard to other control measures in use such as metering and STD access barring, and plans to extend barring where technically feasible and funds are available, it is not considered that further use of call analysers with their need for additional resources to examine monitored data, would be cost effective in my Department at this stage.
Energy Conservation
(Question No. 1903)
Mr Humphreys asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to the various recommendations of the Royal Australian Institute of Architects in regard to energy conservation.
(2) If so, have steps taken toward implementing the Institute's recommendation that the Commonwealth Government establish an Energy in Buildings Advisory Panel to advice on (a) energy conservation and (b) the research and educational aspects of energy conservation; if steps have been taken, what are the details.
Mr MeVeigh-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Various recommendations of the Royal Australian Institute of Architects in regard to energy conservation have been brought to my attention. I have exchanged correspondence with the Institute on a number of occasions, outlining the Government's position and the role of the Department of Housing and Construction.
(2) No steps have been taken to establish an Energy in Buildings Advisory Panel, as a number of Commonwealth bodies are already active in this area.
An Interdepartmetal Committee on 'Energy Conservation in Commonwealth Buildings Throughout Australia and Other Buildings in the ACT' was established in February 1981. It is required to recommend a co-ordinated program to conserve energy in existing and future buildings throughout Australia owned or occupied by the Commonwealth, and to encourage, or, if necessary, recommend legislation for the adoption of energy conservation matters in private sector buildings in the ACT.
An Energy Secretariat has been estalished within the Department of Housing and Construction to examine ways to conserve energy in Commonwealth Government buildings, and the Department is co-operating with the Department of National Development and Energy to develop cost effective energy policies for the built environment.
In addition, organisations such as the National Energy Advisory Committ~e (NEAC) and the National Energy Research Development and Demonstration Council (NERDDC), provide advice on priorities and policies in energy conservation, research development and demonstration and a proportion of NERDDC funds has been allocated to this work in fields related to energy in the built environment.

3538 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

Minister for Trade and Resources and the Minister for National Development and Energy:
Division of Responsibilities
(Question No. 1940)
Mr Hurford asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 28 Apri11981 :
(1) Has his attention been drawn to reports of power struggles and demarcation disputes between the Minister for Trade and Resources and the Minister for National Development and Energy.
(2) Is there a clumsy division ofresponsibilities between the 2 portfolios.
(3) If so, will he correct this serious fault.
Mr Malcolm Fraser-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) to (3) No sensible structure of Government could be devised whereby portfolios did not have interests extending beyond their own boundaries. Where interests do extend beyond a portfolio boundary, the Ministers and departments concerned, consult and co-operate wherever necessary to ensure that government business is conducted efficiently. Details of the arrangements between the specific portfolios referred to were given by Senator Carrick on 10 March 1981 (Senate Hansard, page 409).
Rent Resource Tax
(Question No. 1942)
Mr Hurford asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 28 Apri11981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to reports that he has rejected the views of the Department of the Treasury, the Treasurer and other Ministers, that the imposition of a rent resource tax, or a resource super profits tax, is not only the principal means of spreading the benefits of the expected resources boom to the community but also one of the best ways of managing that boom; if so, is there any substance to the reports.
(2) Does he maintain his opposition to such a super profits tax from large companies in favour of hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians; if so, what is the reason.
Mr Malcolm Fraser-The answer to the honourable member's question is a follows:
I refer the honourable member to the comments made by the Treasurer on this matter in his Ministerial Statement to the House on 13 March 1981 (Hansard page 769).

Encephalitis
(Question No.1984)
Mr Campbell asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 29 April 1981 :
(1) Has his attention been drawn to the recent occurrence of the disease encephalitis in the north of Western Australia.
(2) How many cases of this disease have been identified in this area during the last 12 months.
(3) How many of these cases were amongst Aboriginal people in this period.
(4) What steps will the Government take in response to the occurrence of this disease.
(5) Have the populations of these remote areas been adequately warned of the current danger associated with mosquito bites in the transmission of this disease.
(6) What special efforts have been made to advise the remote Aboriginal communities of the current dangers of this disease.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1 ) Yes. My Department has been in contact with Western Australia State Public Health Department concerning this outbreak.
(2) There have been seven serologically confirmed clinical cases.
(3) Five. (4) The Western Australia State health authorities have implemented mosquito vector control measures to minimize the further spread of the disease. This is the only method available. The Federal Government allocated, in addition to the normal funds for encephalitis research and control to the State, a special allowance of$10,000 to combat this outbreak. (5) and (6) Yes. The State Public Health Department with technical and monetary support from the Commonwealth promoted a health education program in the affected area including remote Aboriginal communities.
Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd
(Question No. 2028)
Mr Humphreys asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

(1) Did he say in answer to my question No. 745 (Hansard, 26 March 1981, pages 1075-6) that he had received written advice that the land purchased in the name of the Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd, and in relation to which orders were issued under the Foreign Takeovers Act 1975 prohibiting its purchase by Iwasaki Sangyo, was not in any way associatedwith Iwasaki Sangyo.
(2) Is he able to say whether, despite such written assurances from Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd, (a) employees of Iwasaki Sangyo are currently carrying out repairs to the boundary and internal fencing of the Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd and (b) 200 bullocks mustered on the Iwasaki property have been fattened on the Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd property and were offered for sale at the Rockhampton saleyards, Queensland, on 22 April 1981.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2) (a) Both Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd and the Iwasaki company have provided written advice that employees of Iwasaki Sangyo are not currently undertaking fencing repairs on or within Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd's property. The Iwasaki company is currently undertaking fencing of its own property, which has a common boundary with one of the Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd properties.
(b) These companies have also advised that the only cattle grazed on Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd's property in recent times were those owned by Setu Nominees Pty Ltd. These cattle were transferred to one of the Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd properties from the Iwasaki company's property, where they had been agisted during drought, about 12 months ago at about the time MaryvaIe Forest Pty Ltd acquired the property from Setu Nominees Pty Ltd, the previous owner. Under the provisions of the sale agreement, Setu Nominees Pty Ltd retained the right to graze cattle on the property for up to 12 months. In September last year, 10 Iwasaki bullocks which were inadvertently included in the above muster were returned to the Iwasaki company's property. Setu Nominees Pty Ltd has vacated the Maryvale Forest Pty Ltd property in accordance with the provisions of the sale agreement.
Interest Rates
(Question No. 2029)
Mr Humphreys asked the Treasurer, upon notice, 0115 May 1981:
(1) Is the base interest rate on trading bank advances of over $100 000 currently 15 per cent.
(2) Is he considering a Reserve Bank recommendation that interest rates on housing loans should be increased to 12.5 per cent.
(3) If so, would this increase on advances under $100 000 be necessary if the Reserve Bank released 1 per cent of Statutory Reserve Deposit funds to ease present bank liquidity problems during the tax rundown period.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) I understand that most major trading banks currently have a 'prime' rate of 15 per cent per annum for advances drawn under limits of $100,000 and above. This is in the nature of a reference rate. The precise rate charged to a particular customer is a matter for negotiation between the bank and the customer.
(2) There is no such recommendation currently before me.
(3) See answer to (2). However, the release of Statutory Reserve Deposit Funds to trading banks would not in itself

3540 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

affect the interest rate at which trading banks or, more importanlty, savings banks can lend for housing.

(Question No. 2042)
Mr Leo McLeay asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:

(1) I am informed by the Marrickville Legal Centre that the following funds have been received in 1980-81:
(a) $20,000 from the Commonwealth; (b) $4,000 from the Ethnic Affairs Commission of New
South Wales; in addition the Legal Services Commission of New South Wales provided furniture, equipment and stationery; (c) $1,000 from the Marrickville Municipal Council, and $5,175 from the Law Foundation of New South Wales.
(2) The Marrickville Legal Centre is an independent organisation and consequently staff employed at the Centre are not in the employ of either the Commonwealth or State Government of any other organisation.
(3) I am informed by the Marrickville Legal Centre that the duties and the hours worked by staff members at the Centre are as follows:

National Servicemen: Discharge on Grounds of Exceptional Hardship
(Question No. 2044)
Mr Campbell asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 May 1981:
(1) How many national servicemen serving in the Defence Force on 7 December 1972 left the service prior to the date on which they would normally have been discharged.

(2) How many of those referred to in part (1) were discharged on the grounds of exceptional hardship.
(3) What grounds constitute exceptional hardship.
(4) Is it possible for a member of the Service to be discharged on the grounds of exceptional hardship without his or her knowledge that this was the reason for their discharge.
Mr Killen-The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:
(1) and (2) Data is not readily available to provide the statistics requested. A lengthy manual search of many thousands of personal files would be necessary.
(3) The term 'exceptional hardship' appeared within the provisions of the National Service Act, 1951 but was not legally defined. Discharge on this ground depended on the circumstances of each case in accordance with the provisions of the Act, specifically, Sub-section 35B (5A).
(4) No. Exceptional hardship is not a current prescribed reason for discharge from any element of the Australian Defence Force. Discharge on compassionate grounds may be approved following application by a member.
Reserve Forces Use of Facility at Studley Park, Narellan
(Question No. 2067)
Mr Kerin asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
(1) Does a unit of the Reserve Forces use a facility at Studley Park, Narellan, New South Wales.
(2) If so, what is the cost of maintaining the unit, with respect to (a) personnel, (b) equipment and (c) maintenance each year.
(3) What sum has been allocated for repairs in each of the last 3 years and what proportion of this sum has been spent.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes. 2 Ordinance Platoon a Reserve Unit of 2 Divisional Field Force Group.
(2) (a) Approximately $64,000.
(b) Specific costs for maintaining equipment are not readily assessable at minor unit level.
(c) Approximately $4,500 for other running costs which include electricity, garbage, cleaning and urgent minor repairs.
(3) No spe~ific allocations were budgeted for depot maintenance over the last 3 years. An amount of $300 for urgent minor repairs has been included in (2) (c).

Integration of Defence Departments
(Question No. 2149)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 May 1981:
(1) When will he announce details of the inquiry into his Department.
(2) Will the terms of reference enable a full examination of the effectiveness of the integration of the formerly separate departments within the Defence group.
(3) Will areas of friction between service and civilian personnel, referred to in the report of the committee on naval technical services, be open for examination.
(4) Will the Committee be specifically requested to examine the size and activities of the Defence establishment in Washington, D.C., USA.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Details of the inquiry were announced by the Prime Minister and me in a joint statement issued on 7 May 1981.
(2) Yes.
(3) There is no specific term of reference dealing with civilmilitary relationships. However, if the Review memhers were to find this relevant to their general terms of reference such matters could be examined.
(4) No. The Defence presence in Washington D.C. was the subject of recommendations in the recent Review of Commonwealth Functions.
