Defence Base Establishments: Printing
(Question No. 2238)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:
(I) Have directions been given that base establishments are no longer to utilise internal printing facilities but must contract out all printing requirements.
(2) What is the estimated value of machinery which will be rendered surplus by this decision.
(3) What is the estimate of delays on the availability of rrinted material and has any estimate been made of the additional cost of required printing; if so, what is the estimate.
(4) Are additional funds allocated for the substantial increase in photocopying which will result from this decision.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable m::mber's question is as follows:
(I) No. We are looking at ways of implementing the recommendations of reports by the Printing Resources Rationalisation Group of the Department of Administrative Services which may have some effect on the amount of offset printing now being done in various establishments.
(2) Nil. No decision has yet been made that would render any machinery surplus.
(3) The Department of Defence will not let out to private contract any printing which cannot be completed in time.
(4) No. The Department of Defence limits the number of copies of any particular document reproduced to ensure that photocopying remains cost effective.
Mulloka Sonar
(Question No. 2241)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:
(I) What is the current position with regard to production and sales of the Mulloka Sonar and have funds been allocated to provide a sales effort for this project.
(2) Is it intended that the Mulloka be fitted in the Australian-built follow-on destroyers.
(3) To which vessels is it now intended that Mulloka will be fitted.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Mulloka is in the pre-production phase, in which one complete system is being manufactured. Full production is planned to commence in late 1981. No funds have heen allocated for sales purposes, but a sales agreement with an Australian firm is under consideration by my Department.

3542 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

(2) Mulloka is being considered as the sonar fit for the Australian-built follow-on destroyers. A decision on the sensor and weapons fit for the ships will be made later this year.
(3) £t is currently intended to fit production Mulloka systems in 5 RAN River Class Destroyer Escorts, HMA Ships Swall, TorrellS, Derwellt. Stuart and Parramatta. The prototype system is fitted in the sixth River Class ship, HMAS Yarra.
War Veterans: Preference in Employment
(Question No. 2255)
Mr Uren asked the Prime Minister, upon notice,on 13 May 1981:
(I) Is preference in Australian Government employment granted to war veterans; if so, under what circumstances.
(2) If preference is granted, does it apply equally to Vietnam veterans and veterans of World War II.
Mr Malcolm Fraser-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes. Under section 47A of the Public Service Act and Regulation 130 of the Public Service Regulations, where an applicant who is a returned soldier and an applicant who is not a returned soldier are placed equal in the order in which offers of appointment or temporary employment are to be made, the applicant who is a returned soldier is offered appointment or employment before the other applicant.
(2) Yes.
United States Anti-trust Case Policy
(Question No. 2258)
Mr Uren asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:
(I) How many officers of the Attorney-General's Department have been fully, or to a significant extent, occupied by the Westinghouse uranium cartel litigation and United States of America antitrust policy as it relates to uranium during each year since 1977.
(2) What has been the cost to the Australian Government of these activities in (a) salaries, (b) travel and administrative costs and (c) legal fees.
Mr Viner-The Attorney-General has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) No officers of the Attorney-General's Department have been fully occupied by the uranium cartel litigation. The number of legal officers involved in work connected with these proceedings or general antitrust policy as it relates to uranium has varied as the need has arisen. As many as 5 officers have been engaged at a particular time.
(2) (a) The cost of officers' work on antitrust matters has not been separated from the cost of performance of their other functions.
(b) Antitrust issues were amongst the matters dealt with on visits I made to Ottawa and Washington in September 1978 and April 1980. In April 1980 I also attended the Commonwealth Law Ministers Meeting in Barbados where I delivered a paper on some aspects of antitrust enforcement. Officers of my Department accompanied me on those visits.
[n addition, one officer returned to Australia via America after a visit to the OECD on other matters. He spent two days in Washington on antitrust matters. Domestically officers have made two trips to Sydney and three trips to Melbourne

in connection with the administration of the Foreign Proceedings (Prohibition of Certain Evidence) Act 1976 as it applied to these foreign proceedings.
(c) The details of legal fees paid in this matter were contained in an answer on 29 April 1981 to Senate Question 454--see Senate HallSard, page 1524.
Commonwealth Public Servants: Study Leave
(Question No. 2262)
Mr Humphreys asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 May 1981:
(I) Will he elaborate on the circumstances in which paid study leave is to be denied to Commonwealth Public Servants (Hallsard, 30 April 1981, page 1850).
(2) Will he agree to extended leave without pay to enable public servants who have already embarked on courses of study, to complete their course requirements.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The intention behind the Government's announcement is to ensure that study leave is granted only when there is direct benefit to the Service through the acquistion of specific identified skills and increase in staff efficiency. The Public Service Board is actively promoting this policy.
(2) It is nol intended that officers already committed to courses of study should be precluded from completing their courses and transitional arrangements are available. Procedures exist for public servants to take extended leave without pay for study or private purposes. Each application is considered on its merits.
Breast Feeding
(Question No. 2280)
Dr Everingham asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 14 May 1981 :
(1) Has his attention been drawn to a claim by James Grant, Executive Director of UNICEF, that breast feeding promotion can save a million infants a year in the 1980s.
(2) Is the International Baby Food Action Network (IBFAN) with the World Health Organisation (WHO) and other authorities preparing a code of marketing for breast milk substitutes to be presented to the World Health Assembly in May 1981.
(3) Has the code been opposed by the International Council of Infant Food Industries (ICIFI) whose 15 companies produce 85 per cent of the $US2 billion baby milk market.
(4) Is he able to say whether the Washingtoll Post, in January 1981, exposed industry links with publications and research foundations seeking third party support and smearing critics as Marxists and Reds.
(5) Is he also able to say whether consumer and health professional groups in India foiled moves for bilateral weak codes of ethics after financial inducements were offered to medical officials who then supported an ICIFI-drafted code.
(6) Will the Government support an international code and expose publicly irresponsible companies and their promotion.
Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) I am aware of recent reports in the Australian press that UNICEF officials have stated it is likely that at least a million

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3543

children in the developing world die each year from inadequate artificial feeding. A successful breast feeding promotion would certainly prevent some of these deaths.
(2) During the last two years, a draft International Code of Marketing of Breastmilk Substitutes has been developed by WHO and UNICEF, in co-operation with member countries of the World Health Assembly and with industry and consumer bodies. The fourth draft of this Code was presented to the Thirty-fourth World Health Assembly in May 1981.
(3) to (5) 1 am aware that there has been considerable opposition from a number of sources to the development and acceptance of the draft Code, some reports of which have been published in the Australian press. However, in the absence of detailed information concerning the specific instances referred to by the honourable member, I am unable to comment further.
(6) Australia supported the draft International Code of Marketing of Breastmilk Substitutes that was adopted by the World Health Assembly on 22 May 1981. No further action is proposed at this stage in relation to the honourable member's suggestion.
Glebe Estate, New South Wales
(Question No. 2281)
Mr Uren asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 14 M2_Y 1981:
(I) What is the current estimated value of all land and premises in the Glebe Estate, NSW.
(2) What has been the total Commonwealth Government outlay on the Estate in each year since its purchase.
(3) How many dwellings (a) have been rehabilitated in each year since the inception of the Estate project, (b) are now in the process of rehabilitation and (c) have yet to be rehahilitated.
(4) What is the estimated cost of rehabilitating the dwellings that remain in their condition.at the date of purchase by the Commonwealth.
(5) How many dwellings in the Estate are currently (a) occupied, and what is the total number of tenants and (b) vacant.
(6) What is the annual value of total rental payments to the Commonwealth for the occupied dwellings in the Estate.
(7) How many tenants in the Estate are in receipt of rental rebates.
(8) What is the annual cost of the rental rebates provided.
Mr McVeigh-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1 ) The Glebe Estate was valued at $23m by the Australian Taxation Office in November 1978.
Since the valuation will be a key factor in negotiations with the NSW Government on the transfer of the Glebe Estate it would not be appropriate for the Commonwealth to release the current valuation.
(2) Total outlays include expenditure on rehabilitation, repairs and maintenance, ex gratia payments for rates and administration costs, but no Project Office staff salaries.

(b) 40 dwelling units are currently with contractors for major rehabilitation works and about 20 dwellings for minor rehabilitation works.

HMAS 'Melbourne': Catapult Mechanism
(Question No. 2297)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:
(I) Were 2 Skyhawk aircraft lo~t during exercises by HMAS Melbourne whilst en route to a goodwill mission in India; if so, what was the cause of each loss.
(2) Did one or both aircraft go into the sea during take-off because of inadequate take-olT speed, due to the unreliable operation of the carrier's catapult mechanism.
Mr KilIen---It>e answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) No. Two Skyhawks were lost from HMAS Melbourne while the aircraft carrier was carrying out routine exercises during the Indian Ocean deployment in October 1980.
(2) No. The first aircraft was lost due to engine failure. The second aircraft was lost due to a Support Services fault (Catapult drill error).

3544 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

Washington Accommodation: Forthcoming Visit by Prime Minister
(Question No. 2316)
Mr Scholes asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 2 June 1981:
(1) Have Australian officials in Washington, DC, USA, been directed to seek from the President of the United States an invitation for the Prime Minister to stay at Blair House, the US official Guest House.
(2) If so, is the obtaining of this invitation to be treated as a top priority by senior officials of the Australian Embassy.
(3) Have Australian officials in Washington been authorised to indicate that the Australian Prime Minister will offer a positive response to an invitation for Australia to participate in a US rapid deployment force to facilitate the Israeli withdrawal from the Sinai if an invitation to use Blair House is made by or on behalf of President Reagan.
Mr Malcolm Fraser-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1), (2) and (3) No.
Payroll Deductions for Health Fund Payments
(Question No. 2350)
Mrs Kelly asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 28 May 1981:
Will he ensure that payroll deductions for health fund payments will be made available to recipients of Commonwealth superannuation payments; if not, what is the reason?
Mr Howard-The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
Superannuation pensions are paid in each State by the Depattment of Social Security and in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory by the Department of Finance, acting as paying agents for the Commissioner for Superannuation. Because of the systems presently in use in the Department of Social Security it is not practicable for that Department to -make deductions from superannuation pensions other than deductions for income tax instalments, and movements of pensioners between the States and the Territories would give rise to problems if the Department of Finance were to act alone.
Labour Market Statistics
(Question No. 2371)
Mr Humphreys asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 June 1981:
(1) Is it a fact that the universal occupational code, the Australian Standard Classification of Occupation (ASCO), is currently being prepared to rationalise labour market statistics.
(2) Will ASCO be used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in the future production of unemployment statistics; if so, will they be available on a regional basis.
Mr HowardThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The Australian Standard Classification of Occupations (ASCO) is being developed jointly by the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs and the Australian Bureau of

Statistics (ABS) to replace the current occupation classifications which suffer from a number of serious deficiencies.
(2) The Statistician has advised that in the labour force survey, unemployed persons who had worked for two weeks or more in a full-time job in the previous two years are classified according to the occupation of their last full-time job. The ASCO will be used for these unemployment statistics as soon as practicable, but is not expected to be available for some considerable time.
Following the next reselection of the labour force survey sample, to be based on results of the 198 I Census of Population and Housing, it may be feasible to provide some statistics of unemployment on a regional basis, but any occupational classification would not be very detailed.
Prices of Petroleum Products
(Question No. 2436)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:
(1) Did the Prices Justification Tribunal say in its report published on 31 March 1981 entitled, 'Inquiry into Prices of Petroleum Products', at page 101, that the Tribunal could also examine the suggestion of the New South Wales Government that the boundaries of metropolitan free delivery areas be reviewed to take account of shifting population centres and geographical proximities to bulk terminals; if so, will he ensure that a review of this nature is conducted.
(2) How, by whom and when will this review be conducted.
Mr Moore- -The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2) The review will be conducted by the Petrnleum Product Pricing Authority. I introduced the legislation to establish the Authority on 27 May 1981.
Prices of Petroleum Products
(Question No. 2437)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:
(1) Did the Prices Justification Trihunal say in its report published on 31 March 1981 entitled 'Inquiry into Prices of Petroleum Products', at page 89, that the existence of a return on investment component (ie in service station sites) in the maximum justified wholesale price is undesirable and that in order to determine the appropriate adjustment component while also giving the companies tirre to negotiate new [ease contracts, the Tribunal proposes to remove the return of investment component from the maximum justified wholesale price of motor spirit in January 1982; if so, will he ensure that this proposal is implemented.
(2) How and when will he ensure that it is implemented.
Mr Moore-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2) The proposal will be implemented by the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority. I introduced the legislation to establish the authority on 27 May 1981.

Nitinol Mr Malcolm Fraser-On 5 March 1981 (Hansard, page 460) the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) asked me a question, without notice, concerning the potential economic significance of Nitinol to Australia.
The following is in answer to the honourable member's question:

Defoliants and Pesticides Effect on Vietnam Veterans
Mr Malcolm Fraser-On 30 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1807) the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) asked me a question, without notice, concerning any discussions and exchanges of information between the Australian and United States Governments on the impact of agent orange and other chemicals on servicemen in Vietnam.
I undertook to provide more detailed information to the honourable member. The following is in answer to his question:
I am advised that arrangements have been made between the Department of Veterans' Affairs and relevant United States agencies to exchange unclassified information on the progress of studies in Australia and the United States, as well as new scientific data having a bearing on the issue. In view of recent Swedish studies that suggest a correlation between exposure to phenoxyacid herbicides and increased risk of lymphoma, the United States Veterans' Administration has asked to be kept informed of any decisions which may be made in Australia in respect of Vietnam veterans' claims in relation to malignant lymphoma. I am advised that there has been no expression of concern by the United States Government to the Australian Government in respect of any precedent that Australian investigations into the alleged effects of agent orange on Vietnam veterans may have in establishing any liability by the United States Government.
There have been high level discussions between Australian and US officials, and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs will be visiting the United States in June this year to discuss issues of concern to Vietnam veterans with officials of the United

States Veterans' Administration, veterans organisations, and other organisations involved in this area. These issues include the epidemiological study which will be investigating whether there were any effects on Australian servicemen of agent orange and other chemicals used in Vietnam, and similar studies underway in the United States.
International Labour Organisation Convention: Aboriginal Employment
.(Question No.6)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:
On what occasions, at, what level and with what results has there been Federal-State (a) consultation and (b) correspondence on the possibility of providing a legislative basis for National and State Employment Discrimination Committees established to give the provisions of International Labour Organisation Convention No. Ill-Discrimination (Employment and Occupation), 1958, which was ratified by Australia on 15 June 1974 and which entered into force for Australia a yearlater. (Hansard, 20 October 1977, page 2289).
Mr N. A. Brown-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The possibility of the establishment of the National and State Employment Discrimination Committees on a statutory basis was raised at the Ministers for Labour Meeting in September 1980. At that meeting Ministers were advised that, following receipt of advice from the National Labour Consultative Council on the Council's views on the desirable form of such legislation, the Commonwealth would seek consultations with the States.
While there has been some correspondence which referred, in passing, to the Government's consideration of this matter it has not been raised in correspondence with the States in a substantive way.
Trade Commissioner Service
(Question No. 255)
Mr Barry Jones asked the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 3 December 1980:
(I) Is it a fact that his Department is increasingly ignoring the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce on the Australian Trade Commissioner Service, by recruiting persons from within the Australian Public Service rather than from the private sector.
(2) Is the current salary structure for Trade Commissioners appropriate compared with the salaries of business executives of equivalent position in the private sector.

3546 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

(3) Is he able to say whether morale within the Australian Trade Commissioner Service is at an all time low; if so, has this contributed to recent resignations by experienced members of the Service.
(4) Is it a fact that the Lynch Committee has frozen a number of Trade Commissioner vacancies at overseas posts; if so, will cutbacks of this kind benefit Australian exporters when commercial intelligence on world opportunities is badly needed and vital to export performance.
Mr Anthony-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Not in my judgment. The honourable member might wish to refer to the Senate Hansard of 27 September 1979, at pages 1032 and 1033, where the recommendations contained in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce on the Australian Trade Commissioner Service, and the Government's responses thereto, are recorded.
(2) The salary structure for Trade Commissioners is directly related to the rates of pay for Second and Third Divison positions in the Public Service which cover a wide spectrum of executive positions within the public sector. The rates of pay for Second and Third Divison positions are presently under review by a Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and any increase forthcoming from that review will also be applied to Trade Commissioners.
(3) No.
(4) In his statement to Parliament on 30 April 1981 on the outcome of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Prime Minister said, inter alia, that, 'significant room for staffing reductions exists in our diplomatic missions overseas. The staffing of the London and Washington posts overseas will be cut by 232 and by 75 staff respectively . . . '. The way in which this decision is to be implemented, insofar as the Trade Commissioner Service is concerned, is presently being investigated but it can be assumed that the intent will be to minimise the effect on Australian exporters. In addition to the number of staff serving under the Trade Commissioner Act has been reduced by just over 2 per cent as a result of decisions flowing from the Review of Commonwealth Functions. This may require a re-distribution of staffing resources but such redistribution would be directed towards maximising overall efficiency including the provision of commercial intelligence to the Australian business community.
School to Work Transition Program
(Question No. 285)
Mr Hawke asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 4 December 1980:
(I) How many new courses commenced in the Commonwealth school to work transition program in 1980.
(2) How many additional places did the additional courses provide.
(3) What was the average cost to the Commonwealth per place.
(4) What proportion of those additional places was taken up by unemployed young persons.
(5) How many additional places are expected to be provided in 1981.
(6) How many young persons experiencing transition problems are expected to be found places in next year's courses.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) Preliminary data available from the States concerning new courses commenced tinder the Transition Program in 1980 indicate that 247 courses began in the TAFE sector.

A major purpose of the Program in schools is to assis,t development of appropriate changes in curriculum, including the development of alternative courses for young people whose
needs are not adequately met by traditional courses. While these measures are expected to encourage more, st~dents to continue longer in secondary education, the major effect so far has been to improve the capacity of schools to deal adequately with the needs of students already in the schools. It i~ not possible to specify a particular number of courses or places provided in schools from Commonwealth funds. However, it is estimated that at least 4,000 students in secondary schools were undertaking courses receiving significant financial sup-
port under the Program.

Funding for the Program is approximately equally divided

between school based and TAFE programs.

'

(2) Courses in TAFE institutions provided for about 4,400

students. Many thousands of students in schools. benefited

from developments supported under the Program in 1980.

These include development and extension of'alternative

course offerings and work experience programs, improvement

of career guidance and education, programs of city visits for

country children, provision of vocational course equipment

and facilities, teacher development and transition, curriculum

development.

',

(3) The average cost to the Commonwealth' of providing
these courses in TAFE in 1980 (excluding Commonwealth
benefits and allowances paid to students and trainees) was of the order of $1,500 per student. It should be noted that courses varied in length from twelve weeks tq forty weeks,
depending on arrangements in individual, ,States and institutions.

(4) Sample data suggests that about three-quarters of trainees in TAFE courses under the Program were receiving Unemployment Benefit before commencing c,?urses.

(5) It is expected that about 6,000 places wi11'be provided in courses in the TAFE sector under the Program in 1981. This is 1,600 more than in 1980. The range of activitieS established in schools will continue and develop. At least 8,000 students in secondary schools are undertaking courses receiving financial support under the Program.

(6) See reply to (5) above. Most participants in courses funded under the Program either have experienced or are regarded as likely to experience transition problems. Activities in the school sector will significantly affect many thousands of students, although few will be enrolled in new places which can be specifically identified as being fully funded by the Commonwealth.

A good part of activities funded by the Commonwealth under the Transition Program supplements similar activities funded by the States.

Building and Construction Industries: Recruitment of Tradesmen Overseas
(Question No. 404)
Mr Uren asked the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:
(I) How many (a) skilled and (b) semi-skilled tradesmen for the building and construction industries were (i) in private

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3547

sector employment, (ii) in government sector employment, (iii) registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service as unemployed and awaiting placement at the end of June and (iv) undergoing apprentice training and newly indentured in each State and Territory and for the Commonwealth as a whole in each of the years 1969-70 to 1979-80.
(2) How many (a) skilled and (b) semi-skilled tradesmen for the building and construction industries were recruited from overseas in each of those years.
Mr N. A. Brown-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) (i) and (ii) Only a limited amount of the information requested by the honourable member is available.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics does not collect, on a regular basis, statistics of tradesmen. It did carry out a sample survey of private and government employers in September 1977 to obtain information on the numbers of apprentices and employees working as tradesmen, but it was subject to certain significant limitations. For further information refer to ABS

publication 'Apprentices and Employees Working as Tradesmen, September 1977', Catalogue No. 6233.0.
In addition, in a survey of the construction industry in respect of the year 1978-79 the ABS collected details of on-site employment by private sector construction establishments at 30 June 1979. While this information does not differentiate between skilled and semi-skilled tradesmen it incorporates a classification of 21 occupations. For further information refer to ABS publications 'Private Sector Construction Establishment, Details of Operation by Industry Class, 1978-79', Catalogue No. 8714.0-822.0. Corresponding figures for the public sector are not available.
(1) (iii) The table below sets out statistics of the numbers of persons registered with the Commonwealth Employment Servie as unemployed and awaiting placement and seeking full time work as (a) skilled and (b) semi-skilled building and construction tradesmen at the end of May (collection of this data was reduced in frequency to February, May, August and November each year as from October 1978) in each State and Territory and for the Commonwealth as a whole in each year from 1970 to 1980 inclusive.

(2) Statistics on the number of migrant arrivals classified by occupations and skill are available from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in its publication 'Australian Immigration-Consolidated Statistics' and 'Australian Immigration-Quarterly Statistical Summary'. It should be noted that statistics on migrant arrivals by occupation are based on the recognised qualifications of some migrants and the stated occupations of others. In addition statistics on migrant arrivals in the building and construction occupations do not indicate that all these workers are employed in the construction industry, as some workers in the building trades are employed in other industries. Similarly not all workers in the construction industry are employed in the building and construction trades, e.g. electrical tradesmen, metal workers.

Government Departments: Staff Recruitment
(Question No. 723)
Mr Hurford asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 5 March 1981:
(1) Is it a fact that a number of Government departments and statutory bodies, including (a) Treasury, (b) Finance, (c) Industrial Relations and (d) the Industries Assistance Commission, are having difficulty in recruiting suitably qualified staff.
(2) Is this fact borne out by the amount ofre-advertisingof certain Government positions being arranged by his Department.
(3) Is this problem particularly acute in the field of quantitative economic analysis.
(4) Is this seeming lack of expertise available for the public sector within Australia caused by a brain drain to overseas countries and a loss of trained personnel to the private sector; if so, is he concerned by this trend.

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3549

(5) How does this loss from the public sector reconcile with the view of the Prime Minister expressed in the House during the question period on 26 February 1981 when he referred to the privileged position of the Public Service in comparison with other employees around this country (Hansard, page 232).
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The Public Service employs specialist staff in a wide range of fields. From time to time departments experience difficulty in recruiting suitably qualified staff in particular specialist fields.
(2) At the time the question was asked the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs was experiencing difficulty in recruiting staff to its Bureau of Labour Market Research and to steno-secretarial positions.
(3) The economics area generally is one in which recruitment difficulties are being experienced at the moment.
(4) There is currently a shortfall in the supply of qualified personnel graduating from tertiary institutions in some specialised categories, such as economics. Private sector employers, competing for the same scarce resources, are also experiencing recruitment difficulties in these fields. While a proportion of resignations from the Service represents trained personnel transferring to the private sector there is no evidence to suggest that this trend is on the increase. There is also no indication of a significant "brain drain" overseas from the Public Service.
(5) The present situation is primarily tbe result of an overall shortage of specialised staff and not the conditions of employment of Commonwealth public servants.
Occupational Safety and Health
(Question No. 742)
Mr Humphreys asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 10 March 1981:
(1) Did he announce on 15 May 1978 that the Code of General Principle concerning Occupational Safety and Health in Commonwealth Government employment would be implemented in Commonwealth departments and factories and would thereby give a lead to both private industries and State Government industries.
(2) If so, is he able to say to what extent the Code has been adopted in private industry.
(3) Into what number of foreign languages has the Code been translated.
Mr Malcolm Fraser-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes. The Government has also approved 37 Codes of Practice as recommendations to be read in suppnrt of the Code of General Principles.
(2) The States have the conatitutional responsibility in respect of occupational health and safety in private industry. Four State Governments have adopted the Code of General Principles with minor revisions in respect of their own employees. The Commonwealth has no detailed knowledge of the extent of adoption of the code by private industry. It is believed, however, that there is an increasing awareness both in the State Governments and private industry of the financial and humanitarian benefits to be gained from the implementation of properly structured and implemented occupational safety and health programs.
(3) There has been no co-ordinated action to prepare translations of the Code of General Principles which is basically a management guide. However, the Commonwealth is aware of

the language problems facing some migrants which could contribute to accidents at the workplace and funds have been provided in the past to combat this problem. Audiovisual aids and handbooks have been produced in up to nine languages.
Bliss Symbols System
(Question No. 872)
Mr Holding asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 25 March 1981:
Has he or his Department made any examination of the Bliss Symbols system for intellectually handicapped children; if so, what was the result of that examination and when was it carried out.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
Neither I nor my Department have made an examination of the Bliss Symbols system. However, the Department and the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority are aware that evaluation studies carried out overseas have shown that a modified version of Bliss Symbols is effective in the teaching of children with particular intellectual and physical handicaps. I am advised that Bliss Symbols in modified form are being used in some schools in Australia.
Concessional Fringe Benefits for Pensioners
(Question No. 922)
Dr Blewett asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:
(I) Has the Minister investigated the possibility of placing Vital call, Visec-Alert, or any other telephone system to assist the elderly and infirm on the list of free or concessional fringe benefits for eligible pensioners.
(2) If so, what is the estimated number of services required, and their cost.
(3) If such an investigation has not been carried out, will the Minister undertake to do so, and provide an estimate of the cost of providing the system outlined in part (1).
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) No. The Commonwealth currently provides telephone rental concessions to certain pensioners and beneficiaries but does not intend to extend those concessions to cover associated services marketed by private companies.
(2) See answer to (1).
(3) For the reason outlined in (1) it is not appropriate to attempt to estimate the cost involved.
TelegJ'ams
(Question No. 1048)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 2 April 1981 :
(1) Does the management of Telecom Australia maintain a policy of scaling down its telegram service; if so, does it do so (a) by increasing costs vis-a-vis costs for telex and telephone services, and decreasing services and (b) with the Government's support.
(2) Is it a fact that some areas of the Brisbane Metropolitan area are not serviced by telegrams in that telegrams cannot be messenger delivered to those areas; if so which areas, and for what reason.

3550 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

(3) Was the minimum charge for a telegram of 12 words in (a) 1976, $1.44, (b) in 1977, $1.80 and (c) in 1978, $3.30.
(4) What is the current charge for a 12 word telegram.
(5) During this period, by how much has the total number of telegrams handled nationally diminished.
(6) Has a cost increase of more than 300 per cent over 4 years occurred while telegram handling has fallen by approximately 60 per cent during the same years; if so, are these factors related.
(7) Is it a fact that prior to July 1979, telegrams had to be issued for delivery within one hour of lodgement, but since July 1979, telegrams must be issued for delivery in (a) metropolitan and larger country areas, within 4 hours, (b) smaller country centres where messenger delivery is available, as early as practicable on the day of lodgement, and (c) other places, as soon as possible depending on local arrangements.
(8) Have telegram services to the public deteriorated; if so, does he propose to recommend changes to the service.
(9) If he will not recommend changes to this service, why not.
Mr Sinclair-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) No. Tariffs and standards provided on all Telecom's services, including the public telegram service, are designed to reflect as far as practicable the cost of providing, and the demand for, each of those services.
(2) Yes. There are nine localities in the Brisbane metropolitan area where no messenger delivery is available, namelyBrookfield, Upper Brookfield, Bellbowrie, Anstead, Pullenvale, Moggill, Pinjarca Hills, Belmont and Chandler. These are lightly populated fringe areas with very little demand for telegram services. Other offices in Brisbane provide either a four hour or same day messenger delivery service.
(3) (a) and (b) Yes. (c) In 1978 the minimum rate was $1.80 for telegrams addressed to a telex number or for delivery by mail. The charge of $3.30 was for a 12 word telegram requiring messenger delivery.
(4) Addressed to a residential or business address-$4.30; addressed to a telegraphic code address-$3.30; addressed to a telephone number--$3.00; addressed to a postal address for delivery by mail-$2.50; addressed to a telex number-$2.00.
(5) The number of telegrams handled in 1979-80 was 5.4 million-a decline of 7.5 million since 1975-76.
(6) The charge for a 12 word messenger delivery telegram has risen from $1.84 in 1976 to $4.30 in 1980-an increase of 133.7 per cent. The current minimum charge for a telegram addressed to a telex number, however, is only $2.00-an increase of 38.8 per cent. Although increased charges have undoubtedly had an effect on the demand for the public telegraph service, the effect of the increased use and availability of high quality telephone, telex, data, facsimile and other communications services has been of equal significance. This reflects a world wide trend.
(7) (a) Prior to 1979 the service standard for ordinary rate telegrams was 30 minutes from time of lodgement to issue for delivery. Since 1979, the standard at most metropolitan and large country offices is 4 hours from time of lodgement to the actual delivery time. These standards are the maximum, rather than minimum, delivery times to be met in 90 per cent of cases. (b) and (c) Yes. In all cases, delivery times for telegrams which are telephoned or telexed to addressees are very much lower.
(8) and (9) The level of service has changed very little in recent years except for the general unavailability of a weekend delivery service outside metropolitan areas. Telegrams may still be lodged across a telegraph or post office counter

during business hours and by telephone or telex on a 24 hour basis from virtually anywhere in Australia. Messenger delivery is limited to business hours outside the metropolitan areas where porterage fees apply after hours, but telegrams can be delivered over a 24 hour period anywhere in Australia by telephone or telex_ Higher standards of service would need to take account of the demand for and cost of providing the service.
Integration of Handicapped Children into Regular Schools
(Question No. 1122)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:
(1) When were copies of the Schools Commission's notes on Commonwealth programs for schools, 1981, sent to Members' and Senators' offices.
(2) Does an attachment to that circular 1/81 contain guidelines for the administration of funds ava:Iable for the integration of handicapped children into regular schools in 1981.
(3) Does the attachment state that applications for grants under that special education program for the integration of handicapped children into regular schools must be lodged with State offices of the Schools Commission, or the Northern Territory Department of Education, by Tuesday, 21 April 1981.
(4) Is it usual procedure for the Schools Commission to inform directly individual schools of the existence and conditions of these programs.
(5) Has the Commission directly contacted individual schools to inform them of the details of this program; if not, why not; if so, when.
(6) If notification of schools of this program has been left to the State Government Departments of Education, what action has the Queensland Department of Education taken in this regard.
(7) What recommendation has the Commission made in respect of funding this aspect of the special education program.
(8) Is it a fact that the Commonwealth Government has no commitment to continuation of this aspect of the program, at least at the present level of funding.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.
(4) and (5) It is usual procedure for the Schools Commission to set out the existence and conditions of programs concerning special education in the publication, 'Notes on Commonwealth Programs for Schools.' These guidelines are circulated to State and Northern Territory Education Departments, non-government school systems and all nongovernment schools. In the case of government schools, it is left to the initiative of the State or Territory Education Department concerned to decide the extent to which any particular school is informed of the contents of the Program Notes.
The publication, 'Notes on Commonwealth Programs for Schools', was circulated to all non-government schools and their system authorities on 10 March 1981. The publication was also forwarded on the same date to the Education Departments of the States and the Northern Territory.
(6) As indicated in (4) and (5) above, it is a matter for State or Northern Territory Education Departments to determine the extent to which any government special school is involved in this program.

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3551

(7) In its Report for the Triennium 1982-84 the Schools Commission has recommended that support for integration programs in 1981 be continued through the 1982-84 triennium to assist the integration of handicapped students into regular schools, and to enable isolated handicapped students to attend their neighbourhood schools where living at home is an alternative to a residential school. It is intended that the funds be administered through a joint program approach and on a project basis, in consultation with government and nongovernment education authorities in the States and the Northern Territory.
(8) For 1982 the Government has maintained expenditure, in real terms, on the integration of handicapped children into regular schools. This expenditure will be more closely related to the special education programs for government and nongover..ment schools by being incorporated as an element of these programs in 1982.

Expenditure Commitments: Department of Finance
(Question No. 1216)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(1) What specific commitments for expenditure, excluding normal recurring costs of running the Department such as salaries and administrative costs, does the Department of Finance have for (a) 1980-81 and (b) 1981-82.
(2) What sum is involved in each commitment and what is the purpose of the commitment.
(3) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the fact that when a similar question was answered by a number of Ministers in 1976, it was claimed that obtaining the information would involve collection of detailed information from a diversity of records and sources, and would therefore require unjustifiable use of staff resources.
(3) Has the development of forward estimates in the Department of Finance now been advanced to a stage where a similar reply is no longer valid.
Mr Howard-The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(I) to (4) I am aware that a similar question was asked by the honourable member of a number of Ministers in 1976, and that the honourable member was informed that the information requested could not be supplied because the task would have required a major commitment of staff resources

,which could not be justified in terms of the time and expense involved.
The development of the Forward Estimates has advanced since 1976 but these estimates are not designed to provide information of the nature requested by the honourable member. I advise that extraction of that detailed information from a diversity of records and sources would still involve substantial and unjustifiable expense in time and resources.

Head Office, Department of Education
(Question No. 1508)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(1) Are any sections of the Head Office of his Department not located in Canberra; if so, what are the sections and how many staff are in each.

Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The entire Central Office of the Department of Education is located in Canberra. The Department's Internal Audit Section is managed from Canberra on a decentralised basis and ten positions are outposted to the various States to provide internal audit services to State Offices.
(2) Not applicable.

(Ii) No part-time staff are employed on tea making and distribution in any of this Department's other offices.

Fishing Industry Research
(Question No. 1648)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(1) What Commonwealth funds have been spent on research into the fishing industry in Western Australia in each financial year since 1975-76.
(2) To whom were the funds allocated and what was the nature and cost of each research project.
Mr Nixon-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) and (2) See table attached.
In addition to the attached projects carried out under the auspices of my department, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has considerable involvement with fishing industry related research in Western Australia. Details are set out below:
Invertebrate Resources Program
Program included research relevant to the rock lobster industry and involved expenditure of $3,557,620 in the period 1976-77 to 1977-78.
Coastal Ecology Program
Research was related to the future of the rock lobster industry. Expenditure in the period 1978-79 to 1979-80 was $992,226. Support from the Rural Credits Development Fund for this program amounted to $27,988 in 1979-80 and $18,839 in 1980-81.

Tea Services: Department ofIndustrial Relations
(Question No. 1604)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 9 April 1981 :
(1) How many (a) full time and (b) part time staff are employed on tea making and distribution in (i) the Head Office and (ii) other offices of his Department.
(2) What was the cost of (a) salaries and (b) other charges in the provision of tea services in his Department in 1979-80.
Mr Viner-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) (a) (i) No full time staff are employed on tea making and distribution in this Department's Head Office.
(ii) No part time staff are employed on tea making and distribution in this Department's Head Office.
(b) (i) A portion of the duties of one full-time Clerical Assistant Grade 1 is allocated for tea making and distribution in the Office of the Industrial Registrar in Melbourne. There is no such service in any other office.

Living Resources Program
Program involved operation of research vessels on the North West Shelf and also investigation of the relationship between South Australian and Western Australian stocks of salmon. It is not possible to separate the Western Australian component of this program from overall expenditure which amounted to $3,780,708 in the period 1978-79 to 1979-80.
Oceanographic Research Program
The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation oceanographic research vessel Sprightly undertook research off Western Australia for approximately five months each year from 1975-76 to 1977-78. The overall cost of this vessel in this period was $806,700 in 1975-76, $758,700 in 1976-77 and $468,500 in 1977-78. It is not possible to identify the Western Australian component of these costs.
The Department of Science and Technology is also involved, through the public interest provisions of the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act, with a three year research and development project grant amounting to $225,000 for the production of freshwater crayfish in Western Australia. The grant was announced in February 1981.

Charter of Racing Yacht 'Anaconda II'
(Question No. 1994)
Mr Rocher asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on29 April 1981:
(1) Have arrangements been made by the Commonwealth Government to charter the ocean racing yacht Anaconda 1I for use by South Australian fishing inspectors.
(2) If so, is the charterrate $1,250 per day.
(3) If the charter rate is not $1,250 per day, what is the daily charter rate.
(4) What are the terms of the charter and, in particular, can the Commonwealth Government become liable to the yacht's owner for any sum additional to the basic charter rate as aresuit of its use of the yacht.
(5) How many crew are required to operate the yacht, what are their qualifications and is the cost of their wages and personal insurances included in the charter rate.
(6) How many fishing inspectors and other officials are carried on the yacht.
(7) Are any persons carried when the yacht is on Government service other than paid crew and public servants on duty; if so, who and for what reason are they carried.
(8) What durations of voyage are (a) undertaken or (b) contemplated in the use of the yacht.
(9) Are all Department of Transport, public service and other regulations complied with in this use of the yacht.
(10) What are the (a) maximum and (b) most economical speeds under power of Anaconda II.
(11) Is he able to say what is the maximum speed of a typical Japanese tuna fishing vessel.
(12) What is the approximate value of Anaconda II as is, complete with all equipment.
(13) What is the rationale for the use of Anaconda II for this purpose and, in particular, why is use being made of a (a) sailing vessel rather than a motor vessel and (b) very large ocean racer rather than a smaller vessel designed for seagoing work with a small crew but which still has ample accommodation and endurance.
(14) Were tenders called for this charter; if not, why not.
(15) If tenders were called for this charter, was that involving Anaconda II the lowest; if not, why was the lowest tender not accepted.
Mr Nixon-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The Anaconda II was the vessel selected by the South Australian Government in consultation with the Commonwealth Government for the deployment of Australian fishing zone observers aboard Japanese vessels operating off South Australia.

3556 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

(2) Yes.
(3) See (2).
(4) The vessel is required to carry four observers to locate and board licensed Japanese tuna longliners operating off the South Australian coast in order to obtain information on the size composition and biology of the Japanese catch and technical information on their fishing operations. Under the terms of the contract, the Commonwealth is not liable to the yacht's owner for sums additional to the basic daily rate.
(5) Eight crew consisting of experienced local seamen were on board for the first voyage lasting 13 days. The charter rate was all inclusive. Wages and personal insurance are matters for the crew and vessel owner.
(6) Three observers and one Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation biologist.
(7) The only personnel carried on the vessel for the two voyages were Commonwealth and State officers together with the crew.
(8) (a) Voyage I undertaken from 23.4.81 to 5.5.81. (b) Voyage 2 undertaken from 21 .5.81 to 28.5.81. No further voyages are contemplated.
(9) All Commonwealth requirements were complied with in the use of the vessel.
(10) (a) Six knots. (b) Approximately 4-5 knots.
(11) Speeds vary according to the operation being undertaken, e.g. 9-10 knots for speed setting line, 3-5 knots for speed retrieving line. Tuna longline vessels are normally stationary (adrift) for approximately 4 hours daily. In the observer operation the question of pursuit does not arise. Boardings of vessels by observers are facilitated by the master of the foreign vessel.
(12) It is understood that the initial construction cost was $100,000; but replacement value is now conservatively estimated at $500,000.
(13) It was the cheapest arrangement. Few suitable vessels were available for charter in South Australia with sufficient range, size and deep seagoing capabilities for operations in the Great Australian Bight. The tuna season was at its height and local fishermen were unwilling to make their vessels available for a charter fee that would be well below the returns they could obtain from fishing.
Of the three vessels available for the charter, two w~re motor vessels priced at $2,000 per day. The Anaconda II although a sailing vessel, met the requirements for the charter, especially for deep seagoing work and its capacity to accommodate crew and observers at least cost. There were no reports of the Anaconda II having difficulty in satisfactorily completing all the necessary manoeuvres to enable observers to perform their tasks amongst the Japanese vessels.
(14) Following consultation with the South Australian Tender Board, it was decided not to call tenders because of the time that would be lost in arranging chatters to meet the deadline for the commencement of the exercise.
(15) See (13) and (14).
Northern Territory Disabled Persons: Education Projects
(Question No. 2052)
Mr Tambling asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

(I) What financial appropriations have been allocated by his Department for use in the Northern Territory for projects to assist the disabled during 1980-81.
(2) For what specific projects has this sUm been allocated.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) and (2) During 1980 and 1981 funds are being made available for disabled young people in the Northern Territory under programs administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission and under the Transition from School to Work Program.
Under the Commonwealth Schools Commission's programs, allocations to the Northern Territory for 1980 included $119,000 for government special schools, and $13,500 for residential institutions. Allocations for 1981 include $123,500 for government special schools, $14,500 for residential institutions and $10,500 for the program for the integration of handicapped children into regular schools. In addition, in 1981, the Northern Territory will share in a new program of assistance for the severely handicapped but individual State and Territory allocations are not yet available.
Under the Transition from School to Work Program, projects to attract funding are initiated by the Northern Territory authorities and are submitted to the Commonwealth for approval. In 1981 $3,200 has been earmarked to help improve the prospects of handicapped students by giving increased attention to literacy and numeracy skills in school and by offering work experience placements. However it is expected that disabled young people would also benefit from projects of a more general nature. Under the Transition Program the Northern Territory received a totaf of$95,599 in 1980and has received $112,860 so farin 1981.
Primary Industry Advisory Panels
(Question No. 2068)
Mr Holding asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
(I) How many advisory panels or similar committees, such as the Federal Potato Co-ordinating Committee, are there in his Department.
(2) In each case, (a) what is the name and purpose of the panel or committee, (b) when was it established, (c) who are the members, what are their qualifications and what areas do they represent, (d) how many meetings have been held in each of the last 5 years and where was each meeting held, (e) what was the cost of these meetings and (f) what was the duration of each meeting.
Mr Nixon-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The Federal Potato Co-ordinating Committee is an industry body representing potato merchants. Its only connection with my Department is to provide nominations of potato merchants to the membership of the National Potato Panel. However, there are a number of advisory panels and committees of a non-statutory nature with which my Department has an involvement. These include the National Potato Panel, National Vegetable Panel, Cherry Panel, Raw Cotton Marketing Advisory Committee, Brucellosis and Tuberculosis Eradication Campaign Committee, and the Meat Industry Advisory Committee.
(2) The attached schedule sets out details on the information sought for each of these bodies.

Bendigo Ordnance Factory
(Question No. 2074)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Industry and -Commerce, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
(I) Does the Government intend to close down the Bendigo Ordnance Factory if no private enterprise buyer can be found.
(2) Will potential purchasers be offered special incentives such as subsidised or guaranteed workloads. etc., to purchase the factory.
Sir Phillip Lynch-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) In the event that acceptable offers for the Factory are not forthcoming, it is not the intention of the Government to close the Factory.
(2) No special incentives of the types described are to be offered when seeking expressions of interest or when inviting tenders. Any requests or proposals by prospective purchasers will be considered.
Bendigo Ordnance Factory
(Question No. 2078)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
What is the estimated value of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory and its fixed assets.
Sir Phillip Lynch-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
See my answer to Question No. 2077.

(Question No. 2125)
Mrs Kelly asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:

Will he provide a detailed list of the (a) numbers of staff and (b) functions to be eliminated in all areas of his Department that are located in the Australian Capital Territory. when the recommendations of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions are implemented.
Mr Nixon-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
I refer the honourable member to the answer provided by the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister to Question Number 2119 which appeared in Hansard on 5 June 1981, page 3317.

Mr Howard-The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

Answers to Questions

Commonwealth Public Service: Reduction in Staffing
(Question No. 2158)
Mr Lloyd asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 7 May 1981:
(1) Has the Government required reduction of the Commonwealth Public Service on several occasions since November 1975.
(2) If so, how many public servants, and at what level, (a) have been affected on each occasion during this period and (b) will be affected following the implementation of the Review of Commonwealth Functions.

(3) Is it a fact that there has been a disproportionate reduction in the lower levels of the Public Service, and that one of the unforeseen results of the reductions has been an increase in the percentage ratio of 2nd Division Officers.
(4) What will happen to 2nd Division Officers in those areas where their function has been abolished or transferred to private enterprise or to a State Government.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) (a) The table below shows the number of full time Public Service Act staff at 30 June from 1975 to date, by Division:

DIVISIONAL GROUP

Year at June

Second

Third

Fourth

Total

No.

No.
