(These figures have been corrected retrospectively for transfer into and out of Public Service Act coverage that occurred prior to 30 June 1980 e.g. for transfers to the Northern Territory Public Service.)

(2) (b) Implemention of the Government's decisions announced in the Prime Minister's statement of 30 April 1981 is expected to result in reductions in the order of 16,000 to 17,000 in the number of Commonwealth Government employees. It is estimated that some 7,000 to 8,000 of the reduction will be Public Service Act employees. Details of savings at the various levels are not available at this stage.
(3) The table illustrates changes within the Second, Third and Fourth Divisions for the period 30 June 1975 to 30 June 1980. The changes in the relevant proportions of the Second, Third and Fourth Divisions of the Service can be attributed to a number of factors such as different work arrangements, the nature of the work done, the impact of technological change, as well as staffing reductions.
(4) Those Second Division staff identified as excess to their department's requirements as a result of decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions to abolish the functions for which they are responsible are covered by the provisions and associated procedures of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act and the Public Service Arbitrator's Determination No 509 of 1977. It is expected that any excess Second Division staff will be redeployed in the Service.
In regard to those staff employed on functions to be transferred to a State Government, it is envisaged that that State Government would make offers of employment to all such staff and that they would transfer to State employment in accordance with provisions of Part IV of the Public Service Act. Finalisation of terms and conditions of transfer and employment with the State Government will be subject to negotiations with State authorities.
For those staff in areas which are to be transferred to the private sector, it is envisaged that those organisations will be sold as going concerns and that offers of employment by the relevant private employers will be made to the Commonwealth staff undertaking the functions to be transferred. The terms and conditions of transfer and subsequent employment of these staff will be negotiated with the individual private employers.

Participation in Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting: Department of the Prime
Minister and Cabinet
(QuestlonNo.2162)
Mr Hayden asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 7 May 1981:
(1) How many (a) 2nd Division, (b) 3rd Division and (c) 4th Division officers of his Department are engaged (i) full time or (ii) part-time in administrative, policy or other preparations for the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne.
(2) How many officers of his Department are expected to attend the Meeting.
(3) What is the expected cost of their attendance at the Meeting, including salaries, overtime, accommodation, travel and other expenses.
(4) What other expenses does he expect his Department to incur as a result of Australia's participation in, and conduct of, the Meeting.
Mr Malcolm Fraser-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) to (4) This will be the largest meeting of Commonwealth Heads of Government yet held and will be by far the largest meeting at this level ever to take place in Australia. At least 41 countries, represented for the most part by Head of State or Head of Government with accompanying delegations of Ministers and officials, are expected to attend.
Over the last decade the practice has developed of holding the Meeting in different member countries of the Commonwealth. Recent Meetings have been held in Singapore, Ottawa, Kingston, London and Lusaka. If smaller countries such as Singapore, Jamaica and Zambia can fulfil their obligations as Members of the Commonwealth of Nations, it is right that Australia should, too.
Much needs to be available in the way of facilities and equipment for a meeting of this level and size. Much of the

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3561

equipment being provided, whether for example in the security area or for Conference Centre furnishings, will have a future government use. Decisions on the acquisition of equipment are made with future use in mind.
There are currently 4 Second Division, 27 Third Division and 13 Fourth Division personnel engaged full-time in my Department on preparations for the forthcoming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. Some of these are seconded from other departments.
Some additional staff will be taken on full time in preparation for the Meeting but the exact numbers will be determined as needs are identified.
A number of officers have as required been employed part time on preparations of an administrative and policy kind for the Meeting. Their numbers have varied and will continue to do so in accordance with need.
My Department's current estimate of expenditure on CHOGM is $12m. The greatest individual expenditure, about $6m, relates to security in Victoria. A substantial portion of this $6m will comprise transfer of funds from the Commonwealth to the State of Victoria to offset increased operating costs of the Victoria Police Force in providing the required security during CHOGM. Also included in the $6m for security is expenditure on security communications equipment such as portable radio transceivers and television surveillance equipment. Much of this equipment will have a Commonwealth use after the Meeting. Other major items of expenditure include residential accommodation, transport, fitting out of the Meeting venue, furniture, and the operating costs of the Task Force which has been established to handle the arrangements for the Meeting.
Australian Wheat Board: Borrowings
(Question No. 2275)
Mr Kerin asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:
(1) What is the current rate of interest at which funds are made available by the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank of Australia to the Australian Wheat Board.
(2) What is the equivalent commercial rate.
(3) What proportion of its total borrowings is the Australian Wheat Board likely to draw from the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank of Australia in 1981-82.
(4) What would be the cost of wheat growers if the subsidised rate of interest was withdrawn.
Mr Nixon-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) On 14 May 1981 the rate of interest at which funds would have been made available by the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank of Australia to the Australian Wheat Board was 11.5 per cent per annum.
(2) The Australian Wheat Board did not draw borrowings from commercial sources on 14 May 1981. However the AWB has heen provided with a representative sample of rates of interest for 14 May at which it could borrow by the issue of bank bills and promissory notes. These rates for different maturity periods would have varied from 16.2% per annum to 17.0% per annum.
(3) The borrowing arrangements for the AWB for 1981-82 cannot be determined until the Board's financing needs are established having regard to the size of the crop, the level of the guaranteed minimum delivery price and the Board's expenses for 1981-82.

(4) The estimate provided in 1980-81 Budget Paper No.4, Estimates of Receipts and Summary of Estimated Expenditure for the Year Ended 30 June 1981, for payments to the AWB for the reimbursement of additional commercial borrowing costs was $28.7m. The estimate of this cost has since heen revised to $24m.
Employment of Handicapped Persons
(Question No. 2321)
Mr Dawkins asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 27 May 1981:
(I) Are schools involved in the education of handicapped persons eligihle for funds under the school to work transition program.
(2) If so, what funds have been made available in each State for these schools during (a) 1980 and (b) the period! January to 26 May 1981.
(3) If these schools are not eligible to receive funds under the program are there any other programs under which the Commonwealth provides assistance for the employment of handicapped persons.
MI' Fife--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes.
(2) As a general program of assistance for the development of transition education programs for young people, Transition Program funding is provided to the States following Commonwealth approval of broad State 'package' proposals for schools and TAFE institutions rather than for specific areas of disadvantage such as handicapped persons. Under the Program guidelines the Commonwealth seeks to encourage education authorities in the States to take account of the needs of particular disadvantaged students, but it is for these authorities to determine priorities amongst individual proposals within the broad 'package' proposals approved by the Commonwealth. While it is not possible to identify all school projects specifically concerned with the handicapped, there have been a number of such projects funded and it is evident that the needs of the handicapped are being recognised by the responsible authorities.
(3) In addition to Transition Program funding, it is possible for handicapped persons attending special schools and classes to benefit from an employment point of view through the Commonwealth's Special Education Program administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission. This program aims to improve the quality and coverage of educational services for handicapped children by supplementing the funding of special schools and classes. While these funds are not specifically directed to assistance for the employment of handicapped persons, they may bc used for work experience and vocational training programs conducted by special schools and regular schools in which there are special classes. Within the Commonwealth's Special Education Program there is a Children in Residential Institutions element which funds projects designed to improve the educational prospects and to broaden the general experience of children living in institutions. It is possible for such projects to be concerned with transition, work experience and vocational training.
As far as programs outside the education area are concerned, the Departments of Social Security and of Employment and Youth Affairs administer programs and services designed to assist the employment of handicapped persons. Subsidies under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act and rehabilitation assistance through the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service are administered by the Department of Social Security. Through the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs disabled persons registered for employment

3562 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

may receive assistance under the National Employment and Training System to gain the skills necessary to obtain employment. Employment subsidies are provided for on-the-job training. A number of work preparation/training programs are funded and assistance for individuals to undertake formal training is available.
Tuition Fees in Universities and Colleges of Advanced Education
(Question No. 2322)
Mr Les Johnson asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 27 May 1981:
(1) Further to the Government's decision to introduce tuition fees in universities and colleges of advanced education for students undertaking degrees and diplomas subsequent to an initial tertiary qualification, which double degrees and diploma combinations permitted by tertiary institutions are not exempt from fees under the definition of recognised double degree or diploma combinations referred to in the statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1843).
(2) Are students to be considered as new enrolments for the purpose of being obliged to pay fees in 1982 if (a) they enrol prior to 1 January 1982, (b) they are registered as postgraduate students before 1 January 1982, (c) they had previously commenced post-graduate studies, discontinued them, and subsequently recommenced them after 1 January 1982 or (d) the tertiary institution obliges all post-graduate students who have commenced courses prior to 1 January 1982 to re-enrol.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) A full list of recognised combined courses, for which tuition fees will not be payable, will be announced later in the year.
(2) The new arrangements for the payment of tuition fees will apply to students enrolling to commence second or higher qualifications in 1982.
Adult Secondary Assistance Scheme
(Question No. 2439)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:
Will he explain what is meant by the Government's announcement that eligibility for the Adult Secondary Assistance Scheme will be restricted to those needing qualifications for employment (Hansard, 30 April 1981,page 1843).
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The Government's decision, following the Review of Commonwealth Functions, that eligibility under the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme will be restricted to those needing qualifications for employment will mean that as from 1 January 1982, only applicants who have indicated an employment objective for which completion of matriculation level studies is considered to be essential or highly desirable will be eligible for consideration under the scheme. Acceptable employment objectives will include those requiring completion of a tertiary qualification for which matriculation is a pre-requisite. It will be necessary in future for the employment objective to be stated on the application form.

Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme
(Question No. 2443)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:
(I) Have changes been proposed to the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme eligibility rules; if so, will students who previously have been granted independent status on the grounds of having lived in a de facto relationship for 2 years, or 1 year if there was a child involved, continue to be granted independent status.
(2) Will students who have previously claimed a dependent spouse allowance on the grounds of a de facto relationship continue to be able to claim that allowance.
(3) Will students who have previously been granted a living away from home allowance on the grounds of being over 21 years continue to be eligible for that allowance.
(4) Will students be able to claim dependants' allowances for a defactospouse in 1982.
(5) Are parents in receipt of a supporting parents benefit, who qualify for independent status on the grounds of having lived in a de facto relationship, able to earn $5,100 before the means test is applied; if so, with the abolition of a de facto relationship as grounds for independent status, will adjustments be made to ensure this higher non-means tested income will still apply to supporting parents.
(6) Has the Government any intention of changing the regulations that allow students to claim independent status by totalling their workforce participation over the previous five years.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes, following the Review of Commonwealth Functions there has been some modification of the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) eligibility rules which generally will take effect as from I January 1982. The general intention is also that students who have already qualified under the rules which have now been modified will continue to do so. Consequently, the decision, that participation in a de facto relationship will no longer qualify an applicant for independent status, wi1l not affect those students who have already qualified for independent status in this way. Those granted independent status on this basis prior to 1982 will retain that status.
(2) Yes, subject to their continuing to comply with the normal conditions of eligibility.
(3) The decision that students will no longer be able to qualify for the living away-from-home rate if, being 21 years of age or more, they choose to live away from home will also take effect as from 1January 1982. Students who have already qualified under the age 21 provision will continue to qualify on the same grounds after 1981 subject to their continuing to comply with other normal requirements.
(4) Yes.
(5) The provision whereby a sole parent, with a dependent child (or children) and who has independent status under TEAS, may be in receipt of $5,100 before the means test on personal income is applied is subject only to whether or not the child is wholly or substantially dependent on the applicant. It does not necessarily require that the applicant should be in receipt of supporting parent's benefit nor to have been involved in a de facto relationship. Students who have already qualified for this provision will continue to do so after 1981, while new applicants as from I January 1982 wi\l be assessed against the ongoing requirements for independent status.

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3563

(6) No. Students will continue to be eligible to apply for independent status if they have been employed full-time in the workforce for periods totalling two years out of the previous five. However, one of tbe decisions following the Review of Commonwealth Functions was that periods of registration for employment which do not involve the receipt of unemployment benefits may now be taken into account in determining the two year qualifying period for independent status, provided the student was unemployed and in Australia and available for full-time work. This relaxation of the rules will take effect as from 1 January 1982.
Homeless Persons Advisory Committees
(Question No. 114)
Mr Les Johnson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:
What recommendations made since December 1977 by the Homeless Persons Advisory Committees (a) have been accepted, (b) have been rejected or (c) are still under consideration by the Government.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
Since 1977, the State Homeless Persons Advisory Committees, which have now been abolished, commented on a wide range of issues and on various Commonwealth Government programs. It is not appropriate to respond to the question in terms of recommendations accepted, rejected or under consideration, because: (i) in addition to the 77 recorded separate recommendations from the various State Committees, some of which have been provided by more than one State Committee, an unknown number of recommendations were made orally in discussions with the former Minister and officers of the Department; (ii) in the nature of Advisory Committees, the expression of views and discussion of issues is as important as (was) the submission of formal recommendations.
Important issues raised by the Advisory Committees include:
amendment of the Homeless Persons Assistance Act to broaden the range of services provided to homeless people;
facilities and services to be provided to categories of homeless people other than the chronically homeless;
an expansion and increase in recurrent subsidies provided under the Homeless Persons Assistance Act; and
an expansion in the allocation of capital funds to the Homeless Persons Assistance Program.

The major initiatives in services for homeless people which reliect the recommendations of the Advisory Committees are:
the Homeless Persons Assistance Act was amended in 1979 to remove all references to a prescribed period, which previously limited the operation of the Act;
the Youth Services Scheme for homeless youth, whiGh is funded jointly by the Commonwealth and State Governments, provides emergency accommodation as well as counselling and referral services to homeless young people up to the age of 18 years;
the regulations of the Homeless Persons Assistance Act have been amended to increase the level of food and accommodation, and meal subsidies paid to voluntary organisations providing these services to homeless people;
the Government's allocation of $10m to a three year capital funding program for homeless persons, with special provisions for homeless young people. I have already announced the first stage of this program and will make a further announcement of projects approved for funding in the near future,
Lost or Damaged Defence Equipment
(Question No. 205)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 November 1980:

(3) Were official inquiries conducted into each accident; if not, why not.
(4) Where inquiries were conducted. what were the findings with regard to (a) the cause and (b) actions that should be taken with respect of the losses.

Department of the Prime Minister: Special Arrangements fol' Disabled Persons
(Question No 458)
Mr Holding asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:
(1) In view of the fact that 1981 is designated as the International Year of Disabled Persons, what special arrangements has his Department made to assist disabled persons.

Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The Government has given its full support to the International Year of Disabled Persons. The situation with the Public Service Board and departments generally is as follows:
(1) The Government and the Public Service Board have a policy of equal employment opportunity in the Australian Public Service. That policy is in keeping with the Government's endorsement of 'access to all aspects of community

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3565

life' as one of the themes of IYDP. The policy of equal employment opportunity applies to disabled people seeking employment, or already employed, in the Australian Public Service.
Disabled people employed in the Public Service receive the same rates of pay, have the same job classifications, have the same terms and conditions of employment and have the same promotion opportunities as their non-disabled peers in comparable jobs.
1981 marks the end of a decade of active involvement by the Public Service Board to ensure that disabled people have equality of opportunity in the Australian Public Service. The full list of steps taken by the Board is quite extensive. I will forward to the Honourable Member a resume of these initiatives, together with other material produced by the Public Service Board on the employment of disabled people in the Australian Public Service.
As part of its commitment to the IYDP the Public Service Board is consolidating and extending its recruitment-based activities to ensure that people with disabilities continue to achieve. equal access to the Service. The Board has produced special recruitment literature and posters which aim to imform disabled people that they can apply for jobs in the Public Service and expect to get 'a fair go'. Special recruitment activities, using this new literature, have been planned for 1981. The Public Service will also continue to provide work therapy opportunities for up to 200 rehabilitees in 1981 under the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service's work therapy scheme. The Board's activities to promote equal access to the Public Service and the recruitment of disabled people is an integral part of its equal employment opportunity program, a program which will continue well beyond 1981.
The Public Service Board is concerned that equality of employment not be viewed solely as a matter involving recruitment and placement of disabled people. Other important facets of equal employment opportunity, in which departments have an important role to play, include induction and orientation, access and job site modification, personnel development and training and rehabilitation of disabled staff. Permanent Heads of all departments have given the Board their full and active support for the implementation ofEEO for disabled staff in this and future years.
To assist departments to focus on the needs of their disabled staff the Board is also conducting a series of seminars for senior managers on the employment of people with disabilities. The seminar series commenced in May and will continue on a monthly basis during 1981 and into early 1982.
Departments have already taken steps to improve the employment position of their disabled staff. For example, the Department of Industrial Relations is consulting with its disabled employees concerning access, modification of amenities, training and career opportunities. It is also fostering a greater consciousness amongst its staff of the problems faced by disabled people, modifying amenities to reduce difficulties for disabled employees and training stafr in the supervision of disabled employees.
The Department of Employment and Youth Affairs, which is heavily involved in IYDP through the Government's programs for the employment of disabled people in the broader community has been expending considerable effort to modify the working environment, to obtain aids and provide induction, training and developmental programs for its disabled employees.
In the Department of Defence a special video program has been produced showing disabled staff at work in the Department. The video promotes positive attitudes towards the employment of disabled people. The Department of Transport is also planning an education program to inform staff about the

disabled, their rights as individuals and citizens and the causes and prevention of disablement.
The Department of Housing and Construction, as part of its commitment to IYDP, has undertaken a survey of staff to determine the number of disabled people employed, the nature of the disability and the difficulties they face in the work environment. This survey indicated that 6.4 percent of its staff were disabled. The Department of Capital Territory is also undertaking a survey of its staff.
2(a) The Public Service Board, the employing authority in the Australian Public Service, has Special Placement Officers in each of its Regional Offices to assist in the recruitment and placement of disabled people. Special Placement Officers are able to arrange modified selection tests which take into account the applicant's disability e.g. for blind applicants tests can be administered in braille or on tape, for deaf applicants an interpreter can be provided.
In 1980 the Special Placement Officers assisted 802 disabled applicants, of whom 251 were placed in employment. 20 percent of disabled applicants gained permanent jobs in the Public Service. This compares favourably with non-disabled applicants where only 15 percent were permanently appointed to comparable positions. Departments which took a substantial number of special placements during 1980 included Defence, Education, Employment and Youth Affairs, Home Affairs and Environment, Social Security and Veterans' Affairs, together with the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Australian Taxation Office. All departments accept, wherever possible, disabled new entrants referred to them by the Special Placement Officers.
The steps being taken by the Board to further increase the numbers of disabled people employed in the Public Service are detailed in (1) above.
2(b) There is a long-standing policy of ensuring that public buildings constructed by the Commonwealth permit reasonable access by disabled people and comply with the Australian Standards relating to Design Rules for Access by the Disabled. Access for disabled people has been provided in such buildings as the FamilyjChildren's Court building and the Public Service Board's McLachlan Offices in Canberra. The Australian Defence Force Academy will include in certain areas special facilities for the disabled. The provision of facilities for disabled people is included in the refurbishment program for the Administrative Building, occupied by the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Attorney-General's.
In its capacity as the central property authority, the Department of Administrative Services, in conjunction with the Department of Housing and Construction, is implementing a strategy for access modifications to Commonwealth-owned buildings. This involves a survey of over 500 buildings to identify any necessary modification work. Details on the Government's activities were provided by my colleague Mr McVeigh in answer to question 483 on 26 March 1981 (Hansard Page 1062).
(3) Departmental IYDP programs are being funded within their overall 1980-81 budget allocations. The Commonwealth however has provided substantial funds as part of its commitment to IYDP. They include provision of:
$lm (over two financial years) for a national publicity and community information campaign.
$500,000 to the Australian Council for the Rehabilitation of the Disabled (ACROD) for the establishment of a national headquarters in Australia.
$400,000 in the Children's Services Program for innovative projects for disabled children and their families.
$250,000 in 1980-81 to the Department of Housing and Construction to commence access modification works in 27 Commonwealth-owned buildings.

3566 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

S700,ooO in 1980-81 towards the provision of a range of aids to daily Jiving under the new program of aids for disabled people.

Vietnam: Use of Herbicides and Pesticides
(Question No. 493)
Mr Holding asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:
(1) Has the Attorney-Genera!'s attention been drawn to the article headed 'KRIEGSRAISON GEHT VOR KRIEGSRECHT-The cause of War goes before the Law of War' (Pacific Defence Reporter, November 1980, pages S9 to 68).
(2) If so, has the Attorney-General or the AttorneryGenera!'s Department or any of the Attorney-General's predecessors provided any Australian Government with a legal opinion since January 1965 on whether herbicides and pesticides used in Vietnam during the war there were or were not covered by the 1925 Geneva Convention on chemical and bacteriological warfare.
(3) If an opinion was provided, will the Attorney-General present it to the Parliament.
(4) If the Attorney-General does not propose to present the opinion will he give the substance of it; if not, why not.
(5) If no opinion has been provided before 24 February 1981, has one been requested by the Governments since January 1980.
Mr Viner-The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) Yes.
(2) The Attorney-General has not provided any such opinion. There is no record of any such written opinion by a former Attorney-General or by the Department.
(3) See (2).
(4) Does not apply. The honourable member's attention is drawn to the usual practice under which the Government does not reveal the content oflegal advice.
(5) No.
Coastal Surveillance: Expenditure by Department ofDefence
(Question No. 565)
Mr Morrison asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

(1) What sum was (a) appropriated and (b) actually spent by his Department on coastal surveillance for (i) 1977-78, (ii) 1978-79 and (iii) 1979-80.
(2) What were the main items of expenditure and cost attributed to each item.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) (a), (b) and (2) No amounts are specifically appropriated to the Department of Defence for expenditure on coastal surveillance. Expenditure on coastal surveillance activities is funded from the appropriations covering all activities of the Defence Force. It is not practicable, other than by apportioning on an arbitrary basis or by historical costing, to separate expenditure on each activity such as surveillance.
Estimates of the direct costs of coastal surveillance are made, based on records of Coastal Surveillance activities undertaken by the Defence Force. The estimated direct costs in 1977-78, 1978-79 and 1979-80 at historical prices, are as follows:

The estimates exclude Army Nomad aircraft activity in 1978-79 and 1979-80 for which costs were recovered from the relevant department.
Vietnam: Use of Herbicides and Pesticides
(Question No. 586)
Mr Holding asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:
Further to his answer to a question without notice from the honourable member for Capricornia on the subject of herbicides and pesticides used in Vietnam, (Hansard, 18 September 1980, pages 1472 and 1473), can he now state (a) was he referring to the group of Ministers, or the Inter-Departmental Committee, or both, when speaking of all the Defence Department documents relating to chemicals sprayed in Vietnam during hostilities there, having been referred to the group which is considering all the ramifications of the issue, (b) what aspects of the question were referred, to which offices were they referred, and when were they referred, (c) have the relevant officers now provided him with the answers sought in whole or in part; if so, what are the details and (d) if the answers sought have not yet been provided to him, will he (i) undertake to obtain those answers as a matter of urgency and (ii) make an undertaking to supply those answers to the honourable member for Capricornia and myself; if not, why not.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The Department of Defence has contributed to a comprehensive report, co-ordinated by the Department of Health, on the use and Effects ofpesticides.
A copy of the Report, entitled: 'Pesticides Used in Vietnam Hostilities and their Use in Australian Agriculture: A Comparative Study', is being placed in the Parliamentary Library.

Defence Service Home Loans
(Question No. 631)
Mr Humphl-eys asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:
(1,) Is it a fact that members of the Australian defence forces with entitlement to a defence service home loan, have on occasion, had to forgo the opportunity to finalise purchase of a house, and, in addition, have incurred considerable expense, due to delays in obtaining evidence of service from the Central Army Records Office.
:.
. (2) If so, what action will he take to expedite the loan authorisation process.
MrKillen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) While I understand that some delays in providing evidence of service to support applications for Defence Service Homeslqans occasionally occur, the Defence Service Homes Corporation has confirmed that the service provided by the Central Army Records Office is most satisfactory. I am aware of only one recent instance where a Serviceman was unable to finalise the purchase of a house because of a delay in the provision of evidence of service. In this instance the delay was caused by a telephoned request for details being inadvertently not actioned.
(2) The'Central Army Records Office and the Defence Service Homes Corporation have now instituted a procedure whereby all requests for information are to be in writing, although urgent requests may be preceded by a telephone call.
Invalid Pensions: Electoral Division ofPerth
(Question No. 707)
Mr McLean asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 4 March 1981:
(1) How many persons in the electoral division of Perth were granted an invalid pension in (a) 1978-79 and (b) 1979-80.
(2) Have-there been any changes since 1 January 1980 in the interpretation of Section 23 of the Social Services Act regarding the assessment of eligibility for an invalid pension; if so,
(a) what changes have taken place and
(b) from what date did the changes become operative.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) The Department of Social Security does not maintain as part of its regular statistical collections statistics of grants of invalid pension by electoral division. The number of invalid pensions granted in Western Australia was 3399 during 1978-79 and 2991 during 1979-80. The number of persons in the electoral division of Perth in receipt of an invalid pension was 2380 at 30 June 1979 and 2440 at 30 June 1980.
(2) There has been no change in the eligibility criteria for invalid pension since 1 January 1980. In order to qualify for an invalid pension a claimant must be permanently incapacitated for work to the extent of at least 85 percent or be permanently blind. Determination of whether this qualification is met is made in conformity with established medical criteria which take into account the degree of the claimant's impair. ment together with relevant facts about the applicant such as age, sex, education, lack of skills and personal disabilities. In

reaching its decision, my Department is guided by the opinion of the Department of Health.
However, during the period in question there have been changes in the procedures for processing invalid pension applications.
New claim forms and associated documents have been introduced (the former Minister for Social Security advised the Senate of the introduction of the new claim form on 20 February 1980).
Additionally, on a State by State basis, a system was progressively implemented over the period January to September 1980 under which medical reports prepared by Commonwealth Medical Officers are reviewed by senior medical officers in the Department of Health. This procedure was designed to ensure consistency in the application of the criteria throughout Australia.
Further, on 7 May 198] the Minister for Health and I issued revised guidelines for use in the assessment of eligibility for invalid pension. These clarify the eligibility criteria stated above and are publicly available.
Vietnam: Use of Herbicides and Pesticides
(Question No. 719)
Mr Holding asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 March 1981:
(I) What (a) Australian and (b) foreign companies, operating in Australia between 1960 and 1972, supplied chemicals to Australian defence forces for use as herbicides and pesticides in Vietnam during hostilities there.
(2) For each of those companies, what was the (a) generic name and trade name of each of the chemicals supplied, (b) quantity of each chemical supplied, (c) cost of each supply contract, and (d) period during which chemicals were supplied.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) and (2) Information about the sources, types and quantities of herbicides purchased for use in Vietnam is contained in a report co-ordinated by the Department of Health, entitled: 'Pesl :cides Used in Vietnam Hostilities and their Use in Australian Agriculture: A Comparative Study.' A copy of the report is being placed in the parliamentary Library. Information on the use of chemicals in Vietnam is being sought by the Commonwealth Institute of Health from participants in its pilot epidemiological study.
The Department of Defence has provided information on the use of herbicides in Vietnam to the Institute. It will continue to co-operate in providing whatever other available information is sought by the Institute.
Service Pensions
(Question No. 766)
Mrs Kelly asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice on 11 March 1981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to the long delays of up to 3 months suffered by pension applicants as a result of the inability of his Department to make available the necessary Service documents.
(2) What are the reasons for these delays and will action be taken to rectify this situation.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

3568 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

There are three classes of pension applicants necessitating provision of documentation by the Department of Defence in support of their applications. These classes are:
(a) Service personnel applying for retirement benefits, on other than invalidity grounds, to the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits (DFRDB) Authority;
(b) Service personnel applying for retirement benefits, on invalidity grounds, to the DFRDB Authority; and
(c) Ex-Service personnel applying for repatriation benefits to the Department of Veterans' Affairs.
The majority of such pension applications are those to the DFRDB Authority relating to retirements on other than invalidity grounds. During the period from 1 January 1981 to 12 May 1981 the average time between date of discharge and receipt of the necessary documents by the DFRDB Authority was:
Navy-5days Army-2days Air Force-3 days
In cases of retirement on invalidity grounds, more detailed documentation is required before the DFRDB Authority can commence its consideration of the applications. This documentation includes Service Medical Board reports and details of the Service member's skills, qualifications and experience.
Generally, a longer time is required than that taken to provide documentation for retirements on other than invalidity grounds, and Some delays occasionally occur due to the complexity of individual cases.
For the small number of repatriation benefit applications which require documentation from the Department of Defence, the details are usually forwarded to the Department of Veterans' Affairs within two weeks. Again, where files have to be retrieved from archives or where subsequent investigations of circumstances surrounding the application are required to be carried out, the provision of all documentation may be delayed.
The Department of Defence treats all requests for such supporting documentation as expeditiously as possible
Public Trustee, Australian Capital Territory
(Question No. 774)
Mrs Kelly asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:
(1) Is it a fact that there is no Public Trustee in the Australian Capital Territory; if so, what action has been taken to provide alternative facilities for Australian Capital Territory residents who wish to make their wills naming the Public Trustee as executor.
(2) When will the (a) Public Trustee Ordinance and (b) Mental Health Ordinance be completed.
(3) What fees structure applies in the matters handled by the Australian Capital Territory Curator of Deceased Estates.
Mr Viner-The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) Yes; Where the Curator of Estates of Deceased Persons, a statutory officer under the Administration and Probate Ordinance 1929, is appointed by will to act the Supreme Court may grant him an order to collect and administer the estate of any deceased person leaving property within the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) (a) 1 expect that the Public Trustee Ordinance will be available for submission to the House of Assembly before the end of this year.

(b) Administrative responsibility for the proposed Mental Health Ordinance rests with the Minister for Health. I am informed that the Minister intends that a draft Ordinance will be ready for referral to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly later this year, the International Year of Disabled Persons, with every effort being made to have the Ordinance in operation before the end of the year.
(3) Under section 87 of the Administration and Probate Ordinance 1929, the Curator is required to charge an estate, which he is administering, commission at the rate of 5 per cent on:
(a) all moneys in the estate which he collects, including money received as income or from the realization of assets; and
(b) the value, fixed by the Curator, of property transferred to a beneficiary where the property is not converted into money.
The requirement to charge commission does not apply to an estate the value of which does not exceed $30,000.
Australian National University: Student Fees
(Question No. 804)
Mr Rocher asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 12 March 1981:
Does the statute adopted by the Australian National University pursuant to the Australian National University Amend ment Act 1979 reflect the policy and intentions of the Government in seeking a reduction of services and amenities fees for students who do not wish to have part of the fees they have paid appropriated for socio-political purposes; if not, will the Government frame further legislative amendments to ensure that its requirements are met.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The purpose of the Student Organisations (Amenities and Services) Statute is to prescribe the amenities and services on which fees monies compulsorily collected from all students may be spent. Where the Council of the University makes compulsory fees monies available to a student organisation for the provision by that organisation of amenities or services, then it is the duty of the Council to ensure that the monies are applied only in respect of amenities and services that are not of an academic nature, that are of direct benefit to the University, and that have been declared in a University statute to be amenities or services in respect of that organisation.
The current provisions of the Australian National University Act enable the University to charge lower fees to students who indicate their wish not to join particular student associations, but do not require the University to do so. It has been the Government's wish for the University to act to see that students who join a particular student organisation pay a separate membership fee, the proceeds of which are to be directed towards supporting voluntary activities which are not eligible for support from the proceeds of the compulsory fee for amenities and services payable by all students. Such an arrangement would present a clear distinction between the students who choose to join an organisation and those who do not.
The Government, after reviewing the operation of the 1979 amendments at the Australian National University during 1980, decided to introduce further amending legislation which has now passed both Houses of Parliament. The purpose of this legislation is threefold. First, it makes income derived from the application of compulsory student fees moneys subject to the same conditions as the fees themselves. Second, where both compulsory fees moneys and other moneys are applied with the effect of producing income, that income must

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3569

be apportioned according to the applications. Third, the administrative expenses of student organisations must also be apportioned, so that only activities devoted to the provision of student amenities and services can be a charge on compulsory fees moneys. With the enactment of this legislation, the Government is confident that compulsory fees moneys cannot be used by student organisations directly or indirectly for the funding of socio.political activities.
North West Cape Communications System
(Question No. 975)
Mr Holding asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 31 March 1981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to the testimony before the United States of America House of Representatives Subcommittee on Military Construction Appropriations in 1979 to the effect that the US Navy has requested $2.5m to construct at North West Cape a ground terminal for the Fleet Satellite Communications (FLTSATCOM) System and the Defence Satellite Communications System (DSCS).
(2) Is it a fact that an agreement has been made between the Australian and US Governments that North West Cape is to be a ground terminal for the FLTSATCOM system.
(3) If so, is the ground station to be constructed at North West Cape for the FLTSATCOM system the same terminal as that previously announced for the DSCS at North West Cape.
(4) If it is not the same terminal what is the formal desig. nation of the new FLTSATCOM terminal and when is it to become operational.
(5) Has a contract been let for the supply of AN WSC-3 UHF radio equipment to the Royal Australian Navy and are WSC-3 radio sets to be installed on all units of the Fleet and most RAN shore establishments.
(6) Is he able to say whether the AN WSC-3 UHF satellite communications equipment produced by E-Systems Inc. (ECI Division) of St Petersburg, Florida, USA, was devel. oped specifically as part of the US Navy's Fleet Satellite Communications System.
(7) Are the RAN'S new AN WSC-3 radio sets to operate through the US Navy's FLTSATCOM satellites; if so, will FLTSATCOM ground terminals other than that at North West Cape be used for controlling satellites used by the WSC-3 radio equipment installed on RAN vessels.
(8) If other FLTSATCOM ground terminals are to be used, where are they located.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) Yes. The appropriation request for $2.5m relates to the construction associated with the installation of the GSC-39 V(I) satellite communications ground terminal (formerly designated MSC-61), at North West Cape. I informed Parliament in March 1979 that installation of this terminal had the Government's support. The terminal will be part of the Defence Satellite Communications System (DSCS III), not the Fleet Satellite Communications System (FLTSATCOM).
(2), (3) and (4) There are no plans for an additional FLTSATCOM terminal to be installed at North West Cape. The station has had a FLTSATCOM receive-only terminal in operation for several years.
(5) A contract was placed with E-System Inc. (ECI Division) of St Petersburg, Florida, USA in April 1980 for the provision of AN/WSC-3 (RAN VI) UHF transceivers and ancillary equipment. These radios will be fitted in most RAN ships and shore establishments. It should be noted that the

UN's AN/WSC-3 equipment and the RAN's AN/WSC.3 (RAN VI) equipment are similar but not identical radios.
(6) Both the ANjWSC.3and AN/WSC.3 (RAN VI) radios arc intended for use on normal line of sight tactical radio circuits. It would not be correct to say that they were developed specifically as part of the FLTSATCOM system.
(7) Some ancillary equipments have b~en ordered for the AN /WSC-3 (RAN VI) equipment to permit access to FLTSA TCOM satellites to provide communications interoperability at sea with ships of our allies. The. ground stations which control access to the com111unications channels on the FLTSATCOM sateliites are lo-cated at Norfolk Virginia, Honolulu, Guam, Stockton California: and Naples Italy. The ground terminal at North West Cape can only receive messages from FLTSATCOM satellites, not transmit them. Nor can it control them.
(8) The FLTSATeOM system is a US system and the US places its ground stations (and mobile stations) according to its own needs. With regard to the Australian equipment, there are no plans for accessing the F.LTSATCOM system other than those referred to in the answer to part 7.
Royal Australian Air Force Drivers: Exposure to Malathion Vapour
(Question No. 992)
Mr Holding asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 April 1981 :
(I) Was there an incident involving 2 Royal Australian Air Force drivers in Mt Isa, Queensland, on 7 November 1980 which necessitated their hospitalisation following their exposure to Malathion vapour from.corroded drums; if so will he now table in the House the following documents: (a) BSDAR 2126j133EQ Ptl (8) of 19 November 1980, (b) DI(AF)SUP lOA Report AMSDAR Ij80 of 19 November 1980, (c) BSFBN SIG MOP H470 of 4 August 1980, (d) BSFBN 2119jl1l/EQ Ptl (51) of 5 January 1981, 2SD 704/3jPl Ptl (9) of 27 January 1981 and (f) DEFAIR QM767 jDMOVT-AF of24 January 1981.
(2) If he will not table these documents, what is the reason.
(3) What was the reason for the transfer of the Maldis'on (Malathion) from Sydney to Darwin.
(4) Has any further action been taken, other than that outlined by Group Captain L. D. Wilkinson in his report dated 4 March 1981, Ref. 2122/1/2493 Ptl (B), to ensure proper precautions to safeguard service personnel against the hazards of toxic chemicals.
Mr KiIlen--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) and (2) Yes. Two RAAF drivers were held overnight at Mt Isa hospital on 7 November 1980 for observation after exposure to Malathion. They were subsequently treated as out-patients at the Base Medical Flight, RAAF Base Darwin between 13 and 16 November 1980, during which time, blood specimens were taken for analysis. When last seen by the Senior Medical Officer RAAF Darwin on 16 November 1980, the drivers were free from any symptoms of effects from the exposure. The documents requested can be tabled and I will arrange for this to be done as soon as possible. However, the names of two non-commissioned officers involved in this incident have been blanked out of these documents because a formal inquiry into this matter was not convened and the individuals were not given the protection of the Air Force Rule of Procedures 125A (B).
(3) The Malathion was required by RAAF Darwin for use by the Hygiene Section for insect control.
(4) All drums of Malathion held are being inspected for possible corrosion. The general matter of pesticide use in the

3570 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Defence Force is monitored by the Pesticides Sub-Committee of the Medical Services Advisory Committee. A comprehensive Joint Service Manual on the handling and use of pesticides is being produced by this Sub-Committee.

(the Department was formed in December 1976), (b) 619,

(c) 704, (d) 830 and (e) 657.

(2) The total cost of this air travel was $596,730.

Movement of Freight and Personnel between Australia and Butterworth Air Base
(Question No. 1090)
Mr Morrison asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 Apri11981:
What was the cost of chartering aircraft for the movement of freight and personnel between Australia and Butterworth Air Base, Malaysia, during (a) 1977-78, (b) 1978-79, (c) 1979-80 and (d) the period lJuly-31 December 1980.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
All aircraft chartered during the specified periods were used for the movement of personnel between Australia and Butterworth Air Base, Malaysia. No aircraft were chartered for the movement of freight. The hire charges for the aircraft chartered were as follows:
(a) 1977-78; $1,098,350 (b) 1978-79; $673,800 (e) 1979-80; $101,000 (d) 1 July 1980 to 31 December 1980; Nil

Defence Services: Resignations
(Question No. 1162)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:

(1) How many (a) officers, (b) non-commissioned officers and (c) other ranks (i) resigned and (ii) failed to re-engage in each Service for each quarter of each year since 1976.

(2) How many of these personnel were (a) technicaily skilled and (b) non-technically skilled (i) males and (ii) females.

(3) What proportion of the existing current strength of each service do the (a) males and (b) females who (i) resigned and (ii) failed to re-engage constitute.

Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

Table I presents the data for officers and other ranks who resigned and failed to re-engage, by service for each quarter of each year since 1976. The table does not differentiate between non-commissioned officers and other ranks as this information is not held by the Services in a readily accessible formal.

The division of technically and non-technically skilled per-

sonnel who have left the Services is shown at Table 2. Navy

figures incorporate 990 personnel, who over the period,

elected to leave the Service on free discharge. Because of

Navy personnel statistical limitations these sailors cannot be

readily classified into technical and non-technical categories.

Army does not hold the req uired information in a readily

available formal. However, figures were for the calendar year 1980. These figures

einxctlruadceteadllmfoarnmusalolyf

discharge but are considered by Army Office as being rep-

resentative of the previous four years in indicating the relative

loss rate of technical personnel.

Table 3 shows the specific wastage rates requested expressed as a percentage of December 1980 strengths.

Family Assistance Payments
(Question No. 1187)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 8 April 1981:
(1) Has the Minister or the Department of Social Security received representations from certain organisations expressing concern over some aspects of the discontinuance of family assistance payments through the Queensland Department of Children's services and the transfer of this responsibility to the Department of Social Security.
(2) Have additional counter or clerical staff been appointed to the Department to deal with extra clients.
(3) Is it anticipated that up to 12,000 extra clients will be dealt with by the Department as a result of the transfer.
(4) Has any provision been made for extra social work staff for women in crisis.
(5) What provisions have been made for immediate cash payments for women in desperate circumstances who may have difficulty in cashing a cheque.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(l) About ten representations concerning this transfer of responsibility have been received.
(2) Some additional clerical staff have been allocated where necessary to ensure that undue delays do not occur.
(3) It is estimated that an additional 7,600 claims for supporting parent's benefit were received in Queensland during the period to 8 May 1981, and that some 6,800 sole parents were granted supporting parent's benefit during the same period solely as a result of the reduction in 'waiting period' for supporting parent's benefit as from I November 1980. It is not known what proportion of these people would have previously been eligible for Family Assistance Payments.
(4) Although no additional social work staff have been appointed, the Department is providing a service to those in urgent need of assistance. In addition, the Department of Children's Services in Queensland is continuing to provide the family counselling services which have traditionally been the responsibility of the State Government.
(5) No provisions have been made for immediate cash payments of benefits; however it is extremely rare that complaints

(Question No. 1212)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

(3) Has his attention been drawn to the fact that when a similar question was answered by a number of Ministers in 1976, it was claimed that obtaining the information would involve collection of detailed information from a diversity of records and sources, and would therefore require unjustifiable use of staff resources.
(4) Has the development of forward estimates in his Department now been advanced to a stage where a similar reply is no longer valid.
Mr Nixon-In answer to the honourable member's question I would refer him to the reply provided to Question No. 1216 by the Minister for Finance which appears in the weekly Hansard of 10 June 1981.

Employment of Private Consultants: Department ofPrimary Industry
(Question No. 1264)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(1) Were any private consultants or consultancy firms employed by his Department in 1979-80; if so (a) how many were employed, (b) who were they, (c) for what purpose was each employed, and (d) what payments were made to each consultant or consultancy firms.
Mr Nixon-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) A total of seven consultants and one consultancy firm were employed by my Department in 1979-80. Who the consultants or consultancy firms were, the purpose for which they were employed and the payments made to each are detailed below.

(a) Dr A. A. Seawright-employed to produce a monograph on toxicological diseases of animals in Australia-Payment $6,000.00
(b) Professor W. 1. B. Beveridge-employed to produce a monograph on microbiological diseases of animals in Australia-Payment $4,000.00
(c) Dr D. M. Flynn-employed to provide a written report on feral animal control in Australia-Payment $8,000.00
(d) Mr R. R. Pascoe-employed to provide a survey of the needs of the Australian horse industry-Payment $7,000.00
(e) China Consulting and Translation Servicesemployed to provide translation and transcription services during visits by Chinese Vice-Minister for Agricultural Machinery and ,visit by Chinese Sheep and Wool Mission. This firm has also provided ad-hoc translations and transcriptions services-Payment $5,349.00
(f) Ass. Prof. P. Courteney--'-employed to provide a contribution to a report on rural research in Northern Australia-Payment $113.35
(g) Prof. C. G. E. Downing-employed to produce a report on agricultutal engineering, research, development and extension in Australia-Payment $4,017.60
(h) Prof. Freeburn and Mr Edwards-employed to produce a paper on the measuring of a country's gain from research theory and application-Payment $800.00.

Employment of Private Consultants: Department of Defence

(Question No. 1267)

Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 April 1981 :

(1) Were any private consultants or' consultancy firms employed by the Department of Defence in 1979-80; ifso,

(2) How many were employed,

(3) Who were they,

(4) For what purpose was each employed and,

(5) What payments were made to each consultant or con-

sultancy firm.

'

Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) Yes-but it should be understood that, in the context of the Public Service Board 'Guidelines for the Engagement of
Consultants and Contractors for Services-May 1978', all outside lecturers and guest session leaders engaged for Defence Force and Departmental approved courses of training are regarded as consultants. These persons are paid sessional fees at the rates prescribed in the Rates of Pay Manual. Examples of this type of consultant are: Eminent persons who lecture to the Joint Services Staff College and individuals who led sessions at Pre-Retirement Counselling seminars.

(2) Excluding outsid'e lecturers a total of 12 individuals and 7 consultancy firms were engaged during 1979-80.

(3,4 and 5) See attached list for details.

Employment of Private Consultants: Department of Finance
(Question No. 1268)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, 9 April 1981:
Were any private consultants or consultancy firms employed by.the Department of Finance in 1979-80; if so
(a) how many were employed; (b) who were they; (c) for what purpose was each employed; and (d) what payments were made to each consultant or con-
sultancy firm.
Mr Howard-The Minister for Finance has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(a) one consultancy firm was employed by the Department of Finance
(b) PA Consultancy Services Pty Ltd

(c) The firm was engaged to undertake the study of options for meeting the Royal Australian Mint's long-term requirements for coinage blanks
(d) $27,770
Employment of Private Consultants: Attorney-General's Department
(Question No. 1270)
Mr ~ungey asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 April 1981 :
Were any. private consultants or consultancy firms employed by the Attorney-Genera]'s Department in 1979-80; if so, (a) how many were employed, (b) who were they, (c) for what purpose was each employed and (d) what payments were made to each consultant or consultancy firm.
Mr Viner--The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
During the year 1979-80 the following consultants were employed:

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3577

(a) Mr J. Q. Ewens, for the purpose of drafting necessary legislation in preparation for self-government of Norfolk Island. A consultants fee of $162 per day was paid.
(b) Mr C. K. Comans, for the purpose of drafting complex and extensive Commonwealth and State legislation for the Office of Parliamentary Counsel. A consultants fee of $162 per day was paid.
(c) Mrs M. E. Heiskenan, for the purpose of preparing taxation returns for the Office of the Curator of Estates of Deceased Persons; Australian Capital Territory. A consultants fee of $50 per day was paid.
Recruitment through Private Employment Agencies: Department of Education
(Question No. 1300)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
Were any staff of his Department or statutory authorities under his aegis recruited through private employment agencies in 1979-80; if so, for what position and at what cost.
Mr Fife--'-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
One person was recruited through a private employment agency in 1979-80, for the position of Steno-Secretary Grade 1 to the Principal, Canberra College of Technical and Further Education. The cost was $691. This was done with the approval of the Public Service Inspector's regional office, which was unable at the time to provide a qualified officer, pending the filling of the position on a permanent basis.

Industrial Action: Department of Defence

(Question No. 1371)

Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

(1) How many officers or employees' in his' Department have been (a) on strike and (b) engaged in go slow, work to regulations or other restrictive work actions, in each of the last two years.

(2) How many manhours were involved in these actions.

(3) Were any officers or employees on strike action paid by the Commonwealth during the strike; if so on what occassions.

(4) Were any pay reductions or qisciplinary. actions taken

in respect of officers or employees on go slow; work to regula-

tions or other restrictive work actions, if so, on what

occassions.

.

Mr Killen-The answe~ t9 the honourable

member's question is as follows:

(1) The Department does not keep records on whether an

individual officer or employee has been on strike or engaged in

any restrictive work actions. However, it is possible to identify

several groups of employees who have engaged in such activi-

ties during each of the last two years. These groups include

employees' at Williamstown and Garden' Island. Dockyards,

foremen, storemen and packers, and a substantial number of

officers in the Clerical grades. It is th~refore possible to esti-

mate the number of officers or employees who have been on

strike or who have engaged in restrictive work action at 'ap-

proximately 6500.

.

,

(2) During the year ende(l 31 March 1980, 182,605 manhours were lost through strikes. DurIng the year ended 31 March 1981, 474,459 manhours wete lost through strikes. Of the latter figure 222,092 manhours were lost in one dispute, concerning the manning of the Plate Preservation Line at Williamstown Dockyard. Because of the nature of restrictive work actions it has not been possible to ascertain the number of manhours involved in them.

(3) No officers or employees have been paid for any periods during which they have been on strike.

(4) Most employees whose conditions of employment are governed by Public Service Arbitrator's Determination No. 44 of 1955 normally receive a naval work adjustment allowance. This allowance currentlly rariges between $3.60 and $9.40 per week. When these employees, most of whom are employed at Williamstown and Garden Island Dockyards, engage in any restrictive work practices this allowance is not paid. On occassions, management has insisted that employees perform work that is under ban or limitation. Upon refusal the paY'of the individuals concerned has been stopped.

Industrial Action: Department of Education
(Question No. 1378)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 9 Apri11981:
(1) How many officers or employees in his Department have been
(a) on strike; and (b) engaged in go slow, work to regulations or other re-
strictive work actions, in each of the last two years.

3578 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

(2) How many manhours were involved in these actions.
(3) Were any officers or employees on strike action paid by the Commonwealth during the strike; if so, on what occassions.
(4) Were any pay reductions or disciplinary actions taken in respect of officers or employees on go slow, work to regulations or other restrictive work actions; if so, on what occassions.
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) (a) A total of 688 departmental officers and employees were engaged in strike action during the calendar year 1980. In the calendar year 1979 the number of officers involved was 666. All were Australian Public Service StatT. A total of 16 APS StatT of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority were engaged in strike action during 1980 and 3,507 Commonwealth Teaching StatT were involved in 1979.
(b) 113 officers and employees of the Department were involved in go slow actions during 1979; no statT were involved in go slow action in 1980.
(2) The total manhours lost in strike action were 5,851 for the Department, 17,325 for CTS StatT at Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority and 117 for APS StatT from the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. Go slow action by Departmental officers and employees totalled 413 manhours.
(3) No officers or employees were paid for the period of any strike action.
(4) Deduction from pay was etTected in relation to go slow action taken by a Departmental officer, during the quartcr ending 30 September 1979, in the course of the ACOAjAPSA campaign against the CE (RR) Act 1978 and the CE (EP) Act 1978.
Entertainment and Hospitality: Department of Communications
(Question No. 1417)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 9 April 1981 :
(I) What was the (a) estimated and (b) actual expendi. ture on entertainment and hospitality within Australia by his Department in 1979-80.
(2) What sum was spent in 1979-80 by his Deparment within Australia on entertainment and hospitality in respect of (a) visitors from overseas (b) Australian residents and (c) officers of his Department, or other Commonwealth and State Departments or representatives of Commonwealth or State statutory authorities.
(3) What officers in his Department are permitted to authorise these expenditures.
(4) Did expenditure on entertainment and hospitality by his Department occur outside Australia during this period, if so, what sum was expended.
Mr Sinclair-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
I draw the honourable member's attention to an answer given by the Prime Minister in respect of Question No. 1413 which covered the matters raised with the exception of the components relating to Commonwealth sponsored international conferences in Australia and information on expenditure outside Australia.

Expenditure on international conferences in Australia sponsored by the Department of Communications is nil, for 1979-80.
Expenditure on entertainment and hospitality outside Australia during 1979-80 was incurred only by departmental officers in the course of overseas visits and under prescribed conditions. The total was $1,185.
Entertainment and Hospitality: Department of Finance
(Question No. 1424)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(I) What was the (a) estimated and (b) actual expenditure on entertainment and hospitality within Australia by the Department of Finance in 1979-80.
(2) What sum was spent in 1979-80 by the Department within Australia on entertainment and hospitality in respect of (a) visitors from overseas, (b) Australian residents and (c) officers of the Department, other Commonwealth and State Departments, or representatives of Commonwealth or State statutory authorities.
(3) What officers in the Department are permitted to authorise these expenditures.
(4) Did expenditure on entertainment and hospitality by the Department occur outside Australia during this period; if so, what sum was expended.
Mr Howard-The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
I refer the honourable member to the answer given by the Prime Minister to Question No. 1414 (refer Hansard of 5 June 1981).
In addition to the above response I am advised that no expenditure on official entertainment at Commonwealth sponsored international conferences in Australia was incurred by my Department in 1979-80; expenditure incurred by my Department on official entertainment outside Australia in 1979-80 was $7,751.

Head Office, Department of Defence

(Question No. 1501)

Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:

(I) Are any sections of the Head Office of his Department not located in Canberra; if so, what are the sections and how
many staff are in each?

(2) If so, when?

Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) The Head Office of the Department of Defence consists of the central policy and coordinating divisions and certain operating elements which have other than single Service interests. Apart from some overseas positions, the policy and
coordinating divisions are all located in Canberra. The operating elements are located throughout Australia. The details of
those outside Canberra are set out below:

(2) Decisions to relocate units of Government Employment to Canberra are taken by Government on the advice of the Location of Australian Government Employment Committee (LAGE), an IDC chaired by the PSB. The advice ten-
dered to Government by the LAGE Committee is based on submissions by the relevant Department, and consultations with interested bodies such as stafI organisations. Any plans to
relocate the sections in Canberra is a matter for LAGE consideration and subsequent decisions by Government.

Vehicle Conversion to LPG Usage: Department of Administrative Services
(Question No. 1563)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(1) How many (a) cars, (b) commercial vehicles and (c) trucks were being operated by his Department as at 30 June 1980.
(2) How many of these vehicles had been (a) converted to LPG usage and (b) purchased already equipped for LPG usage.
(3) Have plans been made to increase use of LPG in vehicles operated by his Department; if so, what are the details.
Mr Newman-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The honourable member has asked similar questions of all Ministers and my Department has collated the information provided.
(I) There were 7,500 cars, 6,072 commercial vehicles and 3,151 trucks operated by all departments as at 30 June 1980.
(2) At that time 140 of these vehicles had been cOflverted to LPG usage and 2 had been purchased already equipped for LPG usage.
(3) Since 30 June 1980 a further 50 factory fitted LPG cars have been purchased, another 10 have been converted and arrangements are in hand to convert a further 215. Consideration is also being given to the scope for a substantial increase

3580 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

in the use of LPG in vehicles operated by all departments. Details will be announced when a final decision has been taken.
Tea Services: Department of Social Security
(Question No. 1609)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(I) How many-
(a) full time and (b) part time staff are employed on tea making and distri-
butionin (i) the Head Office and (ii) other offices of the Department of Social Security.
(2) What was the cost of-
(a) salaries and (b) other charges in the provision of tea services in the De-
partment in 1979-80.
Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
Throughout the Department of Social Security's network of regional offices there is generally no official tea service, while in mUlti-occupied buildings in some of the capital cities the cost of tea services is met by the Department of Administrative Services rather than the individual departments. The costs the Department of Social Security incurred in 1979-80 in the provision of official tea services are set out below.
In Western Australia, the Northern Territory, and Central Office (Canberra), staff were employed to provide tea services, and the details were as follows:

In New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia the Department was charged $94,540 by the Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services Ltd. Other charges in those States totalled $21,860.

Costs of Maintaining Historic Postal Properties
(Question No. 1638)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 9 April 1981:
(I) Did the annual report of the Australian Postal Commission for 1979-80 indicate that extraordinary maintenance costs for maintaining historic postal properties was calculated at $700,000 per annum.
(2) [I' so, what considersation has been given to this expenditure being borne by the Commonwealth Government rather than by the Australian Postal Commission.
Mr Sinclair-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2) The information sought by the honourable member is a matter which comes within the responsibility of the Minister for Home Affairs. I have been advised that consideration is being given by t.he Government to recommendations concerning this issue made by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on environment and conservation in its report entitled 'Environmental Protection, Adequacy of Legislative and Administrative Arrangements, First Report', presented on 18 October 1979.
The Committee recommended that the desirability of introducing a separate item into departmental appropriations to separate the costs on maintenance of Commonwealth properties listed in the register of the national estates be examined. The Committee also recommended that a fund be established for the maintenance of redundant Commonwealth properties listed in the register.

Legal Aid
(Question No. 1670)
Mr Bungey asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 Apri11981:
(1) What sums were expended through legal aid to finance litigation in (a) representative actions and test cases and (b) environmental cases.

Mr VinerThe Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
(1) Between I July 1973 and] June 1981 the following sums were expended as financial assistance:
(a) in representative actions and test cases; and
(b) in environmental cases.
