(2) Financial assistance was provided in respect of the following actual or potential litigation-
(a) Representative actions and test cases
(i) a 8igh Court challenge by an elector concerning electoral boundaries of a federal electorate in Victoria;
(li) a proposed damages action on behalf of a thalidomide victim against a pharmaceuticals company;
(iii) an action by a Vietnam veteran and his family for damages for negligence against the Commonwealth and several chemical companies;
(iv) proposed proceedings by a person seeking clarification of s. 44 of the New South Wales Partition Act in its application to the Australian Capital Territory.
(b) Environmental cases
(i) proceedings in the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory by a group of individuals contesting the construction of the communications tower on Black Mountain;
(li) an appeal by a citizens' committee to a Local Government Court against permission granted to a company to mine clay and produce clay products without the imposition of adequate conditions to prevent pollution, in a major catchment area;
(iii) action by a conservation organiZation first to oppose,' in a Mining Warden's Court, applications for sandmining leases, secondly, in a Supreme Court seeking the issue of a writ of mandQlllus to require a Mining Warden to holli a proper hearing; and thirdly, when the writ was refused, by way of appeal to the High Court of Australia; ,
(Iv) appeal proceedings by a conservation group to a Local Goverruhent Court against a local government council acting without authority in granting approval for cement works to be constructed on the shores of a city's river;
(v) involving a State Commission of Inquiry in which two conservation groups were exonerated from suggestions of dishonesty in the collection of funds fot the purpose of setting up a trust to pr.eserve caves containing Aboriginal Art regarded as part of the National Estate;
(vi) action by a conservation group objecting, in a Mining Warden's Court, to the issue of mining leases over land which the group claimed, in the public interest, should be included in a prQPosed National Park;

(1) Is he able to say whether concern is being expressed in Hawaii that the Australian Navy has participated in exercises which included the bombardment of a range on an Hawaiian island.

(2) Have any Australian naval craft or personnel par-

ticipated in exercises with or independently of the United

States of America Navy in Hawaiian waters off the Hawaiian

islands.

.

(3) If so, on how many occassions has the Australian Navy participated in these exercises.

(4) Have these exercises included the bombardment of a range on any Hawaiian island.

(5) Have any Australian naval or airforce planes participated in exercises which include the bombardment of a range on any Hawaiian island.

(6) Is he concerned that Australia's image could be impaired by the participation of Australian naval craft in exercises which include the bombardment of a range on Hawaiian land in view of the opposition within Hawaii to the military use of Hawaiian land.

Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) to (4) On seven occassions between 1971 and April

1980 the RAN participated in exercises involving the use of

firing range on the island of Kaho'olawe. Concern in Hawaii

about such use was first brought to my atention in March 1980

when a letter was received from the staff attorney of the Legal

Aid Society of Hawaii, acting on behalf of a private group

called the Protect Kaho'olawe Ohana.

.

(5) Yes.

(6) Any future RAN use of the range would be in accordance with the terms of a consent decree signed in December 1980 by the US Navy and the Protect Kaho'olawe group. The terms of the decree state that ordnance used by foreign users shall also be governed by the decree. In these circumstances RAN use of the range should not lead to impairment of Australia's image

Special Assistance Grant for Children
(Question No. 1936)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:
(1) Is it a fact that at a meeting of State and Commonwealth Welfare Ministers the Minister refused to commit the Commonwealth Government to maintenance of present spending levels in respect of pre-school and other early childhood programs.
(2) When was the last increase in the special assistance grant for children in care.

Mr MacKellar-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(a) and (b). My Department does not have definitive information on the number of insulin-dependent diabetics in Australia, nor on the percentage who use disposable syringes and needles.
Australian Navy Exercises in Hawaiian Waters

(3) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the view expressed by some State Welfare Ministers that because of inadequate unemployment benefits for persons under 18 years of age, extra demand is placed on State resources and services for this group.
(4) What commitments will the Government make in respect of Commonwealth spending levels for pre-school and other early childhood programs.

(Question No. 1930)

Mr Hunt-The Minister for Social Security has

Mr Howe asked the Minister for Defence, upon provided the following answer to the honourable

notice, on 28 April 1981 :

member's question:

3586 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June J981

Answers to Questions

(l) Yes. The level of funds to be made available [or children's services in 1981-82 will be considered by the Government in the Budget context. However, [ indicated that expenditure by this Government on children's services, other than expenditure on pre-schools, had greatly increased in real terms since 1975-76.
(2) I assume that the 'special assistance grant' mentioned is in fact 'special needs subsidy' payable to certain services subsidised under the Children's Services Program.
Special needs subsidy is paid to assist day care services to rebate the fees oflow income families.
Special needs subsidy is payable under the general provisions of the Children's Services Program for family day care, and under the provisions of the Child Care Act for centre based services.
Under the general provisions, each family day care scheme receives Commonwealth special needs subsidy equal to the amount of fees foregone as fee rebates, up to a maximum total amount which is calculated on the basis of $7 per week for each equivalent full time child income.
The current rate of $7 per week used to calculate the maximum was introduced in 1977. A scheme can apply to the Minister for increased Special Needs Subsidy payments if it finds that the maximum amount does not cover the costs of fee rebates. Such increased payments are approved at ministerial discretion after an assessment of need. These arrangements also apply to day care centres funded under the centre based day care arrangement with the State governments.
Under the Child Care Act, payments to centres are made on the basis of the numbers of certain categories of children specified in Section 12 of the Act. Since 1975, each centre has been eligible to receive 25c subsidy per hour per child three years and over, and 40c per hour per child under three years.
(3) The question of the appropriate level of unemployment benefit for people under the age of 18 is bound up with the broader question of the assistance available for them in unemployment, education and training. This has been under study in the context of the review of ways of increasing the opportunities available for young people in education, training and employment.
The welfare and education implications for State governments as well as possible effects on State financial responsibilities, are relevant to consideration of possible changes in this area. State governments have been consulted as part of the review and the matter has been discussed by the Council of Social Welfare Ministers.
(4) See the answer to (I) above.
Statement of Professor Milton Friedman on Unregulated Monopoly
(Question No. 1952)
Mr Hurford asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 28 April 1981 :
(1) Has his attention been drawn to the statement of Professor Milton Friedman that unregulated monopoly may not be tolerable and either public regulation or ownership may be the lesser evil.
(2) Does he support this statement; if so, will he increase the resources of the Trade Practices Commission and Prices Justification Tribunal to regulate the conduct of firms enjoying monopoly-type power.
(3) If he will not increase these resources, what is the reason.
(4) Has his attention been drawn to reports in the press that the Prices Justification Tribunal will be abolished or merged

with the Trade Practices Commission; if so, is there any substance to these reports, and particularly to the report that he would not be unhappy if the Tribunal were abolished.
Mr Moore--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) [ understand that Professor Friedman made a statement to the elrect stated in the question.
(2), (3) and (4) The Government is committed to the principle of free and fair competition throughout the Australian economy including, where appropriate, regulation of monopoly power. The Government has reviewed, inter alia, the operations of the Trade Practices Commission and the Prices Justification Tribunal and its decisions were set out in the Prime Minister's Statement to the Parliament on 30 April 1981 on the Review of Commonwealth Functions.
Military Armament Depots
(Question No. 1971)
Mr Shack asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 28 April 1981:
(I) How many military armament depots are there in Australia.
(2) What are the names of each of these depots and where are they located.
(3) How close to the nearest residences are stored explosives at each depot.
(4) How many accidental explosions have there been at each depot during the last 10 years.
(5) What was the extent of damage to property and injury to persons for each of these accidents.
Mr KiIlen--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) There are 17 armament depots in Australia.
(2) The names and locations of the depots are as follows:
(a) RAN Armament Depot (RANAD), Newington, Silverwater, New South Wales;
(b) RAN Armament Depot (RANAD), Kingswood, New South Wales;
(c) No 1 Central Ammunition Depot (l CAMD), RAAF, Kingswood New South Wales;
(d) RAN Armament and Weapon Equipment Depot (RANAWED), Maribyrong, Victoria, with its explosives storage at Somerton, Victoria;
(e) RAN Armament and Weapon Equipment Depot (RANAWED), Byford, Western Australia;
(f) 51st Supply Battalion, Byford, Western Australia;
(g) 2nd Field Supply Battalion, Townsville, Qld;
(h) 13lst Supply Company, Wallangarra, Queensland/ New South Wales Border;
(i) 141st Supply Company, Ashgrove, Brisbane, Queensland;
(j) 221st Supply Company, Bogan Gate, New South Wales;
(k) 222nd Supply Company, Myambat, New South Wales;
(1) 223rd Supply Company, Marrangaroo, New South Wales;
(m) 3I lth Supply Company, Wirlinga, New South Wales;
(n) 311th Supply Company, Ettamogah, New South Wales;

(0) 331st Supply Company, Mangalore, Victoria;
(p) 21st Supply Battalion, Moorebank, New South Wales;
(q) 41st Supply Battalion, Penfield, South Australia;
(3) The nearest residences to stored explosives at each depot are:
(a) RANAD,Newington-170m
(b) RANAD, Kingswood-1350m
(c) ICAMD, Kingswood-320m
(d) RANAWED, Maribyrnong/Somerton-1400m

(4) One accidental explosion occurred at RANAD Newington in 1975. There have been no accidental explosions at the other depots during the last 10 years.
(5) In the RANAD, Newington accident two depot personnel were killed and one suffered shock; some furniture and fittings in the explosives workshop were damaged and the building suffered superficial internal damage.
Universities and Colleges of Advanced Education: Total Enrolments
(Question No. 1997)
Mr Rocher asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 29 April 1981:
(1) What progress has been made in pursuing the recommendations contained in the report of the Committee of Review into the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (the Williams Committee) that universities and colleges of advanced education should strive for more accuracy in recording the number of their total enrolments.
(2) Are the numbers of effective full-time students at these institutions being satisfactorily recorded and is the Government satisfied that the numbers are accurate.
Mr Fife-The reply to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The Committee of Inquiry into Education and Training established in 1976 under the chairmanship of Professor Sir Bruce Williams recommended, R6.25,' . . . a considerable improvement in the accuracy and comprehensiveness of advanced education statistics to make possible comparative studies that should guide any further decisions on rationalisation.' This was one of a number of Williams Committee recommendations referred to the Tertiary Education Commission for consideration.
At present different measures are used to calculate the number of equivalent full time students, 'student load', for the university and advanced education sectors. For universities student load is measured in terms of the weighted student unit (WSU) which is calculated by measuring the academic

program for each student against the normal program for a full time student in each course. Higher degree enrolments are given special weightings. For colleges of advanced education student load is calculated by giving a weight of 1.0 to full time students and 0.5 to part time and external students.
There are difficulties in accurately calculating student load in colleges of advanced education because the measures currently being used tend to overstate it. The Tertiary Education Commission, in Volume 1 Part 1 of its Report for the 1982-84 Triennium, has advised that it considers that since most part time students in advanced education, and particularly external students, undertake less than one-half of a full year's work, the real student load generated by a part time enrolment is likely to be closer to 0.4 than 0.5 of the load of a full time student. The Commission has taken this into consideration in formulating its recommendations on the advanced education sector.
The development of a WSU type measure is under consideration by the Joint Committee on Advanced Education Statistics.
Analysis of Suspected Fire-damaged KTCP
(Question No. 2059)
Mr West asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
(I) Were samples ofsuspected fire-damaged KTCP (Potassiumtrichlorophenolate, a potassium salt of 2,4,5-T) sent by the Industries Assistance Commission to the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories for analysis during or about March 1981.
(2) If so, has it been analysed and what are the results.
(3) From where did the lAC obtain the sample.
(4) Is he able to say if more of the sample is present in Australia; if so, where is it.
(5) What does the lAC propose to do with the sample.
Mr Moore-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
The Chairman of the lAC has advised me that-
(1) A sample which the Commission then believed to" be fire damaged KTCP was forwarded to AGAL during March 1981 for analysis.
(2) Yes. The analysis showed that the sample was mainly iso-butyl ester 2,4,5-T with a lesser amount of n-butyl ester. The sample does not contain KTCP or 2,4-D. Dioxin (TCDD) content of the sample is 19 mg/kg which is equivalent to 26 mg/kg on a 2,4,5-T acid base.
(3) The sample of about 130 ml was received about January 1973 from Chemical Industries (Kwinana) Pty Ltd as part of its evidence in relation to the Tariff Board inquiry into 2,4,5-T products and 2,4,5-Trichlorophenol and its Salts (Dumping and Subsidies Act).
(4) The sample was forwarded to AGAL.
(5) See (4).
Import ofKTCP
(Question No. 2061)
Mr West asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
What is the name of the company which imported 300 tonnes ofKTCP from Singapore during 1969-71.
Mr Moore-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

On the basis of avialable records, Chemical Industries (Kwinana) Pty Ltd and Farm Chemicals Pty Ltd (Queensland) imported about 350 tonnes of KTCP from Singapore during the period in question.
United States Sonar Base on Christmas Islands
(Question No. 2063)
!VIr Fry asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 May 1981:
(1) What is the status of the United States of America sonar based on Christmas Island.
(2) If the base is no longer operational, has its functions been taken over by any other establishment on Australian terrilory, and is the Government kept informed of the function of the base.
!VII' Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) and (2) I refer the honourable member to my answer to Question No. 506 (Hansard of 5 May, page 2004). In particular I would draw his attention to the answers to parts (5) and (6) of that question in which J stated:
'For obvious security reasons I will not provide answers that would confirm or deny whether Australia has underwater sensor systems for operational purposes. For equally sound reasons J would not provide an answer to the honourable member's Question 6. Suffice to say that if such systems were in operation they would be under Australian control, and would be serving Australia's defence interests.
Question 5 (a), specifically concerning Christmas Island, raises however the issue of claims over the past year or so about United States involvement in Operation Flowerless and of a military installation on Christmas Island. These claims are without foundation. I will state now that there is no underwater sensor system at Christmas Island.'
Immigration Prosecutions
(Question No. 2072)
Mr Robert Brown asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on6May1981:
(1) Was a Sydney solicitor, a Mr W. Lee, charged by Australian Federal Police in connection with an alleged immigration racket.
(2) Were any other persons charged in conmnection with the same matter; if so, what were the names of those involved.
(3) What was the nature of the charges and when were they laid.
(4) Has the matter been before the courts; if so, what was the outcome.
!VII' Viner-The Attorney-General has provided the following answers:
(1) A Sydney barrister, Mr William Jansing Lee was charged with conspiracy in 1980.
(2) Mr To Chew was also charged in connection with the same matter.
(3) Messrs Lee and Chew were charged under paragraph 86 (I) (d) of the Crimes Act with conspiracy to effect a lawful purpose by means that are unlawful under a law of the Commonwealth. [n substance the allegation was that the defendants had conspired to bribe an Immigration officer to obtain permanent residence in Australia for two prohibited immigrants, The charges were laid on 5 May 1980.

(4) Committal proceedings against Messrs Lee and Chew were heard from 27 October to 3 November 1980. Both defendants were discharged.
Defence Forces: Training of Recruits
(Question No. 2085)
!VIrs Kelly asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 6 May 1981 :
(1) What intake into each of the Defence forces has occurred in each of the past three years.
(2) What intake is planned for each of the next three years.
(3) Do plans exist for the expansion of each of the three forces; if so, what are the plans.
(4) What construction has taken place at the Singleton base, New South Wales, during the last 12 months and what further construction is planned in 1982.
(4) What provision was made in the 1980-81 Defence budget for the training of recruits in each of the three services.
(6) Will similar provision be madefor 1981-82.
!VIr Killen The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) FY 19'J7-78-RAN: 1819, Army: 3755, RAAF: 2315.
FY 1978-79-RAN: 2032, Army: 3809, RAAF: 2149.
FY 1979-80-RAN: 1964, Army: 4279, RAAF: 2307.
(2) Intakes for the next three years will be of a size to cover losses from the services and to meet the expansion in strengths outlined in lhe response (3) following.
Recruitment planning is carried out on an annual basis and is closely monitored to adjust for unexpected variations in losses from the services. Losses for 1979-80 totalled 7535, whilst recruitment was 8550, The intake for 1980-81 is expected to be approximately 9040. Intakes for future years wiII depend upon ceiling strength levels yet to be approved.
(3) In February 1980 the Government announced its intention to increase regular service manpower by about 5000 by 1984-85. In the current financial year, the ceiling has been increased by 370 for the RAN, 840 for the Army and 370 for the RAAF. The actual size of increase for each service in 1981-82 and subsequent years has not yet been approved.
(4) During the last 12 months, only construction ofaminor nature has been carried out at the Singleton base. This involved individual works valued at less than $15,000 to a total aggregate of about $138,000.
The following new construction is planned for 1982:
An office building, workshops and stores facility and alterations to existing buildings for the Singleton Workshop Platoon at an estimated cost of $170,000.
Provision of 5 x 3 bedroom married quarters at an estimated cost of $300,000,
Provision of Fixed Fire Protection for 8 Camp Hospital at $21,000.
Minor construction work to a lotal aggregate of about $200,000.
(5) Defence resource planning procedures are expressed in terms of prime inpul categories. Recruit training costs cannot be identified as a separate category. The budget for 1980-81 has made provision for the approved expansion of the Defence Forces.
(6) The Defence Budget for future years wiII take into account the planned increase in Defence Force strengths.

Participation in Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting: Department of Finance
(Question No. 2171)
Mr Hayden asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 7 May 1981:

Mandata System
(Question No. 2208)
Mr Les Johnson asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:
(1) What improvements, increased efficiencies and other benefits have been achieved with the introduction of the Mandata system?
(2) What is the expected return from the sale of equipment following the termination of the system?
Mr Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) The consensus of departments is that the Mandata project was of value as an aid to effective management. However, as indicated in the Public Service Board's 1980 Annual Report, whilst the project has achieved reasonably reliable operations within defined limits, it has failed to meet the objectives earlier set for it and with hindsight, the project has not proved cost-effective.
(2) Action is in hand to make known to departments and instrumentalities/authorities details of the items which will become surplus. It is expected that most of the equipment will be taken up by government agencies thus avoiding additional outlay for approved ADP acquisitions. The return will be known when this is done.

Service Personnel: Long Service Leave
(Question No. 2235)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:
(I) What percentage of funds allocated for long service leave for service personnel is payment in lieu of leave.

(2) Do service personnel have a right to long service leave.
(3) If so, is it practice to reject applications for leave when eligibility for leave has been reached.
(4) Is long service leave actually a form of retirement pay under existing legislation.
(5) Is an entitlement for pay in lieu established progressively as qualification periods for long service leave are completed or is this entitlement only available at retirement.
(6) Does a serviceman seeking to take long service leave entitlement have any recourse to review by an independent person or authority where this leave is refused.
MI' Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) There is no allocation of funds for the payment of Ibng service leave to serving members. Members receive normal salary while on long service leave. However, funds are allocated for the payment in lieu oflong service leave.
(2) A member may be granted subject to Service convenience long service leave once he has completed 10 years admissible service.
(3) Long service leave is generally approved. However, an application may be rejected when the taking of long service leave by a member is not in the interests of the Service or because of manning requirements.
(4) No. Long service leave is a period of rest and recuperation, whilst on service, after a minimum of 10 years service. Pay in lieu of long service leave can be taken only for unexpended credits at discharge.
(5) An entitlement to long service leave accrues progressively during a member's service. Payment in lieu of long service leave can only be made to a member when he separates from the Service.
(6) Should a member's application for long service leave be denied, he may submit a request for reconsideration of his application through the normal Service channels. In addition, the member has recourse to the long established Services Redress of Wrongs system, and to the Office of the Defence Force Ombudsman, if he is not satisfied with the results of a request for reconsideration.
Defence: Estimated Expenditure on Wages and Salaries
(Question No. 2239)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:

3592 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

Does the reduction of $1 03m (sic) in estimated expenditure by his Department on wages and salaries in 1980-81 indicate:
(a) that recruitment will be below the figure stated at the time of 1980 Budget;
(b) that expected changes in conditions contained in recommendations of the Defence Forces Pay Review Tribunal and approved by him will cost less than was originally anticipat~d; or
(c) that the recommendations of the Review Tribunal have been delayed beyond the time when it was anticipated that payment of new rates would have commenced.
Mr Killen-The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:
(a) No.
(b) No.
(c) On 31 October 1980 the Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay recommended interim salary increases of around four per cent. These interim recommendations have been approved and implemented.
I understand from the Chairman of the Committee of Reference that it hopes to be in the position to present a further report to the Minister by the end of July 1981.
The amount of $103m (initially $llOm) was included by the Department of Finance in the Defence Budget estimates for 1980-81 to meet prospective increases in wage and salary rates of both Service and civilian personnel within Defence, stemming from national wage cases and work value studies.
The actual additional estimate variation for salaries sought by Defence for 1980-81 is $91.795m to cover mainly increases flowing from national wage cases and work value studies so far awarded to Service personnel and civilians.
Williamstown Naval Dockyard
(Question No. 2240)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 May 1981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to the public statement emanating from the Royal Commission into the Painters and Dockers Union that employees of the Williamstown Naval Dockyard, Victoria, were collecting their pay, rejoining the queue and being paid a second time.
(2) Is there any substance to this claim, if so, why are" the administrative procedures so poor or the staff of his Department so incompetent that second salaries can be paid to individuals without this being discovered by those responsible for the management of payrolls and by the Government auditors.
(3) If the Royal Commission's statement is correct, in what way are appropriations provided for the second payments to individuals, and who arranges this.
(4) Can he assure the House that this practice does not, or never did, occur.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2) Employees can and do legitimately collect more than one pay; their own, and with proper authority from a workmate, his also. This is common practice in Commonwealth employment.

(3) Although allegations have been made before the Royal Commission, it is my understanding that it has not been established that any wrong practices are occurring at Williamstown Naval Dockyard. It is likely that further evidence on the same subject could yet be called before the Commission.
(4) See answer 2 and 3.
Construction of Hydrographic Survey Vessel
(Question No. 2242)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 May 1980:
(I) What costs have been associated with the construction of the hydrographic survey vessel at Williamstown Dockyard, Victoria.
(2) Have significant alterations to the design of this vessel during construction created serious delays in deliver.
(3) What have been the additional costs incurred by the design alterations.
(4) What has been the (a) cost and (b) cause of the period of delay resulting from design and operational problems in the multi-pitch screw hydraulics.
Mr Killen-The following answer is provided to the honourable member's question:
This answer presumes that the honourable member is referring to the Oceanographic Research Ship HMAS Cook presently under construction at Williamstown. The hydrographic survey vessel HMAS Flinders was also constructed at Williamstown; however that vessel has been in operation for the last seven years.
(I) The cost of the Oceanographic Research Ship HMAS Cook is $30.886m at Decemher 1980 prices. The estimated project cost in September 1974, construction commencement date, was $17.5m. The total net real price increase amounts to $2.03Im of the increase of $13.386m. The balance of the increase, i.e., $ll.355m, has occurred due to inflationary factors.
(2) No-the design work package for this ship was completed prior to 1974. Minor design changes have been included in the shipbuilder's work package subsequent to that date; howevcr these have not delayed the completion of the ship.
(3) An increase in real costs of $O.188m (approx) to implement 111 design changes. Balanced against this cost figure is a saving of $0.141m which resulted from implementation of four design changes.
(4) The cause of the period of delay in completion of the ship can be attributed to the inability of the main machinery contractor to satisfactorily instal the main propulsion machinery in the ship to meet specification contract requirements.
Reimbursement of costs associated with rectifying the machinery deficiencies, together with the shipbuilder's consequential costs resulting therefrom, e.g., additional docking, delays to other scheduled docking, dockyard services, are being actively investigated by the contractual authority; the Department of Administrative Services.

Enemy Subjects Trust Account
(Question No. 2285)
Mr Les Johnson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:
(1) When was the Enemy Subjects Trust Account established.
(2) What sums are lodged in the account.
(3) Are there any outstanding claims against the account.
(4) On termination of the account (Hansard 30 April 1981, page 1844) what use will be made of the funds.
Mr Howard-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1') The Enemy Subjects Trust Account was established on 6 October 1939 in accordance with the provisions of section 14 of the Trading with the Enemy Act 1939 to receive and deal with the proceeds of disposal of property formerly owned by Enemy Subjects.
(2), (3) and (4) Funds which became available earlier have been distributed over the years, including two general distributions to eligible ex-prisoners of war and their dependants. Since no transactions involving receipts to the Account have occurred for several years and since it seems most unlikely that any further claims on the Account will arise, it has been decided that its continuation is no longer justified.
Pending its closure the balance of funds that remained in the account ($19;579.93), being too small to justify another general distribution, has been transferred to the Services Canteens Trust Fund.
Defence Force Review Tribunal: Report on Salaries and Conditions
(Question No. 2294)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:
(1) Has the report by the Defence Force Review Tribunal on Salaries and Conditions of Members of the Defence Forces been completed. .
(2) If not, has the time taken for the review been excessive and will he seek to have the finalisation of the Report expedited.
(3) Has an amount of $103m been deducted from the appropriation for the Defence Forces accounts savings, as a result of the Report not being available when initally anticipated.
(4) Will he ensure that the operative date of any beneficial changes to service conditions and salaries will be backdated, in order that Service personnel will not be financially disadvantaged by delays in the preparation or approval of the Tribunal's recommendations.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) No.
(2) I do not consider the time taken for the review to be excessive. The Committee of Reference for Defence Force Pay was given its terms of reference on 22 July 1980. The Committee submitted to me an interim report on 31 October 1980

on the work value aspect of the reference recommending an increase in Service remuneration on grounds of work value change. This recommendation has been approved and implemented.
Additionally, in December 1980, the Committee of Reference was tasked with an examination of appropriate allowances for Special Action Forces. The report on this subject was presented on 6 March 1981. Without doubt, this intervening but extreinely urgent reference eelayed to some extent continuance of the work required by the earlier reference.
Despite these strictures on the time of the Committee, two members of which are full-time members of the Arbitration Commission a further report is expected to be forthcoming by about the end ofJuly 1981.
(3) The amount of$103m (initially $11 Om) was included in the Defence Budget estimates for 1980-81 by Department of Finance, as an Allowance to meet prospective increases in wage and salary rates of both Service and civilian personnel within Defence.
The actual additional estimate for the salaries sought by Defence for 1980-81 is $91.795m to cover mainly increases flowing from national wage case decisions and work value increases so far awarded to both Service personnel and civilians.
(4) The interim increase recommended by the Committee of Reference, which is mentioned in 2. above, was effective from 22 July 1980. This was the date terms of reference for the inquiry were given to the Committee of Reference. In the report accompanying the recommendations, the Committee of Reference stated that it should not be inferred that 22 July 1980 will be the operative date for the final work value assessment or for other recommendations made necessary by the terms of reference. That final date of effect is to be a matter for separate consideration.
Australian Army Reserves
(Question No. 2295)
Mr Scholes asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:
(1) Did the 1980-81 Budget estimates indicate the estimated strength of the Australian Army Reserves to be 31,550.
(2) Do the supplementary estimates in Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1980-81 show a reduced estimated figure of 31,260; if so, is it anticipated that the figure will be reached.
(3) Have estimates of the numbers of recruits and retrenchments been rendered inaccurate by changes in methods at unit level of assessing the numbers of Army Reserve members.
(4) What is the current estimate of the numbers of members of the Army Reserve for June 1981.
(5) Will the public advertising campaign to attract recruits to the Australian Defence Force Reserves be extended into 1981-82.
Mr Killen-The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:
(1) Yes.
(2) The supplementary estimates in Appropriation Bill (No.3) 1980-81 comprehend a reduced estimated target for 30 June 1981 of 31260 but latest returns indicate now that this target will not be reached.
(3) Army has made no policy changes in the method of assessing numbers since the expansion began. Headquarters Field Force was made aware last February of one Army Reserve Officer, who on his own initiative encouraged his subordinates to delay the declaration of non-effective members.

3594 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

Orders were immediately given to prevent such a practice being contemplated elsewhere.
(4) It is expected that the Army Reserve will achieve a strength of 28,500 at 30 June 1981, with the target figure of 30,000 being reached in September 1981.
(5) Yes.

liberations were amongst information provided to the RCF Committee by the Department of Defence.

ation, provided factual information to the RCF Committee.
(4) I was aware that the information would be used in the
context and for the purpose for which it was provided, i.e. re view of Commonwealth functions.
Petrol Prices
(Question No. 2302)
Mr Jacobi asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:
(1) Has his attention been drawn to the fact that since the
release of the recent Prices Justification Tribunal (PJT) report on petrol prices, the extent of discounting petrol has increased markedly in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland.
(2) Is it a fact that South Australia motorists have not
shared in the benefits of the resultant lower level of pertrol prices.
(3) Is he satisfied that petrol resellers and motorists in
South Australia are not being discriminated against by the oil companies; if not, will he (a) instruct the body replacing the PJT to investigate immediately this discrimination by the oil companies in South Australia and (b) continue to monitor petrol pricing throughout Australia.
Mr Moore-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I ) No. Indeed I have noted reports that some oil
companies intended to withdraw discounts, following the re
lease of the PJT report of 31 March 1981 on petroleum prod uct prices. I am not able to confirm or deny the accuracy of
those reports nor to say whether market conditions will enable companies to withdraw those discounts.

{2) See answer to (I) above.
(3) According to ABS figures (catalogue No. 6403.0) the
average retail price of super grade petrol in Adelaide during
the March quarter of 1981 was higher than in other State capi
tals. In the previous quarter the reverse applied.
(4) Prices determined by the PJT for the oil companies are
maximum justified prices. They differ between States only to the extent of differences in State taxes or other charges levied on petroleum products.
Oil companies are not obliged to charge the maximum jus tified prices and, where competition is keen, they might not be able to obtain the full justified price. Actual prices to resellers would reflect both the strength of competition of any State price controls that may apply.
The Petroleum Products Pricing Authority will take over from the PJT the respnmsibility for monitoring prices charged by the oil companies. It will have powers as proposed in the Petroleum Products Pricing Bill which I introduced into Par
liament on 27 May 1981.
As the Commonwealth's jurisdiction over prices is limited to the corporate sector, effective action to monitor retail petrol prices, including the margins applied by non-corporate resellers, is a matter for State Governments to consider.
Domestic Fallout Shelter Guide
(Question No. 2309)
Mr Les Johnson asked the Minister for De fence, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:
(1) Is the Domestic Fallout Shelter Guide 1980 issued by
the natural disasters organisation within his Department sup posed to provide guidance to Australians in the event of nu clear accident or the explosion of nuclear weapons in Australia.
(2) If so, (a) is the Government satisfied with the ad
equacy of the guide and (b) what additions, amendments or alterations can be made to improve the guide.
Mr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) and (2) The booklet was produced to give those who
may wish to plan for protection from radioactive fallout following a nuclear explosion some guidance on domestic shelters which could be constructed at moderate cost.
I am satisfied that the booklet is adequate for that purpose.
The booklet was produced as part of the Natural Disasters Organisation's ongoing public information program. Relevant material is constantly being reviewed and pamphlets produced, in conjunction with appropriate authorities on a range of disaster subjects.
Information on nuclear health matters is presently being gathered under these arrangements. This information could form part of a more comprehensive booklet which would in clude information about fallout shelters and any other relevant material which is ready for dissemination at the time.
United States and Japan Alliance
(Question No. 2320)
Mr Fry asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 May 1981:
{I) Does the recently announced alliance between the
United States of America and Japan have any impact on Australian foreign policy and defence planning.
(2) If the alliance leads to a re-arming of Japan, what impli
cations will this have for Australia and what would be the effect on Australian foreign affairs and defence policy.

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3595

(3) Did the United States Government consult with the Australian Government before announcing this alliance.
(4) Has the USA any obligation, either legal or moral, to consult with Australia on such a matter.
(5) If the Australian Government was consulted, what response did it give.
(6) If the Australian Government was not consulted on this matter, (a) is this a cause of concern for the Australian Government and (b) what guarantee is there that the USA will consult Australia on any future foreign policy initiative involving countries in the area.
Mr Street-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) An alliance between the United States and Japan has tIot been announced recently. In the joint communique issued by Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki and President Ronald Reagan on 8 May, it was stated that 'the Prime Minister and the President, recognising that the alliance between Japan and the United States is built upon their shared values of democracy and liberty, reaffirmed their solidarity, friendship and mutual trust'. Although there has been debate in Japan about the interpretation of the word 'alliance' in this sentence, in particular as to whether it committed Japan to a new or altered security relationship with the United States, the Government of Japan has made it clear that its relationship with the United States remains as it has been.
(2) The joint communique further states that 'the Prime Minister and the President reaffirmed their belief that the Japan-United States Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security is the foundation of peace and stability in the Far East and the defense of Japan. In insuring peace and stability in the region and the defense of Japan, they acknowledged the desirability of an appropriate division of roles between Japan and the United States. The Prime Minister stated that Japan, on its own initiative and in accordance with its constitution and basic defense policy, will seek to make even greater efforts for improving its defense capabilities in Japanese territories and in its surrounding sea and air space, and for further alleviating the financial burden of US forces in Japan. The President expressed his understanding of the statement by the Prime Minister.'
These positions outlined in the communique do 'not alter our perception of Japan's defence and security policies nor of Japan's relations with the United States. The Government sees cooperation under the Japan-United States Treaty of Mutual Cooperation and Security as a vital part of the defence of the Asia/Pacific region, as are the separate arrangements under ANZUS. It is in Australia's interest that the defence relationship between Japan and the United States remain a harmonious one.
(3), (4), (5) and (6) As suggested in answer to questions (1) and (2), no event as suggested by those questions took place which required specific consultations with Australia by any other government. In both formal and informal consultations with the United States on security issues in the Pacific area, discussion would include, as appropriate from time to time, subjects related to Japan. Similarly, established patterns of consultations with Japan on matters of common international concern include subjects such as Japan's, and our own, relations with the United States.
Replacement ofHMAS 'Melbourne'
(Question No. 2331)
Mr Fry asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 May 1981:
(1) What proportion of the annual Defence budget is spent on the acquisition of new equipment.

(2) What are the implications for the Army and Air Force, in terms of new equipment, from the decision to replace HMAS Melbourne with another aircraft carrier or carriers.
(3) For how many years will the proportion of the Defence budget allocated for purchase of capital equipment be tied up in paying off a new aircraft carrier.
(4) Does he favour an aircraft carrier rather than a mix of conventional submarines and small surface ships for the protection of Australia; if so, why.
(5) Is HMAS Melbourne being replaced by another aircraft carrier so as to enable Australia to project a visible presence in the South Pacific and Indian Oceans.
(6) Will other powers in the area interpret the replacement ofHMAS Melbourne in the terms referred to in part (5).
(7) Is the career structure of the Royal Australian Navy centred around serving on an aircraft carrier.
(8) Has Australian thinking on a replacement for HMAS Melbourne been influenced by United States of America Naval doctrine.
(9) How many Oberon-class submarines could be purchased from the sum necessary to replace HMAS Melbourne with another aircraft carrier.
Mr Killen-The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:
(I) The proportions of total Defence expenditures spent on capital equipment over the financial years 1975-76 to 1979-80 are 8.3 per cent, 12.8 per cent, 13.2 per cent, 15.5 per cent and 16.4 per cent respectively. On 19 February 1980 the Prime Minister announced in Parliament details of a defence program which is expected to raise the proportion of expenditure on capital investment to over 25 per cent of the defence vote by 1984-85.
(2) The acquisition of new major capital equipment is considered primarily in the context of its contribution to the development of defence force capabilities as a whole. Planning for the development of Army and Air Force capabilities will necessarily take account of concurrent development of the RAN.
(3) None. In anyone year the major equipment component of the Defence Budget comprises financial allocations for a range of equipment approved in earlier years and for new equipment to be approved in the Budget year.
(4) Studies to assisnhe selection of an aircraft carrier design are continuing. Conventional submarines and small surface ships are not alternatives to the anti-submarines helicopters which will be deployed with any new carrier. The carrier is to have potential for operating short take-off and vertical landing (STOVL) aircraft. The Government will consider in 1983 whether or not to acquire STOVL aircraft, in the light of aircraft costs, capabilities and other relevant factors.
(5) See my answer (4) above. A new carrier would, as do HMAS Melbourne and other major ships of the RAN,conduct operations in the Pacific and Indian Oceans.
(6) I cannot comment accurately on how neighbouring states might interpret Government decisions on Australian defence force development. I should expect them to see a decision to acquire a helicopter carrier as a military matter rather than, as the question implies, a political one.
(7) No. Service with the aircraft carrier is not a prerequisite for advancement in the RAN.
(8) No. Decisions on Australian defence force development are based on Government assessments of Australian defence needs.
(9) See my answer to (4) above. No useful answer can be given to this question. The eventual cost of a new carrier will

3596 REPRESENTATIVES 10 June 1981

Answers to Questions

depend on the type of ship selected and the range of capabilities that it might include. The Oberon submarine is no longer in production.
Visits by United States Attack Submarines
(Question No. 2384)
!VII' Beazley asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:
(1) Will he update the record of visits by attack submarines of the United States Navy provided in answer to Question No. 508 (Hansard, 5 May 1981,p. 2004).
(2) Is he able to say which of the submarines visiting since 1979 have been Los Angeles class attack submarines.
(3) Have the visiting submarines cooperated with Australian Orion P-3C aircraft in surveillance activities in the Eastern Indian Ocean area; if so, on what occasions.
(4) Have the visiting submarines conducted exercises with RAN units and/or RAAF aircraft; if so, (a) on what occasions and (b) which Australian units were involved on each occasion.
!VIr Killen-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(I) The following visits to HMAS Stirling by nuclear powered submarines have taken place in 1981:

Name of submarine
USSMemphis US Gurnard US Cavalla USSPintado US Bluefish

Dates of visit
6-11 February 27 February-6 March 15-22April 22-27 May 29 May-3 June

(2) US Los Angeles, US Baton Rouge, US GroTon, US Omaha, US Philadelphia, US Memphis.
(3) No.
(4) a and b Yes. The occasions on which RAN and RAAF units have exercised with visiting submarines since 1979 have been prior to or on completion of the visits by the US TauTog in August 1980, US Gumard in March 1981 and US Pintado in May 1981. RAAF Orion aircraft participated on all three occasions, and HMAS Perth participated also in exercises with US Pintado.
Sound Surveillance System on Christmas Island
(Question No. 2385)
!VIr Beazley asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:
(J) Has his attention been drawn to the article by Joel S. Wit entitled 'Advances in Antisubmarine Warfare' in the Scielllific American, February 1981, Volume 244, Number 2; if so, does a map appearing on page 37 indicate the presence on Christmas Island of a Sound Surveillance System (SOSUS) shore facility connected with the US antisubmarine warfare program.
(2) Does the facility shown on the map actually exist; if so, is it under Australian or United States control.
(3) In view of the SOSUS offshore arrays near Indonesian waters and the SOSUS shore facility, has Australia access to intelligence gathered on the movements of Soviet and other nations' submarines.
!VII' KillenThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(l) Yes; yes.
(2) No. See my answer to Question No. 506 (Hansard, page 2004).
(3) I will not comment further on the accuracy or otherwise of details about underwater sensor systems contained in the ScienTific American article. Australia obtains intelligence about the movement of other nations' submarines from various sources.
Tertiary Student Loan Scheme
(Question No. 2401)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:
(1) Will the loans made available under the tertiary student loan scheme announced by the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions (Hansard, 30 April, 1981, page 1843) be (a) free of interest or (b) subject to the low rate of interest.
(2) Over what periods will repayments be set.
(3) What procedures will be followed in attempting to secure repayments of loans made under this proposed loan scheme to supplement or replace the TEAS.
(4) Will the Government obtain the services of debt collecting agencies to ensure repayment of loans.
(5) What security will be required of the student in obtaining a loan.
(6) Will loans be taken out at the beginning of a term to last for the duration of the term, or will they be obtained at the beginning of the school year for the duration of that year.
(7) Will students entering their second or third year of studies be required to have paid back the loan for the prcvious year before proceeding or before obtaining a new loan.
(8) What will be the financial indebtedness of a student who secures loans for 3 years of studies and fails in the last term of those 3 years and is unable to continue his or her education.
(9) Is the purpose of providing loans to assist students in (a) the progressive payment of tertiary education fees or (b) meeting expenses incurred while studying for a degree or diploma.
(10) If the purpose of the loan is that referred to in part (9) (b), will students who are not successful in the course of study for which they have received loans, still be required to repay the loan; if so, will the loan scheme add serious financial indebtedness as a penalty to a student's failure to achieve success at his or her studies.
!VII' Fife-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) to (10) At this stage the details of the proposed student loans scheme have not been finalised and it is not possible, therefore, to provide specific answers to the parts to this question. I shall make a fuller statement on the scheme later in the year after negotiations with banks and tertiary institutions have been completed.
Prices ofPetl'oleum Products
(Question No. 2438)
!VII' Hayden asked the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 4 June 1981 :
(1) Did the Prices Justification Tribunal say in its report published on 31 March 1981 entitled Inquiry into Prices of Petroleum Products, at page 25, that the Tribunal accepts that a review (i.e. of the Tribunal's criteria and procedures for

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3597

dealing with petroleum product prices) is desirable and accordingly, following the completion of this Inquiry, it will prepare a statement on the criteria, procedures and information requirements for future pricing proposals and that this statement will be made available to the industry and to interested parties for comment before decisions to implement the proposals are taken by the Tribunal; if so, what stage has been reached by the Tribunal in this review of procedures for future out product pricing proposals.
(2) Will he ensure that the new mechanism to be established to maintain the Government's petroleum product pricing policy will continue with and complete this review as promised by the Tribunal.
Mr Moore-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:
(1) Yes-the Prices Justification Tribunal has this matter under consideration.
(2) Yes-It will be the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority's responsibility to continue the work and complete the review.
Commonwealth Funding for Colleges of Advanced Education
(Question No. 2442)
Mr Young asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 4 June 1981:
(I) Further to the Government's announcement that consideration would be given to funding activities of single purpose colleges of advanced education where they have been amalgamated with or into larger institutions to the satisfaction of the Commonwealth Government by the end of 1981 (Hansard, 30 April 1981, page 1843), is it a fact that Commonwealth funding for 30 single purpose CAE's will cease as single purpose institutions from the end of 1981.
(2) Are a number of institutions listed in Attachment D to the Ministerial Statement on the Review of Commonwealth Functions (e.g. Hartley CAE, Salisbury CAE, Alexander Mackie CAE, Guild T.e., Nursery School T.e., Sydney Kindergarten T.C., Sydney T.C., SCV Coburg, Melbourne and Toorak, and Brisbane Kindergarten T.e.) already beingamalgamated into larger institutions; if so, why are these institutions listed.
(3) If the campuses listed in Attachment D to the ministerial statement amalgamate with, or into, larger institutions by the end of 1981 in a way which results in genuine amalgamations with one governing body and a real saving of resources, will they receive full Commonwealth funding.
(4) How does the Government define a real saving of resources.
(5) Will the Government undertake to guarantee that the total number of student places available in CAE's will not be reduced as a result of the amalgamations.
(6) What guarantees will the Government give to students that there will be provision for them to complete the courses in which they have enrolled.
(7) How will the Government fund courses previously offered by CAEs where they are transferred to neighbouring universities.
(8) Has the Government allocated $5m in 1982 and 1983 to facilitate this rationalisation; if so, is this to be a $Sm grant in each of years 1982 and 1983,
(9) Has the Government rejected the recommendation of the Tertiary Education Commission for $IOm to be allocated during 1982-83 to assist with the rationalisations; if so, why.

(10) Will the amalgamation of CAE's with universities affect access to CAE level courses due to the more stringent entrance requirements of the universities; if so, what action will the Government take to ensure that this does not occur.

(11) To what extent will the University of Western Australia and Murdoch University be expected to collaborate
and share resources.

(12) Has the Government estiinated the cost of pursuing the rationalisations proposed; if so what is the estimated cost.

(13) What. criteria is the Government using to justify the rationalisation ofengineering in Victoria.

(14) Has the Government undertaken a labour power study of the needs for engineers in Australia as a whole and the effect of the proposed rationalisation on the supply of
engineers.

Mr Fife--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

(1) As I explained in my Statement on Commonwealth

Education Policy and Financial guidelines to the Common-

wealth Education Commissions, the Government intends to

reach agreement with each State concerning rationalisation

measures by the end of 1981. If this cannot be done, the Com-

monwalth will not be prepared to continue recurrent funding

for the colleges concerned after the end of 1981 and if the

State Government!; wish these colleges to continue as separate

entities they will have to make their own, separate financial

provision.

.

(2) Some institutions in Attachment D were already being amalgamated and in other cases proposals had been made but not necessarily finalised. The Government wished to confirm and accelerate the process of consolidation.

(3) Yes.

(4), (5), (6) and (7) The Government is concerned to ensure that the funds available for higher education are used in the most efficient and effective manner. The detailed arrangements for these matters will be considered by the Government following the receipt of the reports I have asked
the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to provide by 30 June and 31 August.

(8) Yes. An amount of $5m p.a. has been earmarked within the general recurrent grants for advanced education in the years 1982 and 1983 as additional resources for CAEs which
are able to expand their effort in the technologies and business studies.

(9) See 8 above.

(10), (11) and (12) See (4), (5), (6) and (7) above.

(13) and (14) The Government's decision to rationalise engineering courses in Victoria is based on advice from the Com-
monwealth Tertiary Education Commission which took account of the findings of the Partridge Committee in Victoria in relation to engineering education and of a working part set
up by the Victorian Post Secondary Education Commission to extend the work commenced by the Partridge Committee. I am advised that the working party considered the numerical
needs for engineering education in Victoria and recommended that the engineering schools of Melbourne, Monash, RMIT, Swinburne and Footscray could, if necessary, meet all those needs. In its Volume I Report the CTEC has explained the
difficulties associated with predicting long-term trends in manpower needs but concludes that in view of the large
number of engineering schools in Victoria and the small size of
some of them, some rationalisation is required on grounds of quality.

Retiring Age for Age Pension (Question No. 2520)
Mr Charles asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 9 June l981:
What is the estimated cost of reducing the retiring age for receipt of the age pension to 60 years.

(I) Yes.
(2) and (3) As the result of a routine request by the Public Service Board for items to be discussed by the Joint Council of the Australian Public Service, an officer submitted to his De partment a proposal ' . . . that the existing Superannu ation Scheme be altered or expanded to provide for retire ment on a 'length of service' basis in place of, or in addition to, the current 'age' basis . . .'. The Department forwarded the officer's proposal to the Australian Government Retire ment Benefits Office which referred it to the Department of Finance. Subsequently, the officer was informed by his Per manent Head that he considered that the proposal could not be pursued at this time. The Department of Finance was also informed of the Permanent Head's views. Accordingly, no re sponse was required.
(4) (a) See (2) and (3) above. (b) The basis of retirement of public servants is not determined by the Superannuation Act 1976, but by long-standing provisions now incorporated in the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Re tirement) Act 1979. There is no proposal before the Government to,change arrangements under which public servants, like the great majority of other employees throughout Australia, become eligible to retire, or are required to retire, on the grounds of age rather than length of service.

Mr HuntThe Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:
1 refer the honourable member to my answer to House of
Representatives Question No. 903, asked on 25 March 1981
by Dr Klugman and answered in the Hansard of 29 April
1981 (page 1982). In my answer I outlined the difficulties in estimating the cost of lowering the pensionable age, and provided estimates of the cost of paying an income test free pen sion to men aged 60 to 64 years at November 1980 pension rates and December I980 numbers.
Similar estimates have been prepared based on the estimated number of persons, pensioners and beneficiaries at June 1981, and pension rates applicable from May 1981. The additional cost of paying an income test free pension to residentially qualified men aged 60 to 64 years is now estimated to be about $580 million in a full year. This cost is additional to the estimated $320 million annual cost of exist ing payments to male invalid and service pensioners and un employment and sickness beneficiaries aged 60 to 64 years.

(Question No. 2613)

Services: Retention Rates (Question No. 2501)
Mrs Darling asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 June 1981:

determining the level of recurrent funds for 1982-84 for col leges of advanced education the Government has taken account of such savings in respect of institutions which have been or will be consolidated during the triennium,

Mr KillenThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

vided in answer to the Question No. 829, Hansard, 2 April
1981, (pages 1333-34).
Information for February, March and April l981 is shown in the following table.

(2) If so, (a) what was the total amount of the savings estimated with respect to all institutions, (b) what were the individual savings estimated in respect of each institution proposed for consolidation and (c) by what sum were the re current funds for colleges of advanced education reduced to take account of those savings.
Mr Fife--The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

Answers to Questions

10 June 1981 REPRESENTATIVES 3599

(1) and (2) In determining the l!lvel of recurrent funds for 1982-84 for higher education the Government endorsed the approach taken by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to rationalisation but decided to accelerate the process. As I explained in my statement on Commonwealth education policy of 4 June 1981, the Government intends that the consolidation of institutions shoul;d result in a real saving

of resources. The Government has not been prescriptive in its guidelines to the CTEC and consequently will need to await CTEC advice before taken final decisions, which could vary from State to State and from institution to institution. The CTEC will be reporting on progress by 30 June and finally in its Volume II Report by 31 August 1981.
